Whole_Text.content: The first Marcellus flood occurred on January 16, 1219. The storm surge is named after Saint Marcellus I, on whose feast day it took place. It is the first major storm surge in the North Sea for which an eyewitness account exists.

The eyewitness Emo of Wittewierum, the later abbot of the Premonstratensian monastery of Wittewierum near Groningen, recorded in the Chronicon abbatum in Werum that on January 16, 1219, "in the 55th year after the Julian flood," the "bloodthirsty southwest wind," which had already brought hail for days, turned into a storm, shifted to northwest during the night under a full moon, and caused major floods that overtopped the dikes and washed away houses. Abbot Emo attempted a natural-philosophical explanation but ultimately interpreted the Marcellus flood and the subsequent famine as a deluge "because of our crimes." The wealthy marsh farmers had not thought of the poor; therefore, they lost their land. According to an unreliable report in the Saxon World Chronicle, this severe storm surge, erroneously dated to November 17, 1218, claimed about 36,000 lives along the North Sea coast. The Colmar Annals even mention a figure of 50,000 victims. West Friesland in today's Netherlands was particularly hard hit. There, the North Sea broke through a naturally formed sand barrier, creating the Zuiderzee (southern sea), a sea bay that is now artificially separated from the North Sea as the IJsselmeer.

Some chronicles from the 16th century attributed the formation of the Jade Bight to this storm surge. According to these accounts, the water broke through at the former village mound of Alt-Gödens after destroying the legendary Schlicker Sluice, which was said to have copper doors. However, the parishes allegedly flooded at that time (Oldessen, Dauerns, Hummens, Jadele, Dangast, Arngast, and Alt-Gödens or Lee) still existed in the 1420s. Only Hiddels had already disappeared. Consequently, the expansion of the Jade Bight is to be dated to the course of the 15th century, significantly later than the storm surge legend suggests.

The floods in Finland at the beginning of October 2012 were caused by several days of continuous rainfall. Rivers flooded particularly in South Ostrobothnia and Northern Satakunta. According to meteorologist Matti Huutonen, in some places, as much rain fell in 24 hours (October 5–6) as normally falls in a month. Even outside the flood area, for example in Kokemäki and Pori, daily rainfall amounts of over 30 millimeters were recorded. In Ilmajoki, main road 67 had to be closed due to flooding. Roads were also closed elsewhere in South Ostrobothnia. In Kankaanpää, water also rose onto the roads. In Ilmajoki, Kauhajoki, and Lapväärtti, several houses were surrounded by water, and basements were flooded. In Kauhajoki, residents had to be relocated to temporary accommodations. MTV3 reported on October 8 that the flood situation was already easing, but added that it would take at least a week before water levels returned to normal for the time of year. In contrast, the flood situation in Satakunta remained severe, as Yle reported on October 15 that an additional 20 millimeters of rain was expected there. According to Bertel Vehviläinen, the leading hydrologist at the Finnish Environment Institute, the flood of the Kyrönjoki River was the largest ever recorded in Finland. Many other rivers in South Ostrobothnia also reached record-high levels.
The South Ostrobothnia ELY Centre estimated the damages in its area to be around six million euros. The greatest damages occurred in Kristiinankaupunki and Kauhajoki.

The flood in Central Europe in August 2002 was a flood disaster in Germany, the Czech Republic, and Austria. It led to severe flooding, particularly along the Elbe in eastern and northern Germany, and along the Danube in Bavaria and Austria. The flood was caused by days of extreme rainfall and resulted in weeks of relief efforts, at least 45 fatalities, and damages amounting to a total of approximately 15 billion euros (about 9 billion in Germany, of which 6 billion were in Saxony). The flood is credited with having an effect on the subsequent 2002 federal election.

As early as the beginning of August 2002, heavy and prolonged rainfall in the Alps, as well as in the Ore Mountains and Giant Mountains, caused severe flooding and devastating mudslides in Germany, Austria, Poland, the Czech Republic, and Italy. The precipitation was caused by the Vb low-pressure system "Ilse." A ridge of the high-pressure system "Friedmann" over Scandinavia caused the low to be deflected southward from its usual west-east trajectory toward the Mediterranean. Here, these air masses warmed significantly due to the seasonal conditions and absorbed a lot of moisture. After crossing the Alps northward, they encountered the cold air there, cooled down significantly, and resulted in extreme precipitation within a relatively short period. The rainfall initially concentrated along the path of the low-pressure system on Switzerland, Bavaria, Austria, and the Czech Republic, and subsequently intensified in eastern Germany. Here, the low-pressure system stalled and completely rained itself out by the end of its lifecycle. The rainfall was further intensified by orographically induced lifting processes over the Alps, but especially along the low mountain ranges (Ore and Giant Mountains). A similar weather pattern was also the cause of the Oder flood in 1997.

Whole_Text.header: Historical classification of the flood event
Whole_Text.content: The flood of 2002 surpassed the events of 1954, the strongest flood of the 20th century, across the Elbe region as well as in Austria and partially in Bavaria, and can therefore be considered a once-in-a-century event. In recorded history, it is likely only exceeded by the floods of 1342, 1501, and 1787, as well as the Alpine flood of 2005 (in the Danube region) and the Central European flood of 2013.

A first heavy rainfall event occurred on August 6/7, with focal points in the Chiemgau and Berchtesgadener Land regions. Over 48 hours, widespread precipitation of more than 100 mm was recorded, corresponding to about two-thirds of the average monthly mean (1961–1990) for August. The highest daily rainfall of 117 mm was registered in Ruhpolding on August 6; at Wendelstein, 62 mm of rain fell within just 6 hours. This event led to soil saturation and set the stage for the actual, even higher flood event caused by rainfall from August 10 to 12. On the evening of August 10, a series of thunderstorms moved into Bavaria from the west, which subsequently developed into widespread continuous rain, leading to daily precipitation of over 100 mm along the Alpine foothills on August 11. On August 12, the focus shifted to the Bavarian and Upper Palatinate Forests, resulting in a 100-year rainfall event of 104 mm in 24 hours in Waldkirchen. From August 6 to 12, over 340 mm of rain was recorded in parts of southern Bavaria. On August 12, flood peaks formed on the Danube tributaries Iller, Günz, Mindel, Zusam, Schmutter, Paar, and Lech. In the Oberallgäu district, some 100-year events were observed. On August 14, a long wave formed on the Danube between the Lech estuary and Regensburg, corresponding to a 10- to 20-year flood event. Also on August 12, peak levels were reached on the rivers Isar, Loisach, Ammer, Mangfall, Tiroler Achen, Traun, Saalach, and Salzach, with return periods ranging from 50 to 100 years. The flood wave of the Inn River led to a water level of 10.80 m and a discharge of 7,700 m³/s in Passau on August 13 at 1 p.m., corresponding to a 50-year event. This level was last exceeded in 1954 (12.20 m) and again in 2013 (12.89 m). While the Salzach flood near Burghausen reached a 50-year magnitude, the Inn River in Wasserburg experienced only a 2- to 5-year event. Thus, the 20- to 50-year flood of the Inn downstream of the Salzach confluence was significantly influenced by the Salzach. The Sylvenstein reservoir retained up to 23.3 million cubic meters of water, preventing a larger flood on the Isar. Without the reservoir, up to 730 m³/s would have flowed through Bad Tölz on August 12 instead of the recorded 295 m³/s. With the rain area shifting northward, an extreme flood with return periods of well over 100 years occurred on the night of August 13 on rivers in the Regen and Ilz catchment areas. At the confluence of the Regen and Danube in Regensburg, a water level of 6.63 m was recorded on August 14 at 1 p.m., leading to a 20-year flood up to the Isar confluence near Deggendorf and a 10-year flood further downstream to Passau.

The rain situation was particularly dramatic in the central and eastern Ore Mountains, where on August 12/13, 2002, a 24-hour value of 312 mm was recorded in Zinnwald, the highest daily rainfall amount ever registered in Germany since the start of routine measurements. Due to the poor forest condition in these areas and the already absorbed water quantities, the soil could not store such massive amounts of rainfall, causing the water to immediately flow into the valleys. Rivers originating in this region and flowing into the Mulde or Elbe, such as Zschopau, Flöha, Zwickauer Mulde, Freiberger Mulde, Gimmlitz, Rote Weißeritz, Wilde Weißeritz, and Müglitz, swelled to many times their usual size within hours, leaving enormous damage in their wake. Many bridges were washed away, roads undermined, houses flooded and severely damaged, power and telephone supplies collapsed, entire villages were evacuated or cut off from the outside world. The Müglitz Valley was particularly affected. Here, the flood wave devastated Glashütte, Schlottwitz, Weesenstein, Mühlbach, Burkhardswalde, the lower town of Dohna, and Heidenau. In Glashütte, a small retention basin on the Prießnitz, a lower tributary of the Müglitz, broke on August 12, 2002, around 5:00 PM. The flood wave, estimated at 50,000 cubic meters of water in the Prießnitz Valley, raised the water level in Glashütte by another meter but had little impact on the flooding in the Müglitz because the Prießnitzbach flows into the Müglitz further downstream. In many places, energy, water, and heat supplies failed. The flooding of federal, state, and district roads hindered emergency services. In the area of the Gottleuba and Seidewitz rivers, the flood reached the threshold of flooding in Pirna on August 12 around 5:00 PM. The Gottleuba and Seidewitz overflowed their banks up to 1.50 meters after their confluence in Pirna. In Dresden, the damage was caused not only by the first wave of the Weißeritz on August 12/13 but also by the second, higher wave of the Elbe on August 16/17. On August 12, 2002, at around 6:00 PM, a disaster alarm was declared for Dresden. In the city center, the main train station, the Semper Opera House, the Zwinger, and the state parliament were flooded. Parts of Friedrichstadt were evacuated. In the following days, the disaster situation exceeded flood warning level IV in some places. Built-up areas were partially completely flooded, and the use of water and dam defenses on a larger scale became necessary. There were also fatalities. Only on August 13, 2002, did the full extent of the natural disaster become visible. Other places were enclosed by the subsequent masses of water and cut off from the outside world. In Krippen, the water rose to the second floor. Grimma was hit by the Mulde flood and severely destroyed, including the historic Pöppelmann Bridge. On August 14, Chancellor Gerhard Schröder visited the city. The city of Döbeln was also completely flooded by the Freiberger Mulde. In the evening, tram operations in Dresden were completely suspended. On August 15, Meißen was hit by the first flood wave, partially destroying the local porcelain manufactory. By this time, Pirna had already been reached by the second wave. Entire villages in Saxon Switzerland had to be evacuated. In Dresden, the districts of Laubegast, Kleinzschachwitz, and Zschieren were flooded. On August 16, train traffic on the Leipzig–Dresden, Riesa–Chemnitz, and Jüterbog–Röderau lines, which cross the Elbe floodplain on a shared embankment, was suspended. A dike breach near Röderau caused the overflowing Elbe to undermine a road bridge and a flood culvert of the railway embankment, causing these structures to collapse. In the evening, the flood peak reached Schöna at the Czech border with a maximum level of 12.04 meters. On August 17, 2002, the water level in Dresden reached its peak of 9.40 meters at 7:00 AM. On that day, all Dresden Elbe bridges except the A4 motorway bridge were closed. In absolute comparison of flow rates, the 2002 Elbe flood ranked fifth among recorded floods in Saxony. Such floods are therefore assumed to have a recurrence interval of 100 to 200 years. The Torgau gauge reached a peak value of 9.49 meters on August 18. On August 26, the disaster alarm for Dresden was lifted. A total of 21 people lost their lives in Saxony due to the flood.

Further downstream, the increased risk of dike breaches became the main problem. The Elbe flooded an area of 592 km², of which 480 km² alone were in Saxony-Anhalt. By the evening of August 14, around 4,600 people had been evacuated from low-lying districts of Dessau. In the Bitterfeld-Wolfen chemical park (most affected was the Bayer Group), an environmental disaster was prevented through the massive deployment of helpers. The city of Bitterfeld itself became increasingly flooded in the following days. Near the city, a dam on the Mulde broke on August 15, flooding the former Goitzsche lignite mine. On the same day, the Pretziener Weir south of Magdeburg was opened, preventing the worst damage in the city area. Nevertheless, around 20,000 people were evacuated from the eastern districts of Magdeburg, and a state of emergency was declared for the city. Additionally, the Brandenburg town of Mühlberg was evacuated, and cities further downstream prepared protective measures. On the night of August 16 at 1 a.m., the crisis team decided to evacuate around 10,000 people from Bitterfeld and the surrounding area as the city was gradually being overtaken by the floodwaters. In Saxony-Anhalt alone, about 2,000 Bundeswehr soldiers were deployed. On August 17, the water level in Mühlberg reached its peak at 9.96 meters. On August 18, several dikes broke in Saxony-Anhalt near Seegrehna and Wittenberg on the Elbe, as well as near Dessau on the Mulde. In the Dessau district of Waldersee, the water quickly rose to two meters high. A sandbag logistics center was set up at Leipzig/Halle Airport to supply all endangered areas. On August 19, the situation on the A9 motorway escalated, but a single-lane traffic flow was ensured. The floodwaters moved north faster than expected. The first flood wave reached the state capital Magdeburg, which, not least due to the Elbe flood bypass canal, escaped relatively unscathed. On August 20, when the village center of Rehsen was threatened with flooding, the residents of the village manually breached the dike of the inhabited Schönitzer polder to relieve their own dike. The fire chief of Rehsen and four other individuals were subsequently charged by the public prosecutor's office with dike destruction but were ultimately acquitted due to a lack of evidence of specific involvement. By August 21, more than 60,000 people had been evacuated from endangered areas in Brandenburg and Saxony-Anhalt. On August 22, around 16,300 Bundeswehr soldiers were deployed in Saxony, Saxony-Anhalt, and Brandenburg. 

On August 26, the state of emergency for Magdeburg was lifted. Due to the slow receding of the water, the state of emergency in Dessau could only be lifted on September 13, after 32 days.

Federal Chancellor Gerhard Schröder met with his counterparts from Austria, the Czech Republic, and Slovakia, as well as EU Commission President Romano Prodi, for a flood summit. The endangered cities of Dannenberg, Boizenburg, Lauenburg, and other locations prepared for the flood. Hundreds of helpers were deployed for massive dike reinforcement. Starting on August 16, the evacuation of around 30,000 people from Mecklenburg and Lower Saxony was prepared. On August 21, another 13,000 people had to be evacuated from flood areas in Schleswig-Holstein.

In Dresden, the damage to the Semperoper alone amounted to 27 million euros. The State Art Collections, which include the Gemäldegalerie, estimated the damage at 20 million euros. In Saxony alone, 32 sewage treatment plants along the Elbe (Dresden-Kaditz, Pirna, Meißen, and Riesa) failed during the flood due to flooding or power outages. As a result, untreated wastewater entered the Elbe. In Saxony, 21 deaths were reported due to the flood. From 2002 to 2009, 700 million euros were spent on protection projects, 50% of which came from EU funds. Following the evaluation of the flood, a total of 300 flood zones covering an area of 76,000 hectares were declared. In Saxony-Anhalt, the damage to agriculture amounted to around 420 million euros. Damage and consequential effects to Deutsche Bahn facilities totaled 1.025 billion euros, of which 750 million euros were in the Free State of Saxony. In addition to numerous routes, including the Dresden–Werdau and Leipzig–Dresden lines, around 200 train stations were also affected; at Dresden Central Station alone, damages amounted to 42 million euros. The federal government contributed a total of 650 million euros to the costs of restoring railway facilities.

In the Czech Republic, the rainfall began on August 5, 2002. Initially, South Bohemia was affected, including the catchment areas of the Vltava, Lužnice, Malše, and Blanice rivers, later followed by the Berounka, Otava, and Sázava rivers. From August 11, 2002, the water masses from the Ohře and Bílina rivers in Northwest Bohemia were added. Within nine days in August, the affected regions experienced rainfall equivalent to three summer months of the long-term average. Already in June and July, above-average rainfall had occurred, and the soil's storage capacity was exhausted. Initially, numerous locations in the flat area around České Budějovice were flooded, and the emerging danger was underestimated. The reservoirs of the Vltava, filled to the brim, should have released about 1000 m³/s of water preventively, which would have mitigated the later peak. At the beginning of the second week, the water level in Prague rose to a gauge height of seven meters. At this point, the spillways had to be opened. To the South Bohemian water masses from the Vltava with 3000 m³/s, an additional 2000 m³/s from the unregulated Sázava and Berounka rivers joined before Prague. In Prague, the normal flow rate is 150 m³/s; at this time, an estimated 5300 m³/s was reached. The flooding of the Old Town was prevented by barriers on the riverside streets. However, the subway ceased operations. The Karlín district had to be evacuated. At the confluence of the Vltava and Elbe rivers near Mělník, the water masses spread into the plain. The village of Zálezlice, located near the confluence, was two-thirds destroyed. At the bottleneck below in the Bohemian Switzerland region, the water accumulated. The transition to Germany occurred through the narrow Elbe Valley of the Elbe Sandstone Mountains. The peak level in Ústí nad Labem (Aussig) was reached on the afternoon of August 16, 2002. The water flow of the Elbe exceeded the previous highest level from 1845. The water volume in the Vltava exceeded the 1845 level by almost one-fifth.

In the Czech Republic, 17 people died due to the flooding. The damages in the Czech Republic are estimated at 3.3 billion euros. 446 localities were flooded, 99 of which were completely underwater. 1.33 million people were directly affected, and 200,000 were evacuated. Except for Orlík and Slapy, the machine houses of all Vltava hydroelectric power plants were flooded. Around 1,000 animals were evacuated from the Prague Zoo, but 134 others (including 10 mammals) died in the floods. The Prague Metro was two-fifths flooded and could only be fully operational again in March 2003. The damage to the subway amounted to around 280 million euros. Near the confluence of the Vltava and Elbe rivers, the Czech chemical and pharmaceutical plant Spolana in Neratovice was flooded, and waste and operating materials were washed away. One of the 17 flood victims was a 53-year-old man who was fatally struck by an iron fragment while watching the detonation of a drifting inland ship in Děčín.

In Austria, the highest two-day precipitation total was measured in the Waldviertel region of Lower Austria in Weikertschlag, Waidhofen an der Thaya district, with 246 mm. Similarly high precipitation amounts were recorded in the Gmünd district (Lower Austria), the Freistadt district (Mühlviertel, Upper Austria), as well as in the northwestern Mostviertel (Lower Austria). However, the region around Salzburg was also heavily affected. The resulting runoff volumes reached their peak levels on August 7th and 8th. Unlike previous floods, this time areas were affected for which no comparable figures have been recorded in at least the last 100 years, namely the Machland region in Upper Austria, the southern Mühlviertel, and the Kamp and Krems valleys in Lower Austria.

In the Mühlviertel, the Aist catchment area with its numerous source rivers was most severely affected by the catastrophic extent. The municipality of Schwertberg in the Perg district was flooded during the night of August 7 to 8 and was partially over 1.20 m under water. Maximum flow rates were also observed in Freistadt and Kefermarkt (both on the Feldaist), in Königswiesen on the Große Naarn, in Unterweißenbach on the Kleine Naarn, and in St. Georgen on the Gusen.

On the night of August 6 to 7, the water level of the upper Kamp began to rise. On the afternoon of August 7, the water threatened to overflow the Ottenstein dam, necessitating the opening of the flood relief gates. By midnight on August 8, the water level in Zwettl was 4 meters above the average water level. While cleanup efforts had already begun in the upper reaches of the Kamp on August 9, dramatic scenes unfolded in the lower reaches. In addition to the destruction of roads and buildings in the Kamp Valley, the Kamp dams overflowed below Hadersdorf am Kamp, leading to dam breaches and flooding of the northern Tullnerfeld and numerous villages. The Kamp floodwaters were hindered from flowing into the Danube by the Danube flood protection dams. Only after opening polders and dams could the situation be alleviated. The Lainsitz also showed high water levels in the Waldviertel, but it lies beyond the watershed and belongs to the Elbe's catchment area.
In the Salzach area, several smaller streams did overflow their banks, causing some property damage, but not the Salzach and the Saalach, which only exceeded the flood boundaries.

All Austrian regions along the entire northern side of the Alps from Vorarlberg to Hainburg an der Donau were affected by the second wave. The centers of precipitation amounts were in the Ennstal, the Salzkammergut, and again in the Mühl- and Waldviertel. The highest two-day precipitation total was measured this time in Laussa, Steyr-Land district (Upper Austria) with 227 mm.

Due to the heavy rainfall in southeastern Bavaria, the flood situation on the Danube was already extremely tense. The areas along the Lech and the Tiroler Ache were affected by flooding. Along the Salzach, there was already land under water starting from Golling. The additionally high water levels of the Traun and Enns rivers led to extensive Danube flooding from the Upper Austrian Machland, through the Wachau, the Tullnerfeld, and the area east of Vienna.

At Aist and Naarn, where the ground could no longer absorb water due to the first flood wave, there were severe floods again. Schwertberg was even more deeply submerged this time than during the first wave.

In the lower course of the Kamp, where the water level had hardly receded since the first wave, there were massive floods again. Due to the high Danube level, the Kamp water could not flow into the Danube this time, and more villages were under water than the week before.
In Austria, seven fatalities were reported. The total economic damage was initially estimated at €3.1 billion in 2003.
The total financial damage caused by the flood event is listed below.[28]

The Deutsche Rück reports approximately 2.5 billion euros in higher damages for Saxony. This would result in damages of 8.6 billion euros in Saxony, 11.6 billion euros in Germany, and 17.5 billion euros in Europe. The damages to public infrastructure amounted to 1.353 billion euros, of which 1.025 billion euros were incurred by Deutsche Bahn. Of this, 750 million euros were attributed to the Saxony region.

The flood event had drastic effects on the election campaign for the upcoming federal elections on September 22, 2002.[30] The SPD-led federal government responded promptly to the flood disaster and initiated the largest domestic deployment of the Bundeswehr in its history.[31] As early as August 20, 2002, approximately 45,000 Bundeswehr soldiers were deployed in the affected regions to reinforce dikes, carry out evacuations, and coordinate disaster relief. Numerous politicians, including Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, regularly visited the affected areas under significant media attention.[32] The government quickly allocated 385 million euros to support those affected by the flood in rebuilding. Payments amounted to 500 euros per person and up to 2,000 euros per household. Affected businesses received a flat rate of 15,000 euros and 500 euros per employee.[33] On August 26, the government passed a draft law for a 7.1 billion euro state fund for reconstruction aid in the flood-affected areas,[13] which the Bundesrat approved on September 13.[34] A political science study concluded that the flood relief measures of the SPD-led German government increased the SPD's share of votes in the affected areas by up to seven percentage points in the 2002 federal elections and by two percentage points in the 2005 federal elections.[35] Critics argue that politics and administration drew only limited actual consequences from the flood. Of the 35,000 hectares identified in 2002 as potential floodplain areas along the Elbe, less than five percent were implemented. Additionally, construction bans stipulated in various state laws were often circumvented by district administrators through special permits.[36]

In Austria, the Flood Victim Compensation and Reconstruction Act 2002 (HWG 2002) was passed in September, providing additional funds amounting to 250 million euros alongside a fund. Due to the flood disaster, the Schüssel I government, with the approval of the FPÖ ministers, decided to postpone the tax reform that had been promised to voters by the FPÖ. This and other differences of opinion prompted Haider and other members of the party's right-wing faction, such as Ewald Stadler, to demand the convening of a special party congress (Knittelfeld FPÖ Assembly 2002) from the party leadership under the relatively liberal Susanne Riess-Passer and to collect signatures from elected delegates for this purpose. The events of this assembly led to a power shift within the party, the resignation of several FPÖ ministers, the collapse of the first FPÖ-ÖVP coalition under Federal Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel, and ultimately early elections (Austrian National Council election 2002), in which the FPÖ lost almost two-thirds of its voters. The Freedom Party also suffered significant losses in voter support in most state elections (except in Carinthia) between 2003 and 2005. Similarly, in the municipal and mayoral elections in Carinthia in 2003, the municipal elections in Lower Austria in 2005, and later in Styria, the FPÖ lost voters. After the electoral defeat in the municipal elections in Lower Austria in 2005, the former FPÖ chairman Jörg Haider proposed a re-establishment of the FPÖ as a "casual, dynamic, and young" party, and stated that he would be willing to take over its leadership "in an emergency." When this proposal did not receive unanimous approval within the party, and a contested vote against Vienna FPÖ chairman Heinz-Christian Strache loomed at a party congress scheduled for April 23, Haider announced on April 4, 2005, the founding of the new party Alliance for the Future of Austria (BZÖ) and declared his intention to become its first chairman. The BZÖ subsequently replaced the FPÖ in the Schüssel II government.

Deployed auxiliary forces in Germany included, among others, the Bundeswehr, the police, the Federal Border Guard, the fire department, the DLRG, the THW, the DRK, as well as numerous other aid organizations.[38] Soldiers of the Bundeswehr provided a total of 270,000 man-days of deployment, with an additional 190,000 man-days of readiness. A total of 46,600 soldiers were involved in the operation.[39] The Elbe flood of 2002 was at the time the largest operation in the history of the THW, with 24,000 emergency personnel working 1,750,000 hours and using technical equipment.[40] The German crisis management team was at times overwhelmed with coordinating the aid forces. As a result, some non-local fire department units had to wait in vain for the assignment of an operational area.[41]

As the issuer of postage stamps in Germany, the Federal Ministry of Finance published an extraordinary 56-cent special stamp with a 44-cent surcharge in favor of flood victims on August 30, 2002, with a circulation of 6,740,000 copies. Due to the short-notice release date, which did not allow for a design competition for the stamp motif, the Ministry used the motif of the 1998 special stamp "Protection of Coasts and Seas" and only adjusted the inscription and value indication.
There were a number of awards for helpers in the fight against the floods.

Whole_Text.content: The Elbe flood in March and April 2006 was among the strongest floods ever recorded along almost the entire course of the river and differs from the usual spring floods of the Elbe, which are caused by thawing in the upper reaches. Affected areas included the Czech tributaries Vltava and Ohře, parts of the two Mulde rivers, and almost the entire course of the Elbe from Hradec Králové (Königgrätz) through the Czech and Saxon upper reaches to the northern German middle and lower reaches. Especially in the lower middle course, the flood is comparable to the flood of 2002, but it passed through the river in a much longer flood wave. At the beginning of April, some towns, such as Hitzacker in Lower Saxony, were largely flooded. The mark of the century flood of 2002 was reached or even exceeded in some places. In Lauenburg, this occurred as early as April 7.

The trigger for the flooding was intense thawing in the low mountain ranges at the upper course of the Elbe. In the ridge areas of the Ore Mountains, Bohemian Central Uplands, as well as in the Bohemian Forest and Giant Mountains, snow depths of over 1.5 meters accumulated throughout the winter. Due to previous short thawing processes and the long duration of snow cover, the snow was comparatively highly compressed and water-rich. At the end of March, a rapid melting of the snow masses occurred due to a sharp temperature rise and heavy precipitation. In the Ore Mountains, precipitation was comparatively low, so there was no dangerous flooding in the tributaries of the upper Elbe. At the beginning of March, these waters had already experienced flooding, which appeared more dangerous due to ice jams. Heavy precipitation fell at the end of March, particularly in southern Czechia and the central Bohemian Basin. Further causes must be sought for the significant swelling of the river in the lower middle course. On the one hand, in the southern middle course, especially in Saxony-Anhalt, dike systems were raised and renewed along entire stretches since 2002. These withstood the Elbe and prevented the flooding of retention areas as in 2002. This is accompanied by unfavorable river construction. Another reason for exceeding the 2002 flood mark north of Magdeburg lies in the stretched flood wave, which triggered the highest alarm levels simultaneously along the several hundred kilometers from Lower Saxony to the Moldau estuary. In the middle course, the flow velocity decreased, leading to the compression of the wave.

In southern Czechia, several tributaries of the Elbe overflowed; large areas had to be evacuated. The Elbe itself also rose so high that evacuations occurred. In Czechia, several people lost their lives in the river floods.

The very elongated flood peak passed through Saxony between April 1 and 5. In Dresden, the water level on April 4 was 7.49, about 2 meters below the record level of 2002. For some districts of Dresden (Kleinzschachwitz, Pillnitz, Laubegast, and Gohlis), as well as for numerous municipalities in the districts of Sächsische Schweiz, Meißen, and Torgau-Oschatz, a state of emergency had to be declared. Apart from disruptions in road traffic (closure of numerous riverside roads and the Loschwitz Bridge), Dresden was little affected by the flood. The district of Gohlis, whose dike is designed for up to 7.40 meters, was the most at risk. The cities of Bad Schandau, Pirna, and Meißen were more severely flooded than Dresden. In Dresden, most of the damage occurred due to flooded basements, although in some cases, such as in Zschieren, houses were also flooded. In Dresden, the Elbe's water level was still almost 5 meters, more than twice the normal level, on April 18, two weeks after the peak had passed, and remained in the flood level range for weeks.

In Saxony-Anhalt and Brandenburg, the dikes withstood the flood. After the 2002 flood, the dike systems of the Elbe were renewed over entire stretches, especially in these two states. Magdeburg was relieved by the Elbe flood relief canal. In both states, the prolonged flood peak became more of a threat because it exerted high pressure on the dikes for a very long time.

In Lower Saxony, Hitzacker was particularly heavily flooded. The water there was higher than in 2002. Hitzacker is not protected by any dikes and was thus flooded throughout the entire town center. Parts of the old town of Lauenburg in Schleswig-Holstein were also flooded by the Elbe.

The Elster flood was a flood event classified as a centennial flood in 2010 on the Schwarze Elster and its tributaries.

August in the year 2010 was characterized by Atlantic low-pressure systems that brought precipitation with prolonged heavy rain, especially in the catchment area of the Schwarze Elster. The cause of the prolonged and heavy rainfall was a Vb weather pattern. In this pattern, air masses deviate from their usual west-east direction towards the Mediterranean to the south. Here, these air masses warm up and absorb a lot of moisture. After crossing the Alps northward, they encounter the cold air there, cool down significantly, and result in extreme precipitation in a relatively short time. This weather pattern was also the cause of the Oder flood (1997) and the Elbe flood (2002).

Starting on September 24, 2010, there were widespread heavy rains in the Elbe-Elster region. Between Fläming and the Saxon Upper Lusatia, more than 100 liters of rain per square meter fell in some areas from September 24 to September 27. As a result, on September 29, the Schwarze Elster and its two tributaries, Große Röder and Pulsnitz, which flow into it at Elsterwerda, reached flood warning level 4. After flood alert level 3 had already been declared throughout the Elbe-Elster district the day before and a crisis team had been formed, District Administrator Christian Jaschinski was forced to declare a disaster alert at 11:50 a.m. on this day. Due to further rising water levels, preparations began in Elsterwerda, where the water level of the Schwarze Elster had risen to about 3.50 meters, for the voluntary evacuation of the city center, which was at risk of flooding. At the official gauge in Bad Liebenwerda, located about ten kilometers downstream, 3.50 meters were also measured. By evening, the tense situation required the closure of the first roads and bridges. While the newly constructed important Elster bridge in Elsterwerda remained open, bridges over the Schwarze Elster in Saathain and Bad Liebenwerda, as well as the partially flooded federal highway 169 near Plessa, the district road 6207 between Saathain and Stolzenhain, and the village road through Schmerkendorf, had to be closed. Near Ortrand, where the Pulsnitz overflowed its banks, the federal highway A 13 also had to be closed due to flooding. The escalating situation also attracted increased media interest, with several television teams from public and private broadcasters reporting live from the region. On Thursday, September 30, all schools in Elsterwerda, Bad Liebenwerda, and Herzberg, as well as schools in Annaburg, were closed for students affected by the flooding. On this day, maximum water levels were measured at all gauges along the Schwarze Elster, reaching record levels never before recorded. The measured peak flow of the Schwarze Elster in Löben was now 128 m³/s, corresponding to a discharge characteristic of HQ 200. The water level in Bad Liebenwerda reached an absolute record high of 3.55 meters during the night, never before measured. From then on, it began to slightly decrease here, while levels in downstream locations continued to rise. The situation remained critical at the increasingly softening dikes of the Schwarze Elster. Weak points and cracks, such as between Kotschka and Saathain, where the dike began to overflow over a length of about 50 meters, were sealed as quickly as possible with sandbags by emergency forces and the help of rushing residents. For safety reasons, the voluntary evacuation of about 2,700 residents began in Elsterwerda at this time, with police vehicles driving through the city and public notices urging residents to leave their homes and properties. The district hospital of the city, located in close proximity to the river, was also evacuated using ambulances and helicopters. About 100 patients were transferred within about four hours to nearby hospitals in Herzberg, Finsterwalde, Lauchhammer, Riesa, Großenhain, or Dresden. Despite all efforts by emergency forces, a disaster occurred the following day about twenty kilometers upstream from the Elster estuary. On October 1, at around 12:50 p.m., the left-side dike of the Schwarze Elster near Meuselko broke at a water level of 3.34 meters, measured at the Löben gauge. Just over four hours later, at around 5:00 p.m., a disaster alert was declared for the entire Wittenberg district. Eight hours later, parts of the village of Löben, located two kilometers downstream, were flooded, and the Waltersdorf district was cut off from the outside world. The prolonged peak of the flood ensured that the disaster alert for the Elbe-Elster district, except for the city of Herzberg/Elster, was not lifted until October 6. On October 7, with the permanent drop below flood warning level 4 at the Löben gauge, the disaster alert for the Wittenberg district and the city of Herzberg was lifted. The dike near Meuselko, which had broken over a length of about 30 meters, was closed on October 5, despite water levels remaining constant and in some cases still rising.

A final report on the flood disaster published in 2010 recorded over 100 damage points on the dike in the Elbe-Elster district alone, through which 58 kilometers of the Schwarze Elster flow, which had to be secured, stabilized, raised, and repaired. Additionally, up to 2,000 helpers were deployed. The estimated agricultural damages in Brandenburg amounted to approximately 3 million euros. The costs for the nine-day disaster operation in the Elbe-Elster district were stated to be up to 2 million euros. Immediate damages to hydraulic structures in the Wittenberg district caused by the flooding were estimated at 670,000 euros. The preliminary estimated costs for dike rehabilitation in Brandenburg (as of 2011) were stated to be up to 50 million euros, with an additional 50 million euros planned by the state of Saxony-Anhalt for the rehabilitation of dikes along the Schwarze Elster by 2020. In the eastern part of the Annaburg Heath, several hectares of forest were destroyed due to the over five-month-long flooding and a high groundwater level caused by the flood.

Whole_Text.header: Further floods on the Schwarze Elster in the past
Whole_Text.content: Due to the significant straightening of the riverbed, which mostly took place in the mid-19th century, the Schwarze Elster now flows as a canal through the landscape. The extensive floodplain forests adjacent to the river and the meandering course of the Schwarze Elster disappeared, and recurring floods no longer had the opportunity to use these areas as compensation zones. As a result, water levels rose with each flood, leading to further expansion of flood protection measures. Just a few years after the regulation of the Schwarze Elster began, the newly constructed dikes broke in 1861 due to a flood. Flooding along the river was also reported in the years 1862, 1871, 1895, and 1907. Another devastating flood on the Schwarze Elster became known in 1926. A breach of the Röder dam near the small village of Würdenhain flooded the entire village on June 18, 1926. The flood affected nearly all rivers in the area, including the Röder, Pulsnitz, Schwarze Elster, and Kleine Elster, causing enormous damage. In the floodplain of the then-district of Bad Liebenwerda, two-thirds of the harvest was destroyed that year. Downstream, in the Mönchenhöfe area, up to 144 hectares of flooded land were reported. In June of the following year, during the summer flood near Mückenberg (Lauchhammer-West), a breach of the Elster dam occurred, which could only be closed with great effort.
