The Weser breakthrough in March 1981 occurred in the northwestern German city of Bremen and was a relatively narrowly confined flood event. However, due to its intensity and the extensive urban redevelopment it triggered, it holds lasting significance in the city's history. The flood is considered the culmination and northern endpoint of a geographically widespread flood situation that at the time dominated the course of the Upper and Middle Weser as well as some of its source and tributary rivers. Flood peaks of the Weser and its tributary Aller, caused by rain and snowmelt, converged near Verden. In Bremen, the flood encountered a critical river bend at the Weser weir, which was only limitedly controllable and significantly reduced the discharge cross-section, prompting the water to carve a new path instead. In the process, two summer dike breaches occurred immediately above and below the weir. Over 120 allotment gardens were destroyed, and massive landscape damage was caused. Although the plots were located in the designated overflow area and the flood remained within its bounds, hardly anyone had anticipated a flood of such magnitude "from above"—that is, as inland flooding. All dike construction measures up to that point had been aimed at protecting the allotment gardeners from storm surges from the sea. Under the impact of the Weser breakthrough, the responsible authorities developed a new flood management concept for the affected areas, which was gradually implemented in the following years. Relocations, expansions, and new constructions of dikes, roads, and waterways sustainably altered the city's landscape.

Essentially, the Weser breakthrough in 1981 affected the southern Bremen district of Habenhausen, which is part of the Obervieland district. However, there were also landscape damages in other districts. Habenhausen – a neighborhood at the time almost exclusively characterized by residential buildings – is bordered by the Weser to the east and north. The river makes a sharp bend to the west around the district, where the Weser weir is located. The old structure, still existing in 1981, was built between 1906 and 1911 to create an artificial boundary against the tides and simultaneously ensure a minimum water level for inland navigation through a barrage. It separates the Middle Weser from the Lower Weser. Within this sharp river bend lies a wide area with grasslands and allotment gardens, which today make up about one-fifth of Habenhausen's area. This area experienced the most severe destruction as a result of the flood. The area is shielded from the Weser only by low summer dikes; only directly in front of the regular residential area further south does a winter dike protect the houses. With the Werder Bridge (officially called Karl Carstens Bridge today, colloquially known as the Strawberry Bridge), Habenhausen has had a long connection to the north since 1971, leading to the Hastedt district, which belongs to the Hemelingen district. At the southern foot of the bridge, there was a significant bend in the winter dike in 1981, where the floodwaters pressed with full flow intensity. This spot was later straightened. The second significant body of water in Habenhausen is the Werdersee, which was 2.7 kilometers long at the time. It was created between 1953 and 1960 in an east-west orientation according to plans by Wilhelm Hübotter, south of the Stadtwerder, as a flood channel and ended in 1981 about 180 meters west of the bridge. It was intended that the lake would protect Habenhausen from storm surges in case dikes broke along the Weser, which flows almost parallel further north. Additionally, it was supposed to absorb floodwaters that – like the Weser breakthrough – originated eastward in the Weser bend designated as an overflow area. The lake extended westward to the Deichschartweg, which ran on a small dam in a southwest-northeast direction. On the other side of the dam, the Kleine Weser continued, a small tributary of the Weser. There was only a connection between the Werdersee and the Kleine Weser through a few small culverts.

On November 13, 1980, a routine flushing of the weir chamber was carried out in the left sector of the Bremen Weser Weir, which had been in operation since 1911. During this process, a defect occurred when the sector broke through the upper end position due to advanced corrosion of the locking mechanism, destroying the seals. It was immediately reset after the incident, preventing the dam stage from draining. By December 24 of the same year, the damaged seals were partially replaced; however, an emergency lock still made it impossible to control the sector. As a result, a serious problem arose: the more water flowed downstream, the greater the load on the functioning right weir field, while at the same time, the outflow was increasingly slowed. Calculations indicated that only 1,500 m³ of water per second could flow out regularly. 

In the early days of March the following year, maritime polar air flowed into Germany, bringing light rain or snowfall. At that time, the snow cover in the Harz was slightly above the long-term average. Between March 6 and March 11, several low-pressure troughs moved northeast across Germany, initially bringing tropical warm air and, from March 10, maritime polar air again. This resulted in prolonged rainfall, particularly heavy from March 9 to March 11 (e.g., 96 mm in the Kahlen Asten area and 131 mm in the Oderbrück district of Sankt Andreasberg), which, combined with rapid snowmelt in the low mountain ranges – such as the Weserbergland and the Rhön – quickly caused the Weser and Aller tributaries from the low mountain ranges to swell. Favorable temperatures also caused almost complete snowmelt in the Harz. The water volumes flowing from the mountains exceeded the flood storage capacities of the Eder and Diemel dams; three reservoirs in the western Harz also overflowed. Although the flood peak of the Fulda preceded that of the Werra significantly, considerable flooding had already occurred in the Upper Weser. The flood peak passed the Weser gauge at Hannoversch Münden on March 12 and reached the gauges in Vlotho and Porta Westfalica on March 14. 

The Middle Weser region was also affected by the flood situation, particularly downstream of the confluence with the Aller, which was also experiencing flooding. The immense inflow caused the Weser outflow to swell to critical levels, leading to the flooding of the Bruchwiesen near Thedinghausen. Initially, this did not provoke any press reports, as these uninhabited areas were often at least partially underwater. Between March 12 and March 14, low-pressure troughs moving from west to east brought further rain. Only from March 15, with significantly lower temperatures, did precipitation decrease. In some areas upstream of Bremen, however, the winter dikes soon came under threat, and on March 12, the Weser-Kurier reported for the first time on a potential flood in the Hanseatic city in a small, 18-line article titled "Flood Wave Endangers Allotment Gardens." Subsequently, various allotment gardeners in the city began evacuating their small houses located in officially designated overflow areas. 

The summer dike running along the left bank a few hundred meters upstream of the Weser Weir was designed for up to 1,300 m³ of water per second. Therefore, an overflow was expected on March 13, which would have resulted in the flooding of the allotment garden areas Hastedter Bulten and Fresenbulten behind it before the water could be channeled back into the river via the Werdersee and Kleine Weser flood channels as planned. Initially, this did not occur but was then rescheduled by experts for the early morning hours of March 14, though it again did not happen. Meanwhile, at the Weser Weir, due to the exceptionally high water level, there was hardly any noticeable difference in level between the Middle and Lower Weser gauges.

The first serious damage caused by the flood occurred in Bremen on the morning of March 15, when around 7 a.m. the riverside path below the so-called "Weir Castle" on the right bank near the weir began to collapse. The fire department deployed twelve emergency vehicles and secured already fallen trees with wire ropes—on the one hand to prevent obstruction of shipping if they fell into the river, and on the other hand to use them as a natural protective barrier for the shoreline. Four trees (poplars and beeches) had to be felled, and 18 others were tied down with steel cables. By noon, however, the water had washed away three meters of the riverbank. The backwater at the damaged weir caused the Weser River—already expected for two days—to overflow the summer dike, which was between 6.50 and 6.70 meters high, and partially erode it. After the westward-flowing floodwaters poured over fields, grasslands, and bird meadows, the designated Werdersee flood channel was filled, but most of the flood unexpectedly flowed further north, destroying several allotment garden areas. About 120 meters east of the Karl-Carstens Bridge, the water hit the summer dike (on the left bank of the Weser) from the land side, putting so much pressure on it that it gave way and broke around 3 p.m. Within an hour, this breach had multiplied in size. The water flowed back into the Weser more than four kilometers upstream from the point where the Werdersee would have had its regular inlet. In the process, about 100 allotment garden plots were washed into the Weser. The water police tried to stop and secure drifting huts, cars, and detached boats with small tugs, succeeding only partially and sometimes six kilometers further downstream. The river bypassed the weir in a short time and created a new, deep riverbed within a few hours. A large part of the Weser water now flowed around the weir on the left side. This new stream—from the overflowed summer dike on the Middle Weser through the overfilled area with allotments to the breach of the winter dike and the backflow into the Lower Weser—quickly became known as the "New Weser." The water also caused severe damage to the banks of the intended flood channel. Particularly affected was the bend in the winter dike at the Karl-Carstens Bridge, as the water pressed directly against this protrusion. Around 6 p.m., an inflow of 1850 m³ per second with a rising trend was measured at the weir. The police closed the paths leading directly into the flooded area, including access roads to the Weser weir. In the evening, about 3.3 kilometers in a straight line from the main flood area, the road embankment separating the Werdersee from the Kleine Weser broke at the west end of the Werdersee, on the road leading from the Buntentor Deichschart in Bremen Neustadt to the "Kuhhirten" restaurant on Stadtwerder. This breach allowed better drainage of the Werdersee, which contributed only slightly to a quick improvement of the situation but led to the lake draining into the Kleine Weser after the flood peak. The next day, March 16, a new flood wave of 1900 m³ per second turned the already wide breach in the winter dike from the previous day into a powerful stream, washing 50 more plots into the river. The water flowed back into the Weser but was not carried away by its current; instead, it pressed against the riverbank on the opposite right side further downstream, causing significant damage there as well. Trees previously secured with steel cables were washed away. In some places, the riverbank eroded up to five meters. For example, the promenade between the fish ladder—where the force of the water broke apart concrete boxes—and the Jakobsberg sports field completely collapsed. The Hemelingen harbor facilities on the right bank of the Weser above the weir were also flooded knee-deep despite high sheet pile walls. Work had to be stopped in the Allerhafen. Water seeped out between the gates that sealed off the roads into the harbor. Sandbag barriers were erected near the access road to the A1 federal highway. While a Weser outflow of up to 2,650 m³ per second was reported from Verden in the afternoon, the promenade at the dike bend near the bridge slipped two-thirds of the way down by noon despite the efforts of the helpers who had since arrived. If the winter dike had broken here, large parts of the residential areas in Habenhausen would have been flooded. It was considered to dig a channel to absorb water immediately west of the bridge, but the work took too long. At 5 p.m., 200 helpers from the fire department, the Technical Relief Agency, and the riot police began building a relief dam from the damaged dike bend to the bridge pier. By 4 a.m. the next morning, March 17, this dam was completed, and the flood risk for Habenhausen was temporarily averted. On both March 15 and 16, the grotesque sight of the devastated allotment garden areas attracted thousands of onlookers who gathered on the Werder Bridge. Some even cheered individual huts being washed into the Weser. Snack stands were even set up on the slightly elevated pedestrian and bike path. The police had up to 120 officers on duty at times and struggled to keep the roadway clear for car traffic. The behavior of the "disaster tourists" was heavily criticized both during the flood and in retrospect. A total of about 550 allotment gardeners were affected by the flood, with the Hastedter Bulten e.V. being hit harder than the neighboring Fresenbulten e.V., where initially only about 40 huts were underwater. Around 6 a.m. on March 17, the road surface of Hannoversche Straße in Hemelingen partially collapsed, presumably due to underwashing from the flooded Allerhafen. By late afternoon, the water level at the Weser weir had dropped by six centimeters, and the feared risk of a weir breach was temporarily averted. Nevertheless, scouring up to twelve meters deep was observed in the now 150-meter-wide "New Weser." In this area, in addition to the allotments, eight network stations of the municipal utilities (now swb AG) were destroyed. By the afternoon of March 18, the water level at the Weser weir had dropped from 7.04 to 6.95 meters, according to the Bremen Water Management Office. In the residential area located directly behind the softened dike on the southern edge of the flooded area, the fire department had to pump out basements on Habenhauser Dorfstraße and Holzdamm. As the peak of the disaster seemed to have passed, another small embankment above the Weser weir on the left bank—the so-called Boat Harbor Dike at the marina of the Upper Weser Sailing Club—broke at 2 a.m. on the night of March 19. In the following days, the sheet pile walls, a small peninsula, and the regatta tower there were washed away. Although club members built sandbag and stone barriers, they could only limit the erosion and not stop it. As a result, while the Weser weir was further relieved, the "New Weser" was additionally fed with several million cubic meters of water. This also intensified the breach back into the Weser east of the Werder Bridge again in the course of the morning. Around 1 p.m., another 15-meter-long and five-meter-deep section of the dike's soil was washed away about 30 meters east of the bridge. The additional water masses caused significant damage to the opposite Weser bank again after flowing back into the Weser, hitting it at almost a right angle. Although the Water Management Office tried to fill the holes in the embankment, they had little success. By 10 a.m., the Hastedter allotment garden area "Im Suhrfelde" had been evacuated as a precaution. Subsequently, both the Osterdeich between Stader Straße and the Weser weir and, due to concerns about structural stability, the Werder Bridge were closed to all traffic for several days. The "New Weser" continued to erode deeper into the ground of fields, allotment garden areas, and marshes hour by hour, so the flow velocity in the Hastedter Bulten area initially hardly changed. The Weser outflow dropped to 960 m³ per second by March 24, but the water receded only slowly from the flooded areas. It was not until April that a medium water flow was restored at the weir. Just under two months later, on June 9, another flood with a peak flow rate of 1100 m³ per second reached the Hanseatic city but remained largely without consequences.

Whole_Text.header: Cleanup work in the first year
Whole_Text.content:
Five days after the first breach of the Weser into the overflow areas, securing and later cleanup operations began. On the morning of March 20, during one of the regular static measurements at the Werder Bridge, it was discovered that a pillar had twisted by one and a half centimeters. A seven-meter-deep scour had formed around it. However, authorities declared there was no danger. To support the pillar, normal stones as well as over 150 tetrapods and so-called delta stones were sunk at the site on the same day. Additionally, officials at the Water Management Office voted for the construction of a pontoon bridge over the water surface of the "New Weser," following the interrupted Wehrstraße and to be built by the Bundeswehr. It was planned that starting March 23, trucks would transport stones over the bridge to fill the dike breach located above the weir. The dike closure work was to begin at the site of the Oberweser Sailing Club, where the "New Weser" originated with a width of 180 meters. Also on March 20, the Budget Committee of the Finance Deputation allocated 500,000 Deutsche Marks to be advanced for dike repairs. Meanwhile, the SPD local association in Hastedt called on the Senate and its own parliamentary group to restore the recreational and green areas in the district between the weir and Jakobsberg as quickly as possible. On March 22, 150 soldiers from the 160th Floating Bridge Battalion from Minden and the 11th Heavy Engineer Battalion from Dörverden began constructing a 500-meter-long steel mat road on a sand bed from the southern start of the Wehrstraße in the Habenhausen residential area directly toward the Middle Weser over the flooded meadows. A prior survey had revealed that the original plan—construction along the Wehrstraße—was not feasible. The current in that area would have been too strong for the bridge. Additionally, there were concerns that Bundeswehr vehicles might get stuck in the silt after the "New Weser" drained quickly.

Other flood-damaged areas were also considered during rescue operations in those days. On March 22, work began to fill the heavily affected Wehrpromenade in Hastedt with slag and natural stones. To prevent further progression and expansion of the breach at the Werder Bridge, a 300-meter-long sheet pile wall was driven across the remaining Hastedter Bulten starting March 23. For this, 16 previously undamaged garden plots had to be sacrificed. Additionally, starting March 23, a Bundeswehr pontoon ferry transported machinery and filling material to the Oberweser Sailing Club. Initially, a small dam had to be pushed over a tidal channel to the Werraweg before actual dike construction could begin with the sinking of tetrapods. Work started on both sides of the breach to better control the current. The gaps were filled with hydraulic and slag stones and the resulting elevations were sealed with a mineral mixture. By March 24, the new dike had already grown to a length of 20 meters. To relieve the "New Weser" in the construction area from excessive water pressure, the weir was set to its lowest possible position to allow additional water to flow off via the "Old Weser." In addition to the previous filling material, employees of the Water Management Office supplemented the construction site starting March 26 with approximately 1,000 three-meter-long special nylon sandbags maneuvered from a pontoon by cable. These were intended to help reduce the water's flow speed, as otherwise, the filling material of the new dike could be washed away. However, the bags were partially pushed away by the current, leading to a renewed focus on stones and tetrapods. On March 28 and 29, unexpected delays occurred in closing the dike. The pontoon's cable broke multiple times, and Hans-Dieter Bücken, head of the Bremen Water Management Office, stated that approximately 5,000 more special sandbags would likely be needed for the remaining 40 meters. The current of the "New Weser" remained very strong, and the water continued to erode the Hastedter Bulten with a slightly altered impact direction. Individual plots were still being destroyed during these days. Following the actual flood disaster, the Weser breach still caused injuries. A construction worker had to be treated in the hospital after his leg got caught between a freight cart and a tool rod on March 29. A major setback occurred at the breach site on April 4, when the current tore a 30-meter-wide hole in the nearly completed dike around 6:30 PM. Over 30,000 tons of natural stones had already been used, but the dike gave way at its weakest point, where no stones had yet been sunk due to transport reasons. In light of this development, Hans-Dieter Bücken urgently called for the construction of the originally planned pontoon bridge on April 5, as more material was needed and the ferry was not efficient enough. The conditions for bridge construction were now significantly better due to the changed current conditions compared to two weeks earlier. Consequently, engineers began building the bridge on the evening of April 6, completing it by noon on April 7. The bridge consisted of 100 hollow bodies and could support a weight of 50 tons. After completion, it was used continuously by trucks. In addition to filling the dike breach, cutter dredgers flushed sand from the Middle Weser in front of the newly emerging dam as a flanking measure. Starting April 8, approximately 20 tetrapods were to be launched daily. It was also estimated that several thousand tons of stones and fill material would still be needed. By the night of April 9, the dike breach was finally closed. In the following weeks, the area was continuously reinforced and sealed with a mineral mixture. The costs for this spatially limited measure amounted to 3.2 million Deutsche Marks. A total of 36,000 tons of fill stones, 3,000 tons of mineral mixture, 635 tetrapods, and over 4,000 sandbags were used. During tidal high water, which affects the Lower Weser up to the Weser weir, the "New Weser" still periodically turned into a river within the dike during the summer, as the incoming tide pushed into the erosion channel through the breach at the Werder Bridge. This situation remained unchanged throughout the summer. Initially, water construction experts had to address more pressing issues. For residents in the Werraweg area, a provisional path was built on the dike, and on April 9, Senior Building Officer Winfried Reiner from the Water and Shipping Office announced that the steep bank at Jakobsberg in Hastedt would be set back. It had been driven too far into the Weser after World War II. Starting in mid-April, engineers were to focus primarily on repairing the still defective weir structure. On April 9, Hans Dieter Rissland, head of the Hemelingen local office, demanded that the Hastedt promenade and green corridor below the weir be completely restored, as the industrialized district already had few recreational areas. In that area, a 40-meter-wide section had been washed away. Rissland accused federal and state authorities of indifference regarding the protection of green spaces. Meanwhile, several dredging ships on the Lower and Middle Weser cleared the river of numerous sandbanks and shallows that had formed due to sedimentation during the flood. At noon on April 14, ships with a draft of up to 2.20 meters were again allowed to navigate the Middle Weser, albeit with time restrictions: lock operations for upstream travel were only permitted two hours before and after tidal high water. Starting April 14, 600 tons of earth were moved to replace the broken dike breach path at the west end of the Werdersee with a provisional sand dam. The embankment was to be completed by Easter (April 19) to provide a temporary connection for pedestrians and cyclists. If the lake's water level rose again, the path connection was to be maintained via a pontoon bridge. Local politicians from Neustadt demanded that the Werdersee be temporarily dammed again to revive its recreational value and limit ecological damage. However, the lakebed would first need to be cleaned of debris. In May, the Bremen Dike Association on the left bank of the Weser, together with the Water Management Office, began repairing damage to the Habenhausen Winter Dike over a length of one kilometer. This included straightening the highly endangered dike bend at the foot of the Werder Bridge. The repaired dike section was one kilometer long. For these measures, 50,000 cubic meters of clay soil had to be moved, and 60,000 square meters of slope and foreland areas were reseeded. The Werdersee feeder at the foot of the dike was filled with 75,000 cubic meters of sand. Dietrich Harborth, spokesperson for the Building Senator, predicted at a Neustadt local council meeting on May 6 that the Werdersee would likely not be usable as a sports and recreational area by the public until 1983 at the earliest. He explained that the lake was completely silted up and might have to be manually shoveled out. Using machines to remove the sand would break the insulating clay soil layer. When news of another potential flood reached Bremen, the recently completed dike above the weir was hastily raised from five to six meters starting June 4, at a cost of 80,000 Deutsche Marks and using several thousand cubic meters of clay soil. The flood passed without incident, allowing work to focus on the western end of the disaster area. Starting June 11, plans from mid-April were implemented, and the Werdersee was dredged and cleaned—despite the sensitive clay soil—with heavy machinery. The silt removed was used to partially fill the erosion edges at the Hastedter Bulten. On July 2, Hans-Dieter Bücken informed the Obervieland local council about the progress of the plans. The work on the Habenhausen Winter Dike, which began in May, was nearing completion, with the slope flattened and the crown path widened. Repairs were expected to be finished by the end of August. Bücken noted that filling the Werdersee feeder was necessary because it ran too close to the dike foot and could soften it during high water. The summer dikes were also to be closed and supplemented. To better protect the riverbank, an additional clay wall was planned. SPD local politician Egon Hartwig expressed the view that the landscape altered by the "New Weser" could later be used as a recreational area. On August 10, the Building Deputation's awarding committee approved five construction and planning measures in the flood-damaged floodplain area. Among other things, the Wehrstraße was to be rebuilt for 670,000 Deutsche Marks, following its former course but at a higher elevation. The dam received three water passages. More importantly, the decision was made to close the backflow breach in the Hastedter Bulten. It was feared that otherwise, winter storm surges could again flood the meadows and remaining gardens. The gaping hole was to be sealed with a new six-meter-high dike, on which a two-meter-wide asphalt foot and bike path would be built. The cost was estimated at 2.5 million Deutsche Marks. The cost of restoring the revetment on the south bank of the lake over a length of one and a half kilometers was estimated at one million Deutsche Marks. On September 1, this construction site at the Werder Bridge was established. Initially, 25,000 tons of sand from the "New Weser" were piled up into a dam; the same amount was supplied by dredging below the Stephanibrücke. The sand core, the clay soil cover layer, and the dike crown were secured with a 60-centimeter-thick stone layer. The angle of the dike slope allowed for water overflow in an emergency. To reinforce and secure the new dike, a steel sheet pile wall was driven parallel to the Weser, connecting to the one from spring. It later disappeared into the revetment and was no longer visible. To maintain a connection between the "New Weser" and the river and thus ensure water exchange, workers installed a pipe with a gate through the dam. A flap at the Weser end of the pipe closed automatically under the pressure of incoming tide water, preventing a rise in water levels in the "New Weser." On September 17, the breach was closed by bulldozers at 11:05 AM—186 days after its formation. The "New Weser," now re-diked on both sides, had thus become a lake. By the end of the day, the dike was raised to a height of three meters. A total of 35,000 cubic meters of sand, 10,000 tons of fill stones, and an additional 10,000 cubic meters of clay soil were needed for this dike closure. By the end of October, repair and overhaul work on the Weser weir was also completed. The costs for restoring flood protection burdened Bremen with nine million Deutsche Marks in 1981 and the federal government with 13 million Deutsche Marks.

As early as March 16, just one day after the dike breach, Bremen's mayor Hans Koschnick reminded that the affected allotment garden areas were known to have been designated as overflow areas and that the city could therefore not be legally held liable for compensation payments. However, he promised a sympathetic review of financial aid by the Senate, as the deficit of allotment gardens should not be increased. To also protect the city from demands for compensation, Building Senator Bernd Meyer critically noted on the same day: Johann Dreyer, chairman of the Bremen State Association of Garden Friends, then stated that the affected parties could not and would not bear the water damage alone. Despite the state's financial difficulties, the Senate must help the allotment gardeners—especially since the flooded area also served tens of thousands of Bremen residents as a recreational area. He emphasized that the damages were not insured but also admitted that every allotment gardener was aware of the risk of owning a hut in the designated overflow area. His association called for a fundraising campaign on March 18, as neither the association nor the affected individuals could even come close to covering the damages. The chairman of the opposition FDP parliamentary group, Horst-Jürgen Lahmann, also pointed out the following day that the allotment gardeners were aware of the risks of their location and therefore could not expect compensation from the state or city budget. He suggested a tax deferral as an alternative. Finance Senator Moritz Thape followed up on this idea on March 20, when he, with the approval of Federal Finance Minister Hans Matthöfer, decided on a regulation for tax relief for citizens affected by the flood. Among other things, tax debts could now be deferred upon request, advance payments on income, corporate, and trade taxes adjusted, and enforcement actions suspended. Also, on March 19, the self-help efforts of the allotment gardeners intensified. The Federal Association of German Garden Friends called on its ten state associations to organize fundraising campaigns, and independently, the Hamburg State Association of Garden Friends pledged its support and assistance. Additionally, the SPD local association in Hastedt announced plans to conduct a fundraising campaign among the population and businesspeople. On March 22, the Bremen Allotment Garden Association Werder decided at a general meeting that each member should donate 15 Deutsche Marks. The board intended to top up the total amount from the association's funds to 7,500 Deutsche Marks. The association also reserved five newly created plots for the flood victims. At the same time, the SPD parliamentary group made its own assessment of the situation on-site in the flood area. Parliamentary group chairman Klaus Wedemeier pointed out that the Weser was a federal waterway. Therefore, the regulation of damages could "not essentially be a Bremen matter." On March 23, Building Senator Meyer offered the affected parties quick and unbureaucratic help from the state government. From now on, 100 new plots could be created at Park Wolfskuhle in the Kattenturm district, for which the Senate provided 1.2 million Deutsche Marks. By this time, around 10,000 Deutsche Marks had already been deposited into the allotment gardeners' donation account. A large automobile plant had sent a check for 1,000 Deutsche Marks and also offered "quick and unconventional help." Another company provided the allotment gardeners with free fertilizers and peat products for a fresh start. Following urgent motions, the board of the Bremen State Association of Garden Friends received approval on March 28 at a general meeting in the Niederdeutsches Theater from the 276 delegates to allocate 100,000 Deutsche Marks from the association's assets. Additionally, a solidarity levy of ten Deutsche Marks per member was decided for the Hastedter Bulten association. By this time, 307,000 Deutsche Marks in donations had been collected. The following day, on March 29, the beneficiaries of the Hastedter Bulten allotment gardens held an extraordinary meeting with 500 members and relatives in the community hall on Drakenburger Straße. They called on the Senate not only to provide them with the replacement areas at Wolfskuhle but also to offer financial assistance. Furthermore, the authorities should fully restore the allotment garden area "as soon as the water has receded." In a letter to Johann Dreyer on May 5, Meyer announced that a perspective for joint action had been found, which should also be perceived as fair by the flood-affected allotment gardeners: "The clarification of the legal situation revealed that Bremen must provide appropriate compensation for the plots taken on the sheet pile wall route." Although there was no legal basis for compensation for private individuals affected by flood damage, the Senate had agreed to help the affected allotment gardeners—those who wanted to continue—financially and through services from the authorities. There should be no distinction between creating a new garden and taking over an existing free garden. "Furthermore, I will advocate for a decision to be made shortly that allows for arbor loans of up to 7,000 Marks in these cases," Meyer continued. On the same day, recipient Dreyer estimated the damage at 1.2 million Deutsche Marks. He stated that the allotment gardeners themselves wanted to raise 300,000 from solidarity donations, and 30,000 Deutsche Marks had so far been donated by outsiders. The following day, on May 6, he increased his damage estimate to 1.5 million Deutsche Marks and stated that no politician had yet promised concrete help—although this contradicted the city's offers of assistance. However, Ludwig Meyer, chairman of the most severely affected Hastedter Bulten allotment garden association, expressed similar sentiments on the same day. He found it outrageous that Bremen politicians had not yet made any proposals to alleviate the hardship almost two months after the flood. However, the allotment gardeners were pleased with the spontaneous willingness to help shown by the population and associations from across the country. By the end of the first week of May, 65,000 Deutsche Marks in donations had already been collected. Additionally, various garden associations from the Hanseatic city provided over 17,000 Deutsche Marks, and the Bremen State Association of Garden Friends contributed 300,000. Its chairman Dreyer emphasized that the members felt abandoned. He rejected the argument that the allotment gardeners had always known how vulnerable their settlement area was. After a visit by the CDU parliamentary group to Obervieland, its chairman, opposition leader, and CDU state chairman Bernd Neumann, called on May 7 for unbureaucratic help for all allotment gardeners who had lost their plots in the Hastedter Bulten. He stated that they had informed themselves about the flood damages, which by now had to be estimated at between 40 and 50 million Deutsche Marks. Almost verbatim, SPD building deputies and members of the board of the Bremen State Association of Garden Friends reaffirmed their willingness to help the affected parties quickly and unbureaucratically after a joint discussion on the same day. At the same time, the Social Democratic deputies appealed to the allotment gardeners to make greater use of the replacement garden offer at Wolfskuhle. After all, arbor loans of up to 7,000 Deutsche Marks would be approved regardless of income. The operating company of the Stadthalle organized a benefit concert on May 13 as part of the ongoing relief efforts—officially called a "Colorful Evening"—in favor of the affected parties. All artists and catering businesses waived their fees or revenues. They expected 5,000 spectators in the Stadthalle and a corresponding revenue of about 100,000 Deutsche Marks. The nearly four-hour event under the motto "Bremen Helps Bremen" was moderated by Jo Hannes Müller and Manfred Ebel. Despite numerous media announcements and the lineup of well-known artists, the "Colorful Evening" met with very little interest. Only about 1,000 Bremen residents wanted to attend—it was even necessary to bring in nearly 300 Bundeswehr soldiers as "gap fillers" in the largely empty hall. The proceeds ultimately amounted to only 15,000 Deutsche Marks. On June 11, Building Consultant Götz Neuber cited a report already presented to the parliament during a public meeting of the Obervieland local council regarding damage regulation, stating that no culpable behavior by public authorities was evident. Therefore, the state could not cover direct flood damages and losses. The Senate could only pay compensation to those whose property was affected by flood control measures (farmers whose land was used for emergency access roads/allotment gardeners whose plots were used for driving sheet piles in front of the bridge pier foundation). Within this "framework of what is legally permissible," the senatorial offices were striving to help the allotment gardeners and compensate for the damage caused. Economic Senator Karl Willms stated that he wanted to examine, in discussions with the Chamber of Agriculture, to what extent farmers could be compensated for yield losses. Subsequently, on June 23, a controversial debate took place in the parliament regarding a major inquiry by the CDU parliamentary group. Building Senator Bernd Meyer emphasized that only areas were flooded that "by their natural function and under applicable law are intended to serve as flood discharge." This had also been considered when approving allotment garden huts on the Hastedter Bulten. Bremen could therefore hardly provide financial aid for the privately affected. However, he reiterated the plan to offer replacement allotment gardens in the Wolfskuhle area, grant arbor loans to the plot holders, enable tax relief, and provide unbureaucratic individual assistance. Peter Willers of the Bremen Green List criticized the confusion of responsibilities between the federal government and the states of Bremen and Lower Saxony. He attributed the flood significantly to human intervention in nature—such as the canalization of the Weser—and therefore argued that the allotment gardeners had a legal claim to compensation. In the summer, the allotment gardeners received several large donations. On June 26, Horst Reich, as the first chairman of the Arsten Leisure Community, presented Johann Dreyer with a check for 3,500 Deutsche Marks on the occasion of the association's tenth anniversary, collected by its 116 members. By this day, the donations received had totaled 220,000 Deutsche Marks. Wolfgang Schreck, head of the Daimler-Benz plant in Sebaldsbrück, handed Dreyer a check for 26,000 Deutsche Marks on July 22. About a year after the Weser breach, 570,000 Deutsche Marks had been donated by Bremen residents for the allotment gardeners. On August 20, several soldiers from the Heavy Engineer Battalion 11 from Dörverden visited the Weserwehr Allotment Garden Association. Its plots on the so-called "Weir Island" were completely surrounded by water during the flood but were not flooded due to their elevated location. Nevertheless, the association members were particularly dependent on the pontoon bridge and wanted to express their gratitude for the assistance provided with this meeting. The local council and local office of Obervieland supported this initiative "because the deployment of the Bundeswehr soldiers is not taken for granted, but a committed thank you should be expressed."

In order to make the largely devastated harbor of the Oberweser Sailing Club e. V. directly at the Weser bend usable again, the club chairman Helmut Steinmetz estimated a sum of one million Deutsche Marks on March 20. Only the boathouse and the winter storage halls remained undamaged. In the emergency, the camaraderie of the athletes came into play, and they were taken in as guest moorers by neighboring clubs. The Weser Sailing Club e. V., located directly west of the Weser Stadium, was somewhat less severely affected. By the end of April, 15 berths for larger dinghies, amounting to a quarter of the capacity, had become silted up and unusable after silt from the upstream floodplain had deposited behind the club's sheet pile wall. However, the club was prohibited from dredging its own harbor bed and dumping the sand into the Weser, chairman Helmut Barenborg stated at the end of April. Therefore, the Waterways and Shipping Office would have to address the problem using dredgers and barges. However, this request was rejected after just a few days. In a letter, the authority declined the removal of the sand, citing the small quantity. At the same time, it was pointed out that the club's application to flush the silt into the Weser at its own expense would be approved. Threatened in its financial existence, the Weser Sailing Club e. V. then turned to Sports Senator Henning Scherf for help. At the public meeting of the Obervieland district advisory council on June 11, Scherf promised to organize aid for the Oberweser Sailing Club, and indeed, on July 2, Hans-Dieter Bücken informed the advisory council that as part of the dike renovations, the bank revetment at the club would also be restored. A point of contention on its grounds was the construction of the harbor boundary. Before the flood, there had been a sheet pile wall as a barrier to the Weser. After the dike closure in early April, plans were made to limit the newly created harbor with a stone embankment. However, this would have significantly narrowed the harbor basin. No one was willing to bear the additional costs of 350,000 Deutsche Marks for the construction of a new sheet pile wall. After lengthy negotiations, the Senate ultimately decided to partially finance the solution favored by the club. Although the Oberweser Sailing Club still had to take on 100,000 Deutsche Marks in debt and cover the cost of building the 95-meter-long landing bridge opposite the sheet pile wall itself, it was thus saved. This was made possible not least thanks to donations amounting to 50,000 Deutsche Marks – including from SC Niedersachsen Werder and WV Woltmershausen. On May 9, 1982, the new harbor was inaugurated in the presence of numerous local politicians.

The Weser breakthrough in 1981, during which the Weser sought a new bed, went down in Bremen's city annals as one of the most severe floods, even though "only" allotments were affected. Although it significantly altered the landscape, it reflects only part of the threat at the time, as during those days, a storm surge over the Lower Weser reached the Hanseatic city simultaneously with the high water of the Upper and Middle Weser. An area of 70 hectares was flooded as a result of the Weser breakthrough, destroying 44 hectares of agricultural land, between 127 and 150 allotment houses on the eastern Stadtwerder were destroyed, causing damages amounting to approximately 56 million Deutsche Marks, and more than 1.5 million cubic meters of soil and sediments were washed into the Weser. Large parts of the affected area were subsequently covered by a layer of silt, mud, and sand up to one meter thick, contaminated with heavy metal deposits. Most of the swept-away allotments were not rebuilt. Their location—the breakthrough of the "New Weser" back into the river—is now dominated by wild growth. Particularly from a bird's-eye view, the course of the flood can still be well traced. The allotment area of Hastedter Bulten has been divided as a result. The water flow at the threshold from the Middle to the Lower Weser increased massively due to the Weser breakthrough and the forcibly created additional drainage possibility. For example, on March 20, only about 300 m³ per second flowed over the weir itself, while 1000 m³ per second sought the path of the "New Weser." As a result, the water level of the Middle Weser upstream to Langwedel dropped dramatically in some places. There were short-term fears that it could drop to 60 to 80 centimeters. In combination with the sandbanks created by the flood, this was one of the main reasons for the nearly one-month closure of the corresponding Weser section to inland navigation.

As early as 1981, the Senate commissioned the Franzius Institute for Hydraulic Engineering and Coastal Engineering at the University of Hanover to conduct hydraulic model tests on future flood diversion possibilities in the area of the Weser breakthrough. The large-scale model experiment began at the end of October and cost around 500,000 Deutsche Marks, 40 percent of which was covered by the federal government and 60 percent by the state of Bremen. Scientists from the University of Hanover and the Technical University of Braunschweig also dealt with this topic from mid-June. A commission of inquiry was established, which, however, merely concluded that the dike breaches resulted from a chain of unfortunate circumstances. On the one hand, the weir should have been repaired much earlier, and on the other hand, the flood protection measures taken in the 1950s—namely the construction of the flood channel—had failed. On April 21, 1983, apart from the previous repair and security work, work began to partially refill the deeply entrenched bed of the "New Weser" east of the Werder Bridge. Over the next few months, trucks transported around 125,000 cubic meters of earth to the area. This was excavation material from the Krimpelsee, located in the districts of Habenhausen and Kattenturm in Obervieland. This made it possible to fill about two-thirds of the erosion channel. The future of the "New Weser" remained unclear for several years. While the Bremen Water Management Office, for example, initially wanted to wait for the results of the Franzius Institute's report at the end of May 1983, conservation experts assumed that the habitat, which was interesting for flora and fauna, could be preserved regardless of flood protection strategies. The farmers affected by the Weser breakthrough, on the other hand, advocated refilling the "New Weser" to regain the lost arable land. Hermann Cordes, a professor of vegetation science and nature conservation at the University of Bremen, explained that remarkable plant species had established themselves relatively quickly on the edge of the water. These were mainly species that were once part of the typical flora of large glacial valleys. From an ornithological perspective, the shallow water zones on the Hastedter Bulten were also interesting, as they attracted numerous feeding guests, such as herons and sandpipers. Cordes stated that the area did not necessarily have to be designated as a nature reserve. It was also conceivable to preserve it as a remarkable landscape formation and recreational area without special protection status. Hans-Dieter Bücken, head of the Water Management Office, also said it was highly unlikely that the "New Weser" would have to be removed for flood protection reasons. However, Holger Schmidt, spokesman for the Obervieland local advisory board, pointed out that private property had been affected by the "New Weser." Therefore, the farmers' desire to restore the original state was only too understandable. Furthermore, preserving the "New Weser" and constructing a nature conservation-friendly feeder system would be difficult to achieve together. During the Weser breakthrough in 1981, the Werdersee had proven almost ineffective in its intended protective function: while it protected the Neustadt from storm surges, it failed to secure Habenhausen from inland flooding of the Middle Weser. This fact, the already partially completed remodeling of the dikes, the "New Weser," still perceived as a foreign body, and the question of how to deal with it ultimately led to the decision to redesign the area on a large scale. The holistic and nature-oriented concept aimed to prevent a similar catastrophe and ensure a more controlled flow of potential floods. The most visible measure was the extension of the still-dry Werdersee by 1.07 kilometers eastward beyond the Werder Bridge to protect the structure from uncontrolled undercutting and provide a faster catchment area for incoming inland floods. Deepening the lake near the bridge was also intended to keep flowing water away from the foundations. The eastern basin of the overflow area was raised over a large area to slow the flow velocity of overflowing Weser water. The Wehrstraße was restored to its old course and now passes the Werdersee directly at its eastern end. Here, the new feeder also flows into the lake, branching off from the left bank of the Weser above the Oberweser Sailing Club and ensuring the lake's supply of fresh water and circulation over 738 meters. The slightly winding canal features artificial rapids, was built far from any winter dike, is equipped with gates at two summer dike crossings, and was designed in a very nature-oriented manner as a compensatory measure for construction work in the port area. A significant intervention in the redesign was also the removal of the land bridge at the western end of the Werdersee, which separated it from the Kleine Weser. Since then, the Deichschartweg has crossed a bridge for pedestrians and cyclists, already demanded in 1981, under which the two bodies of water have been fully connected. From the Wehrstraße to the mouth of the Weser in the city center at the Bürgermeister-Smidt-Brücke, they now form a 5.7-kilometer-long continuous left-flowing watercourse. This allows potential floods from the Middle Weser to flow unimpeded into the Lower Weser. Finally, in 1987, the Werdersee was reflooded and has since served as one of the city's largest and most frequented recreational areas. The floodwaters of March 1981 eroded marsh soil and sand layers, relocated them, and created a patchwork of different soil types, offering diverse niches for plants with varying requirements. As Hermann Cordes had already predicted in 1983, this provided conservationists with the opportunity to preserve a small area of dynamic river activity within the city. The lake remaining in the floodplain was ecologically redesigned. Individual shore areas were flattened, and a buffer zone was established around the reservoir to prevent excessive eutrophication from surrounding agricultural land. Finally, on December 28, 1988, the lake and surrounding green spaces were designated as the 34.8-hectare "New Weser" nature reserve. The area is left to natural vegetation development, uninfluenced by humans and grazing livestock, and is scientifically monitored. Today, it hosts a diverse natural landscape with numerous habitats, such as reed beds, grasslands, tall herbaceous vegetation, flood meadows, still waters, near-natural floodplain shrubs, and trees, and is designated as a European bird area. As such, it is of great importance for both migratory and breeding birds. Numerous duck species and gray herons live there, and river terns nest on an artificial pontoon. The water body is fed by bank filtrate from the Weser and drains through discharge pipes into the Lower Weser. In summer, there is no stable temperature stratification. As early as June 11, 1981, Senior Building Officer Winfried Reiner from the Waterways and Shipping Office admitted at a public meeting of the Obervieland local advisory board that the Weser weir no longer met the DIN standards of the time. For new constructions, safety standards valid after 1981 required three independently controllable flow openings so that, in the event of damage to one weir, most of the floodwater could still flow through the other two. One of the most practical solutions for the new regulation of flood discharge in Habenhausen was therefore a modernization or new construction—in any case, an increase in the weir's capacity. Ultimately, a new Weser weir was built 180 meters downstream from the old location starting in 1989, with costs—together with the new lock system—amounting to approximately 287.5 million. It was put into operation on June 10, 1993. The new concept for inland flooding is designed for a Weser discharge of up to 4,200 cubic meters per second—this value corresponds to the flood event of February and March 1881 and has a recurrence interval of 600 years. Of this, 3,400 m³ is to flow through the weir, and the remaining 800 m³ through the so-called "flood discharge channel," which consists of the Werdersee feeder, Werdersee, and Kleine Weser.

The critical remarks following the Weser breakthrough of 1981 were essentially aimed at the flood control concept in place at the time—which many commentators retrospectively deemed inadequate—and at the behavior of political decision-makers. As early as March 16, Johann Dreyer, chairman of the Bremen State Association of Garden Friends, spoke out. He criticized that at the western end of the Werdersee, the dike path had been laid over a dam. Dreyer preferred a bridge with a small weir instead of just the existing narrow passage. However, the official admitted that he could only assess this technical problem as a layman. Wilhelm Mahrtens, who was the department head of the Northwest Waterways and Shipping Directorate and responsible for the Jade-Weser area, stated on March 21 that the "delayed" breach of the boat harbor dike was not due to water pressure from the Middle Weser but rather to backward erosion in the floodplain. This was mainly possible because loose farmland in the area of the undermined Wehrstraße had been converted into relatively solid pastures, which, according to him, should never have happened. The plowed soil had offered the water significantly better opportunities to dig deep. Furthermore, the flood was by no means a result of the failure of one of the weir structures. Mahrtens instead considered the overflow basins between Werraweg and Bullenwerder to be a serious planning error. Without them, the first flood wave would have taken its pre-programmed path through the flood channel to the Werdersee. Even the former director of river construction, Ludwig Plate, had criticized the establishment of allotment garden areas in the flood-prone region, Mahrtens said. Archive documents show that as early as 1928, officials had demanded that no plots be built in the water drainage area. On March 23, Building Senator Bernd Meyer responded with the words: "There are far more important things to discuss now than questions of blame." At the extraordinary general meeting of the Hastedter Bulten Allotment Garden Association on March 29, several participants expressed disappointment and anger at the absence of the dike captain at the beginning of the events. The association's chairman, Ludwig Meyer, criticized the "human incompetence" and the inability to put the defective weir structure back into operation in time. As early as January, the authorities should have ensured a regulated outflow of the Upper Weser through the Werdersee channel as a compensatory measure. "Hanoverian merchant stinginess" had also prevented the dike path from being designed as a bridge. They had saved in the wrong place, as the summer dike at the Werder Bridge could only have broken and caused the violent backflow into the Weser because the water, which had already flowed further in the intended flood channel, was dammed back by the reinforced dike dam. Meyer concluded: "The Werdersee has failed its first stress test." Anyone blaming the allotment gardeners must also hold accountable those who had issued building permits for the Hastedter Bulten. Presumably encouraged by Meyer in his opinion, Johann Dreyer brought up the topic again on May 6 at a meeting of the Neustadt local council. At the public meeting of the Obervieland local council on June 11, Meyer also renewed his criticism: the dike dam that additionally dammed up the floodwater and the winter dike bend at the Werder Bridge were the results of "catastrophic planning errors." It was possible that a merely makeshift floodwater management system had been designed out of frugality. During the meeting, members of the Fresenbulten Allotment Garden Association also expressed concerns about being affected by future floods. The safety of their gardens was already at risk during the next summer storm surge. Due to the not even two-year-old commissioning of the barrages at Lesum, Hunte, and Ochtum, the Weser water could rise significantly higher than before and reach the garden sheds unimpeded through the (at the time of the meeting still not closed) damaged area at the Werder Bridge. However, Senior Building Officer Winfried Reiner from the Waterways and Shipping Office gave them little hope for a quick remedy. Restoring a dike that was secure against overflow during both Middle Weser floods and storm surges from the opposite direction would cost four million Deutsche Marks. This expenditure could only be justified once model tests had provided corresponding results. Furthermore, Reiner countered criticism of an allegedly delayed repair of the Weser weir. After the defect in November 1980, repairs had been started immediately but could only continue until Christmas, as winter and the high water level had made any further work on the weir impossible for safety reasons. He further speculated that the Bulten with the allotment garden areas would likely have been flooded even with a fully intact weir during the March flood.

This page is a verified version Accuracy-checked The 1775 Pest flood devastated Pest, Buda, and Vác on February 15, during which a total of 611 residential houses were destroyed. After the flood, the large embankment in Vác was constructed, between today's Nyugati Square and Lehel Square, the Soroksár dam, which extended from Boráros Square to Haller Street, as well as the so-called ice dam along today's Közraktár Street up to Fővám Square.
This page is a verified version Accuracy-checked The 1821 flood in Makó was caused by the Maros river overflowing its banks in Makó and its surroundings.

Makó was located directly next to the river before the regulation of the Maros. From the 1800s, the idea of creating a new riverbed further away from the town was continuously raised; the most dangerous section was considered to be the winding bends between the Makó timber market and Kiszombor. In 1814, surveyor József Vertics prepared a regulation plan, but it was thwarted by the resistance of Károly Oexel, the landowner of Kiszombor, who refused to allow cuts through his lands. In 1815, royal navigation engineer Fábián Dániel Őry, sent to the site, proposed cutting through three bends near Makó. In 1816, a committee of experts led by royal commissioner Miklós Vay navigated the Maros. As a result of the inspection, the council of governors ordered the commencement of river regulation works in November of that year, but the digging of the new riverbed was halted due to a lack of financial resources. In 1820, Mihály Buday prepared a new regulation plan, but the town again did not receive financial support for its implementation. Teknyőkaparó, a well-known soothsayer and shaman in the Makó area, repeatedly predicted impending destruction. He foretold things like: "You will see, soon the flood will come again. It will destroy people, animals, and trees." "Such a great flood will come upon us that in Dry Street, Barna the fisherman will fish for catfish."

Károly Oexel's stubbornness and the treasury's stinginess eventually backfired: in 1821, the greatest flood of all time swept over Makó and the surrounding settlements. In the two weeks leading up to the flood, continuous efforts were made on bank protection works; nevertheless, on July 2, 1821, the river flooded Apátfalva and Csanád, then broke through towards the city at the Csipkés and Szugoly forests. At the same time, the embankment at Kakás broke; only a small portion of the surging flood could be collected by the Mikócsai and Margitai streams. Once they were filled, the flood washed away the Dália and Margitai bridges, inundated Belsőnyomás and the Jángor meadow. Although the above-mentioned outer areas were submerged, on this day, Makó's inner area was not yet under water. The river continued to rise, and at dawn on July 3, it broke through the Szentlőrinc embankment section. First, it flooded the vineyards, and within a few hours, the city itself. By 9 a.m., almost the entire city was underwater. After this, the city was surrounded by the Maros River for nearly a week; the hardships of the locals, stranded far from their lands, were alleviated by aid packages and donations sent by the residents of Hódmezővásárhely and Szeged, delivered to Makó by boats. The damage in the city and vineyards exceeded 270,000 forints. One-third of the residential houses were damaged or collapsed; 10,600 quintals of salt dissolved in the salt warehouses, exceeding half a year's salt needs for the area belonging to the Makó salt house district.

As a result of the 1821 flood, 4-5 million grapevines were cut down. Their place was taken by vegetable gardens, where large-scale onion cultivation began. Thus, after the flood, the size of the vineyards shrank to a fraction, but the world-famous and popular Makó red onion, the city's most famous landmark, was created. The flood provided an opportunity to organize the streets and squares of Makó: at the instruction of László Kőszeghy, the bishop of Csanád, Antal Giba, a surveyor and the designer of the town hall, prepared a partial layout plan for the area around the Reformed Old Church after the water receded, and based on the plans of Ferenc Fejérváry, the streets of the Jewish quarter were straightened, and the plots were proportionally measured.

This page is a verified version Accuracy-checked The flood of 1838 was the most devastating natural disaster in the history of Esztergom, with seventy percent of the royal city's buildings collapsing.

In the upper reaches of the Danube, a massive amount of snow fell, and the river froze at Visegrád as early as December 1837. Following the spring thaw, the Danube could not recede. According to the contemporary account of József Helischer, a city councilor, by March 5, the lower-lying streets of the city were already flooded. On March 6, despite defensive efforts, the icy flood broke through the dikes, and by the 8th, everything in the downtown area, except for the vicinity of the Franciscan church, was submerged. The water level rose until March 13, "exceeding that of 1809 by five feet, flooding the entire inner city." "The Captain's Office promptly announced house by house and also proclaimed with drumbeats that everyone should move their belongings and livestock to safe places, transport their fodder to the road near the upper hemp fields, and support their houses exposed to flooding with props. Millers, fishermen, and timber merchants were instructed to keep their barges, boats, and rafts ready for use in case of need." The flood lasted until March 14, a total of nine days. Some residents left the city, fleeing to higher areas such as Szenttamás, Szentgyörgymező, and cellars, press houses, or cemeteries in the surrounding hills. The Franciscan monastery provided shelter and care for 760 people. However, on March 12, water also entered the friars' church and monastery, forcing everyone to leave the significantly damaged building. The crypt remained underwater for days, the walls weakened, and the church, which had become life-threatening, could only be restored with the support of benefactors in 1857 to the extent that it could be visited by the faithful without danger.

As the danger slowly increased, there were no human or cattle casualties. Out of the city's 853 houses, 614 completely collapsed, and only 150 remained somewhat intact. The collapse of the houses was exacerbated by the fact that residents moved their furniture to the attics, which the walls could no longer support. During this time, the relief distribution center of the city of Esztergom was set up in the economic office of the cathedral chapter. Today, the building houses the Danube Museum.

After the flood receded, the damage was estimated at one and a half million forints. The government sent Pethőfalvi Uzovich János, the deputy lord lieutenant, who began the restoration work on the 16th. During the reconstruction, schools and barracks were given priority. The House of the Elderly, which had been operating on the main road for 120 years, also became unusable, and the institution had to leave its old location. János Packh, who was overseeing the construction of the Basilica, prepared free plans for the construction of a new hospital at the corner of Csillag Street and Hosszú Row, which opened its doors a year and a half later. A new plan was developed for the regulation of the streets, and Esztergom received a loan of one hundred thousand forints from the government for the reconstruction.
