Whole_Text.content: A great flood occurred in the Kingdom of Hungary in 1838, which particularly affected present-day Budapest.

Earlier in 1775, a flood occurred, so later dikes were built to protect especially the towns of Vác, Buda, (then independent) Óbuda, and Pest (city). In the early months of 1838, the Danube was completely covered with ice, and at that time, a lot of precipitation fell. In early March in Vienna, the ice was already floating. The first danger occurred in Vác, where despite the dike, a flood happened. This was repeated in Pest on March 13, but only part of the city was under water. Many believed that the flood could not spread. The river built a dike with ice just after the cities of Buda and Pest, but soldiers constantly fired cannons at the dike. This maneuver was unsuccessful. On the 14th, the level reached the record of 1775, and the rescue began. The residents partly took refuge in churches, which were very stable. On the contrary, the residential houses began to collapse. 50,000 people became homeless. On the 15th, the remaining dikes could no longer protect the houses, and a catastrophic flood occurred. The most notable helper was Baron Miklós Wesselényi, who saved people sitting on rooftops with a boat. (After the flood, all Hungarians added the epithet "the flood sailor" to Miklós Wesselényi. On that day, in some places, water depths of almost 3 meters were measured. In Pest, 2,281 houses were destroyed, 827 houses were damaged, and 1,146 houses remained untouched. In the opposite Buda, 204 houses were destroyed, 262 houses were damaged, and 2,023 houses remained untouched. In summary, in the Kingdom of Hungary, 10,000 houses were destroyed, and 4,000 houses were damaged. In total, 153 people died, of which 151 lived in Pest. When Franz Liszt learned about the flood, he immediately traveled to Vienna and organized 8 concerts, the proceeds of which helped the homeless. After the flood, new dikes were built, and the new houses became more stable. At that time, Újpest was founded. The next flood occurred in 1876, but the dikes protected the then-new city of Budapest (however, some damage occurred in Buda and Óbuda). During the Habsburg suppression, memorial plaques were placed about the water level at that time, but it is mentioned that the mentioned day, March 15, reminded Hungarians of the Hungarian Revolution of 1848, and not of the flood in 1838.
This page is a verified version Accuracy-checked The great spring flood of 1970 was the overflow of the swollen Maros River from its banks in Makó and its surroundings.

The year 1970 was rich in precipitation; the first-level inland water protection alert was issued on January 6, and the third-level alert on February 2. In the city's lowest area, the Honvéd district, which already struggled with social and infrastructural deficiencies, and in a significant portion of the outer agricultural fields, groundwater, rainwater, and snowmelt simultaneously caused problems. In the Lesi district, located between the Békéscsaba–Kétegyháza–Mezőhegyes–Újszeged railway line and the flood protection embankment, 21 families were evacuated as early as January. On May 12, 100 millimeters of precipitation fell within 48 hours in the Maros watershed area—this triggered an unprecedented flood wave in Transylvania, on the upper section of the river.

On May 16, 1970, a water level of 398 centimeters was measured on the Maros River near Makó; a day later, a third-degree flood alert was declared, and a municipal defense committee was formed. Water began seeping through the saturated and soaked dikes in more and more places, and near Makó, water overflowed from several channels. The water of the Sámson-Apátfalva channel was pushed back by the Maros for ten kilometers. On May 19, massive forces were mobilized in the city as the flood wave reached the Hungarian-Romanian border. The Maros peaked at 624 centimeters on May 20, 1970, at 10 p.m., while four kilometers from the city, a large group of water springs (seepage water on the protected side of the embankment) emerged with significant water flow. During the critical hours, full mobilization was ordered, and the city was defended by 56 engineers, 92 technicians, 178 water management professionals, the Makó fire department, 2,600 civilians, two military units, a Soviet military unit, an engineering battalion, as well as one law enforcement unit, a 120-member police unit, a civil defense unit, a workers' militia battalion, and a Red Cross battalion.

The Flood and Inland Water Protection Regional Committee (ÁTB), one day after the river's peak, on May 21, decided to evacuate Makó, which then had 32,000 residents, as well as Maroslele, Földeák, and Óföldeák, considering the effects of the springs, the paralyzing downpour on transportation, and the risk of the dam breaking, to avoid a potential mass disaster. In the event of a dam break, the lowest-lying parts of the city would be covered by four meters of water, and the highest point by two meters. A total of 18,000 people were evacuated from the four settlements and surrounding farms in a single night, most of whom—16,000—were relocated to Hódmezővásárhely, but Szentes and several other villages also took in refugees. The operation, carried out with great organization and exemplary discipline, is an important milestone in the technical history of flood defense. This was the largest evacuation ever in Europe. The evacuees were able to return to their homes on July 3, after the immediate danger had passed.

After the flood wave receded, the damages and the costs of evacuation were assessed on June 10, amounting to over 294 million forints. To encourage reconstruction, the government provided long-term construction loans, and the Hungarian Red Cross distributed aid to the affected for several years. The dikes of the Maros River were raised by an average of 1-1.5 meters, and their bases were widened. The flood marked a turning point: when the Maros returned to its bed, the government of the time saw it as an opportunity to develop the settlement – until then, the proximity of the Yugoslav border and the predominance of individual farming had excluded the city from regional development policies. The main square was reconstructed, and several large housing estates were established. Although delayed, industrial development also began, exclusively by establishing subsidiaries of national and county factories.

The Heinrich Flood or July Flood, also known as Black Friday of Waldeck, refers to the flood disaster that struck Northern Hesse, Southern Lower Saxony, and East Westphalia, as well as parts of today's federal states of Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, and Saxony, following severe storms on July 15 and 16, 1965. A total of 16 people died in the extreme heavy rainfall and subsequent flooding, three of them in the GDR. Damages amounted to hundreds of millions in Deutsche Mark and GDR Mark. Particularly hard hit were the catchment areas of the Twiste and Diemel rivers, the town of Bad Karlshafen located at the Diemel estuary, the catchment areas of the Lippe and Altenau rivers, where seven people died, as well as the Ilme river. The present-day districts of Göttingen, Holzminden, and Kassel were also severely affected. Significant damage occurred in the city centers of Paderborn, Lippstadt, and Kassel. In the GDR, the districts of Erfurt, Suhl, Gera, Karl-Marx-Stadt, Leipzig, Dresden, and Halle were heavily impacted.

The Heinrich flood of July 1965 occurred at a time when modern information technology and the methodology of hydrology and meteorology were in their infancy. There were no weather satellites, and the agencies responsible for water level and weather forecasting operated on a national level; international networking was only rudimentary. In particular, the runoff behavior of smaller rivers and streams during floods was completely unknown. In many places, there were no gauges on them. Sudden weather deteriorations or a sudden rise in water levels could sometimes only be detected when it was already too late to issue timely warnings to the population. Communication methods available included analog technologies such as telephone, teletype, and radio. Notices, daily newspapers, air raid sirens, and loudspeaker vehicles from the police and fire departments served as links between authorities and the population. Television and radio broadcasted only for a few hours a day in a limited capacity. Ongoing programs were often taken over by other German broadcasters and were very difficult to change or interrupt. Another recurring problem was the fact that, even in the 1960s, power supply in residential areas, both in rural and urban regions, was provided via overhead lines. If these were damaged by lightning or storms, it led to widespread, long-lasting power outages, further reducing the possibilities for remote communication. Under such conditions, the population could only be warned by loudspeaker vehicles from the police and fire departments or by officials going door to door. If power and telephone connections were interrupted and access routes were impassable, only rescue measures could be initiated.

After an unusually wet and cold spring and summer, warm air masses from the subtropics moved northward in mid-July 1965, where they encountered cold Scandinavian air masses. This resulted in the formation of a so-called cold air drop on the rear side of the incoming warm air over northern France, which caused the very moist warm air to be completely enclosed by cold air. The warm air rose over the cold air, leading to severe thunderstorms with torrential rainfall. As early as the late evening hours of July 15, severe storms with torrential rains occurred in the Einbeck area, leading to widespread flooding. Due to the situation, the disaster management authorities of the then-district of Einbeck were forced to declare a disaster alarm at 8:45 PM, three-quarters of an hour after the storm began. In the following hours, the precipitation area, interspersed with severe thunderstorms, moved further west and also caused stormy rainfall in the area of the later disaster zone. In the morning hours of July 16, severe storms began in the Stadtoldendorf/Heinade/Mackensen area, which exacerbated the flood situation in the Ilme region. The storms moved westward with increasing intensity and reached the Paderborn/Warburg area around noon. Starting at 12:00 PM, under almost complete darkness, torrential and stormy rainfall lasting about two hours began over the Paderborn plateau, the Warburg Börde, and the Waldeck tableland, in an area spatially bounded in the west by the Rothaar Mountains and in the east by the Egge Mountains and Reinhardswald. These rains slowly weakened as they moved eastward, reaching the Einbeck/Göttingen area in the evening hours. During the storm, rainfall amounts of well over 100 mm were recorded at weather stations in an area between Paderborn in the north, Brilon in the southwest, and Warburg and Hofgeismar in the east, as well as in the Kassel and Fritzlar areas, most of which fell within a two-hour period. In the area between Paderborn and Höxter in the north, and Warburg and Hofgeismar in the south, about 200 mm of rainfall was recorded between July 14 and July 17 over 72 hours, and in Dalheim, even well over 200 mm in 24 hours. Short-term maximum rainfall intensities of up to 4.5 mm/minute were recorded. Further severe storms worsened the situation again in the following days, particularly in the Kassel and Hannoversch Münden areas.

In the catchment areas of the Diemel and Twiste as well as the Lippe and Altenau, the rainfall could no longer be absorbed by the already saturated soils; similarly, the underground cave systems typical of karst landscapes were already so filled beforehand that a catastrophic runoff event occurred. Due to the surface runoff and the erupting karst springs in the area of the Paderborn plateau, as well as in the Stadtoldendorf and Heinade areas in the Holzminden district, water levels in rivers and streams reached previously unobserved heights within a very short time. The erupting karst springs on the flanks of the box valleys typical of karst landscapes and the high intensity of the rainfall caused large amounts of water to not only enter the towns from the rivers but also flow directly down the mountain slopes as flash floods. In unfavorable slope areas, numerous landslides occurred. Damming structures, such as road embankments, undersized bridges and culverts, as well as field walls and even pasture fences that trapped the abundant debris, temporarily led to even higher water levels. Due to the extreme rainfall on water-saturated soil, water levels in streams and rivers in the rainfall area rose rapidly. Depending on the size of the catchment area, the possibility of flooding, and the capacity of the riverbed, maximum water levels were reached shortly after the midday storms subsided. At the Schmittwasser, a discharge of 15.4 m³/s was recorded on July 16 at 1:57 PM, and at the Ellerbach, a discharge of 20.6 m³/s was recorded at 2:38 PM. In Paderborn, the discharge at the Pader gauge on July 16 was 47.3 m³/s, which corresponds to almost ten times the average discharge. At the Pader spring, it took until the end of August for the values to normalize. This extreme discharge led to widespread flooding in the urban area. The Altenau brought a flood wave to the Lippe, which caused flooding up to the Lippe's mouth. The flow rate at the Lippe gauges was ten times the five-year average. The Diemel gauge at its mouth in Bad Karlshafen rose by 5 meters within a few hours on the morning of July 17. In Eberschütz, which was passed by the flood peak during the night of July 16 to 17, the Diemel swelled so quickly that the town was flooded within half an hour. At the gauge on the upper course of the Diemel in Westheim near Marsberg, the flow rate on July 16 was 225 cubic meters per second (average 1954/2006: 5.26 m³/s). In Helmarshausen near Bad Karlshafen on the lower course of the Diemel, the flow rate was even 820 cubic meters per second, while the normal rate here is about 10.4 m³/s. The Diemel flood wave caused a water level in the Weser at Bad Karlshafen that exceeded the summer flood of 1956. However, the flood peak of the Weser flattened significantly on its course to the Weser weir in Bremen-Hastedt and, unlike the July flood of 1956, was no longer noticeable at the tidal gauges of the Weser below Bremen. At the gauges of the Fulda and Eder, the situation remained calm despite the extreme rainfall, as the water level of the Edersee had already been lowered a few days earlier. This allowed the partially drained reservoir to absorb and store 29 million cubic meters of water flowing in from the heavy rainfall in the upper Eder catchment area.

The starting point of many very severe damages was numerous damming structures. These included the small dams built at the many water mills of the time, as well as outdated road bridges and culverts that were not designed for such loads and were heavily damaged or destroyed. In the settlements, river cross-sections were very constricted by installations and therefore unable to accommodate the water masses coming from the upper reaches. The large amount of debris carried along, which clogged culverts and bridges, proved to be very dangerous. Particularly vulnerable were the stone arch or vaulted bridges common in the region at the time, 40 of which in the catchment area of the Alme, Altenau, and Lippe rivers alone were destroyed or so severely damaged that they had to be replaced by new constructions. Flood waves several meters high caused by dam breaches destroyed or severely damaged numerous massive bridges, interrupting regional road connections as well as power and telephone lines. High flood waves were also caused by field walls built across the valley cross-section or near the banks, which could not withstand the high water pressure over time. The collapse of the medieval monastery wall in Dalheim, the breach of a road embankment near Wrexen, the breach of the medieval city wall at the Esse culvert in Grebenstein, and the collapse of a wall damming up the floodwaters in Etteln led to flood waves several meters high, which appeared completely unexpectedly to the population and rushed down the valley. Severe damage occurred on agricultural land where floodplain meadows had been converted into arable land, as well as in areas where river straightening had been carried out as part of land improvement measures. In these areas, there was not only severe damage to the banks but also, as at the Dalbach below Oesdorf near Westheim, a return of the river course to its old riverbed. Riverbanks with only individual trees were also severely damaged. There were significant bank collapses, severe scouring, and deepening of the riverbeds of rivers and streams. In Paderborn County alone, 24 road bridges were destroyed. Above damming road embankments, large deposits of silt and gravel occurred. Gravel deposits also caused severe damage to agricultural land, where they were deposited by sheet floods and flash floods rushing down from the slopes of box valleys. These floods had a similar character, depending on the slope gradient, to those observed in alpine torrents. The German geologist Ecke von Zezschwitz, who was in the disaster area during the storm, observed a sheet flood about 1.5 km long and several hundred meters wide near Elisenhof as an eyewitness. On the flanks of box valleys, there were large landslides in many places, and in unfavorable locations, entire old forest stands slid down, such as in the forest areas near Blankenrode. In some areas, the special geological structure of the karst as well as the slope and soil conditions led to the formation of badlands. In the Minstal, located about 1.5 km southeast of Etteln between Donnerberg and Ettlerberg, a 1.5 km long and up to 5 m deep erosion channel reaching into the rock was washed out. Not only loose material but also large rock material was washed out of this channel. A cloudburst, during which more than 150 mm of rain fell in a very short time, is assumed to be the cause.

In the catchment area of the Diemel River and its tributaries, the towns of Wrexen, Grebenstein, Helmarshausen, Trendelburg, and Bad Karlshafen were particularly severely affected. A major damage hotspot was in Wrexen. After 156 mm of rainfall fell in Rhoden within a very short time and immediately flowed into the Rhodener Bach, which drains into the Diemel, the water masses accumulated in front of the bridge located in the road embankment of Federal Highway 252, which was not designed for such a flood, to such a height that the embankment was flooded. The excessively steep outer slope gave way under the water masses now flooding the embankment in a broad front, and the embankment broke over a length of 80 meters. As a result of the embankment breach, the previously dammed water masses suddenly poured into the areas below the embankment. On their way downstream, three water mills and their associated buildings were hit by a four-meter-high flood wave and severely damaged or destroyed. On the way to the Diemel, the massive road bridge along Ramser Straße in Wrexen was completely washed away. Numerous houses and businesses were severely damaged, and building debris and agricultural equipment were transported over long distances. In Wrexen, a woman lost her life during the storm. She was in a house that was hit by a mudslide. The bridge over the Diemel along Federal Highway 7 near Warburg was destroyed by the flood. This interrupted an important regional road connection between Kassel and Paderborn at the time. At the Immenhausen train station on the Kassel–Warburg railway line, hundreds of passengers of the Deutsche Bundesbahn were stranded because the line was no longer passable due to the flooding of the station in Grebenstein. In Grebenstein, the Esse, a tributary of the Diemel, carried logs from a sawmill upstream of the town to the city wall. The river, initially dammed by the driftwood consisting of long logs, then caused part of the city wall at the Esse inlet at the Hilte to collapse, after which the water suddenly poured into the city center in the form of a meter-high flood wave, causing severe damage along with the carried logs. In Helmarshausen, over 100 people were trapped by the rapidly rising water of the Diemel. They could only be rescued with the help of helicopters. During the rescue, there was one fatality. Trendelburg and Bad Karlshafen also suffered severe damage from flooding. The entire historic old town of Bad Karlshafen was flooded several meters high. On the Weser River, the water level of the 1956 flood was exceeded. Debris and animal carcasses were transported as far as Hameln.

Whole_Text.header: Catchment area of Lippe, Alme, and Altenau
Whole_Text.content: The hardest-hit area was the Lippe catchment area and its tributary, the Alme. The focus was on the Paderborn plateau with the towns of Etteln and Borchen on the Altenau (Alme). In Etteln, 200 people were trapped by rapidly rising floodwaters, and 7 residents were killed, including 4 children, after a field wall that initially held back the Altenau's water from the town gave way under the pressure of the water masses. After the wall broke, a two-meter-high flood wave suddenly poured into the village. Four people, including three children, were swept out of a residential house and drowned. Many of Etteln's residents, who were in life-threatening situations, could only be rescued from their homes by helicopters or heavy military equipment. In Schloss Neuhaus, two people lost their lives in the floods. Here, the bridge over the Alme on Federal Highway 64 was destroyed after it became clogged with debris. The Alme flood wave, as well as rainfall that could no longer be managed by the stormwater drainage system, flooded parts of downtown Paderborn, where some streets were flooded up to a meter high. Severe damage occurred in the flooded houses in the city center and in shops and businesses. Severe flood damage also occurred in Schwaney, where the entire town center was flooded, and in Lipperode. In Lippstadt, the city center was flooded up to a meter high. Numerous important buildings, including the two hospitals, were no longer accessible even to emergency services. Flooding also occurred further along the Lippe in the Hamm, Haltern am See, and Dorsten areas; however, no residential areas were affected here, as the Lippe dikes controlled by the responsible authorities withstood the floodwaters.

In the Schede Valley, severe damage occurred in Volkmarshausen, where a felt factory was flooded, and its stockpiles were washed away. Here, as in the other disaster areas, drainage ditches completely clogged with mud caused major problems.

The places Mackensen, Einbeck, and Dassel were flooded along the Ilme. The Spüligbach brought a flood wave of unprecedented height from the karst areas in Hellental and from Holzberg. A landslide at Bierberg near Dassel caused the failure of telecommunications facilities.

Whole_Text.header: River basins of Fulda and Werra
Whole_Text.content: Landslides and floods disrupted numerous rail connections. In the Kassel area, rail traffic on the Kassel–Eichenberg routes in the Kassel–Hannoversch Münden and Kassel–Waldkappel sections came to a standstill due to landslides. In Kassel, traffic on some main roads came to a halt because the sewer system was not designed to handle such large amounts of rainfall in such a short time. In Hannoversch Münden on the Fulda River, a campsite was evacuated as a precaution. In Wilhelmshausen near Reinhardswald, a stream coming from Gahrenberg brought a flood wave carrying large debris and rubble, flooding parts of the town. Here, as elsewhere, bridges were clogged with debris, significantly hindering water flow.

Neighboring areas of the former GDR were also affected by severe storms, such as in Großengottern and Torgau. A total of three people lost their lives. Severe thunderstorms on July 16, 1965, particularly affected Thuringia and the western Ore Mountains, leading to precipitation amounts of up to 75 l/m².

Due to the catastrophic rainfall during the midday and early afternoon hours and the rapidly swelling rivers and streams, the responsible authorities declared a disaster alert. This led to the deployment of thousands of civilian and military helpers. In addition to local fire departments, the Red Cross, church aid services, the police, and the Technical Relief Agency, soldiers of the Bundeswehr as well as the British Rhine Army stationed in Detmold, Hameln, and the Senne were deployed. While in Lower Saxony, the disaster plans established and practiced by emergency forces after the storm disasters of August 1955 and June 1961 in the Leine region, as well as the July floods of 1956 on the Leine, Aller, and Weser, were effective, and more severe impacts were prevented through a centrally coordinated deployment of rescue forces, the disaster response in the affected regions of North Rhine-Westphalia proved inadequate. During the cleanup operations, the then North Rhine-Westphalian Interior Minister Willi Weyer had to admit serious deficiencies in disaster protection. Due to a lack of coordination among the emergency forces, there were initially significant problems with rescue operations. For instance, Bundeswehr units stationed in the region, as well as Belgian, Dutch, and British military units, acted on their own initiative after the responsible local commanders recognized the existence of a catastrophic emergency. Other rescue units, such as the fire department, THW, and Red Cross, were unaware of these operations. The complete collapse of the telecommunications network and the lack of radios proved particularly devastating. The responsible district authorities had to send messengers in some areas to warn municipal administrations in the endangered regions. These messengers sometimes only reached the affected areas after hours. In the particularly hard-hit municipality of Etteln, the technical operations command set up by the local administration had only a single radio device. Numerous destroyed bridges and local, regional, and interregional roads impassable even for high-wheeled emergency vehicles caused significant problems. As a result, long detours were sometimes necessary to reach the operation sites. The inadequate equipment of the rescue teams prevented the rescue of those trapped in many places. At the Kuhlemühle Küting near Ossendorf, the Bundeswehr's attempt to rescue eight people and several children from buildings surrounded by water using a helicopter not designed for this situation failed. In Etteln, a woman and a child fell from a rescue rope provisionally attached to the helicopter. In some cases, people were stranded on the roofs of their houses in the flooded area for 17 hours. A woman also lost her life during a failed helicopter rescue operation on the Diemel. Below the Wrexer Pond between Wrexen and Rhoden, where a catastrophic flood wave occurred after a road dam broke, a dramatic rescue operation took place. The people trapped in the mill building threatened with collapse, including two children, could not be rescued from the air because the helicopters in use were only equipped with ropes that were too short, making it impossible to reach those trapped. Wrexen resident Louiza Ramus, who rescued the trapped individuals from the building together with sport diver Horst Richard Platt, was honored for her selfless act in December 1965 with the Hessian Rescue Medal by the then Hessian Prime Minister Georg August Zinn.

Whole_Text.header: Investigations and measures after the flood

Whole_Text.content: Just a few weeks after the disaster, extensive investigations into the course of events and the damage caused by the flooding were initiated. Noteworthy among these are the studies by geologist and then-director of the Geological State Office of North Rhine-Westphalia in Krefeld, Herbert Karrenberg, "Rainfall Intensity and Erosion in the Karst Area of Paderborn during the Storm of July 16, 1965,"[12] the work of geologist Ecke von Zezschwitz, "Soil and Vegetation Influences on Flooding and Erosion during the Storm of July 16, 1965, in the Paderborn Plateau Area" (1967),[15] as well as the report "Flood-Related Landscape Damage in the Altenau Catchment Area and Its Tributaries"[41] by Walter Mrass, with contributions from Wilhelm Lohmeyer and Gerhard Olschowy, commissioned by the then Federal Institute for Vegetation Science, Nature Conservation, and Landscape Management on behalf of the Westphalia-Lippe Regional Association. Of particular importance is the work of Ecke von Zezschwitz,[15] as he experienced the storm firsthand as an eyewitness and, as an experienced geologist, made detailed observations that could be incorporated into both his work and that of Herbert Karrenberg. The investigation by Mrass, Lohmeyer, and Olschowy focused primarily on the damage that occurred outside settlement areas. They found that river sections with banks covered by dense tree stands, preferably ash and willow, withstood even this extreme flood without significant damage. This applied to both flat banks and erosion-prone steep banks. The ash tree proved to be optimal in this regard, as its dense root system stabilized the bank, preventing the water masses from washing away loose material. In some areas, according to Mrass, Lohmeyer, and Olschowy, shrub stands, especially nettles, also proved to be highly effective bank protection during the Heinrichs Flood. The nettles' extensive root systems stabilized the bank substrate, and the plants laid down with the strong current on the riverbank, thereby preventing erosion.[24] Sections with sparse tree cover along the banks or those without any tree cover experienced the most severe damage, according to Mrass, Lohmeyer, and Olschowy. This was particularly true for river sections where grassland use extended right up to the bank. A destroyed grass cover due to livestock trampling in watering areas significantly promoted bank destruction. Fencing structures also had extremely negative effects. Dam-like structures, such as bridges and culverts with insufficient flow capacity, encouraged bank collapses and the formation of deep scour holes below the structures. River sections with individual trees or small groups of trees also suffered severe damage. Unlike banks with continuous tree cover, the formation of vortices here intensified the impact of the highly turbulent floodwaters. This led to the formation of deep scour holes, and the trees standing on the banks were uprooted, subsequently becoming driftwood that created obstacles in front of culverts and bridges. This driftwood not only worsened the situation in front of dam-like structures such as bridges and culverts, but also pasture fences developed a flood-retaining effect due to the accumulating driftwood.[24]

As a result of the July floods in 1965, flood protection and the system of water associations in the affected areas were reorganized. To prevent similar events, significant interventions were made in river systems. These included, among other measures, the straightening, deepening, and canalization of riverbeds, widening of bridge cross-sections, and the creation of large retention basins, such as in the catchment area of the Alme near Husen-Dalheim and its tributary, the Sauer near Sudheim and Ebbinghausen. The Aabach dam near Bad Wünnenberg, which had been planned before World War II, was also tailored to the needs of flood protection and implemented, creating additional storage capacity in the Aabach catchment area during floods. In the jurisdiction of the Upper Lippe Water Association, founded in 1971, 23 flood retention basins were constructed. In the Diemel catchment area, there were also significant interventions, including river straightening and the construction of dikes. On the Twiste, the Twistesee, which had been planned in the first half of the 20th century but repeatedly abandoned, was built to improve flood protection. In Lower Saxony, measures had already been initiated following the storm disaster of August 1955, the floods on the Weser, Aller, and Leine in July 1956, the June floods in southern Hanover, and the 1962 flood disaster on the North Sea coast. These included, among other things, an improvement in disaster protection, a fundamental reform of the partially centuries-old water association laws, and especially the development of the Aller-Leine-Oker Plan. At the time of the Heinrich flood, planning procedures for the construction of flood protection structures in Lower Saxony were already in full swing.

Although the Heinrichs Flood caused a stir in the national press at the time, it is largely forgotten today outside the affected areas. Due to the narrowly confined disaster area, it is overshadowed by the 1962 storm surge on the German North Sea coast, the Quimburga hurricane in 1972, as well as the catastrophic floods on the Oder in 1997 and the Elbe in 2002 and 2013. However, in many places, flood markers attached to buildings still commemorate the event. Commemorative events are regularly held on the anniversaries of the disaster. On these anniversaries, the regional press and regional magazines of Westdeutscher Rundfunk also recall the disaster. For example, on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of the Heinrichs Flood, Osnabrück Bishop Franz-Josef Bode visited Etteln, where he witnessed the disaster as a youth. For the 50th anniversary, a stele was erected in Etteln in July 2015.

The event was called Heinrichsflut because, in Catholic-influenced regions, the Heinrichsfest is traditionally celebrated on the second weekend of July, commemorating Henry II, among other things, the founder of the Diocese of Bamberg.

Throughout history, there have been numerous floods in Hanover. One of the oldest protective measures is the construction of the Schneller Graben, mentioned in 1449. The worst flooding in Hanover to date occurred in 1946, shortly after World War II.

The Leine flood in Hanover was part of the Weser flood of 1946. The peak of the catastrophic escalation of a flood situation occurred in the Weser catchment areas from February 2 to 11, 1946. After a winter frost period, thawing began on January 28, 1946. Neither the frost-induced impermeability of the soils in January 1946 nor the snowmelt in the Harz Mountains, which began at the end of January 1946, played as significant a role in the catastrophic extent of the February flood as in previous extreme floods in the Hanover area. The catastrophe was caused by unusually heavy rainfall in early February 1946. As a result, on February 10, 1946, the city of Hanover experienced its largest flood disaster to date. The rivers Leine and Ihme, as well as the Maschsee, overflowed their banks. Contributing to this was the natural narrowing of the 900-meter-wide flow area of the Ihme at Waterlooplatz to 400 meters at the Glocksee Bridge. Additionally, around 700,000 gasoline cans from a British depot at Schützenplatz Hanover were washed up there, further blocking the water flow under the bridges. Consequently, 1,666 hectares were flooded up to a height of 3 meters, including the districts of Altstadt, Calenberger Neustadt, Südstadt, Linden, and Ricklingen. The water level of the Leine in Herrenhausen rose to 6.44 meters, a level that has not been reached since. This water level is considered a centennial flood for the city of Hanover. The flood claimed three lives and caused significant property damage. After the flood, historical documents from the Hanover City Archive were removed uncontrollably and burned during the winter, resulting in the loss of 80% of the 19th-century city history records.

As early as the 1950s, extensive safety measures were implemented, particularly in dike construction. As a result of climate change and to counter potential extreme weather events, reconstruction measures were carried out along the Ihme at the Peter-Fechter-Ufer near the Ihme Center between 2010 and 2013. Further upstream on the left bank of the Ihme, the existing dike in eastern Ricklingen was extended by one kilometer in 2013 and 2014 with a southernly adjoining dike and a flood protection wall at the Michaelis Cemetery. During the renovation of the Benno-Ohnesorg Bridge over the Ihme between 2008 and 2013, the bridge structure was extended to prevent backwater. During the Central European floods in May and June 2013, water levels in Hanover's rivers were also high due to heavy rainfall in the Leine catchment area. In the floodplain of the Leine in the Stöcken district, a woman died on May 30, 2013, after being swept away by the current while crossing a flooded road.

Whole_Text.header: Flood in the Eastern Ore Mountains 1927
Whole_Text.content: The flood in the Eastern Ore Mountains in 1927 occurred in the river basins of Gottleuba and Müglitz in the Eastern Ore Mountains. On the night of July 8 to 9, 1927, after several days of rainfall during a Vb weather pattern, a thunderstorm front passed through, causing 113 millimeters of precipitation within 25 minutes in the source areas of Gottleuba and Müglitz, the Ore Mountain ridge near Sattelberg, Mückentürmchen, and Geisingberg. In Dohna, the discharge of the Müglitz reached a value of 330 m³/s, while in the town of Gottleuba, the discharge of the Gottleuba even reached 400 m³/s. For comparison, the Elbe at the Schöna gauge has an average discharge (MQ, based on the years 1980–2008) of 305 m³/s. The masses of water surprised the residents of the valley settlements during the night hours. There was virtually no warning time, resulting in a total of about 160 fatalities, including 88 in Berggießhübel alone. This makes the flood in the Eastern Ore Mountains in 1927 one of the most devastating flood disasters in recent German history.

The Eastern Ore Mountains, particularly the catchment areas of the Gottleuba, Müglitz, and Weißeritz rivers, are among the classic flood-prone regions in Saxony. Since 1560, heavy rainfall with devastating flash floods, causing significant damage and numerous fatalities, has been repeatedly documented here. In the Müglitz Valley alone, eighteen severe flood disasters occurred between 1609 and 2002. Overall, according to records, nearly 60 severe floods have occurred in the valleys of the Gottleuba and Müglitz over the past 500 years. The floods of more recent times, namely the years 1897, 1927, 1957, and 2002, caused particularly devastating destruction. Among these more recent floods, the event of July 8/9, 1927, stands out in a particularly tragic way due to the estimated 160 fatalities.

Whole_Text.header: Flood origin area Ore Mountains (Eastern Ore Mountains)
Whole_Text.content: Origin, course, and consequences of the catastrophe on July 8/9, 1927, as well as numerous other severe floods in the Eastern Ore Mountains, were determined by the complex interplay of precipitation events and regional characteristics.

The location and shape of the Eastern Ore Mountains have always favored the formation of orographically induced air mass boundaries, leading to the occurrence of heavy precipitation. Initially multi-day rainfalls repeatedly developed in the past into torrential downpours, with precipitation totals in the higher elevations reaching extreme values, sometimes approaching the limits of physical possibility. The flood of 1927 (as well as the floods of 1897, 1957, and 2002) was attributed to a Vb weather pattern. In this situation, low-pressure systems brought extremely moist and warm air with high precipitation potential along the trajectory from the Mediterranean region to the Polish Baltic coast, causing strong and prolonged steady rain (area-wide precipitation). Since Saxony was located on the western flank of this low, the air masses were pushed from the north against the Ore Mountains. The stowage effect led to the precipitation of the saturated air masses on the northern side. At the same time, the decreasing movement speed caused a longer stationary presence over the mountains. This resulted in the complete precipitation of convective rainfall with torrential showers and thunderstorms.

The rivers of the Eastern Ore Mountains have comparatively high-relief energy catchment areas. While the source areas of the Müglitz and Gottleuba are located at about 700 to 800 meters altitude, their mouths into the Elbe, reached after 34 and 49 kilometers of flow respectively, are at about 110 meters altitude. Thus, the rivers exhibit a steep terrain gradient with significant elevation differences in a confined space. As a result, the river valleys have cut steeply and narrowly into the bedrock. Natural retention areas, such as larger valley expansions, are scarcely present or have been utilized for settlement and transportation development since the mid-19th century. The steep gradient and insufficient retention areas cause high flow velocities of the waters, especially during floods.

The river basins of Gottleuba and Müglitz belonged to the dense forest area that stretched from the edge of the Elbe valley expansion to the ridge areas and the Bohemian southern slope of the Ore Mountains before their settlement. At the time of the 1927 flood, however, the source areas of both rivers were considered to be sparsely forested. Even today, only about 45% (202 square kilometers) of the approximately 460 square kilometer catchment areas of Müglitz and Gottleuba are forested. The comparatively low forest proportion for a low mountain range is, among other things, a consequence of the settlement that began in the 12th century. With land acquisition, the forest landscape in the Eastern Ore Mountains was transformed within a few decades into a cultural landscape characterized by villages, towns, fields, and transport routes. This settlement activity led to extensive clearings, as the firewood consumption alone in the 16th century was estimated at at least 20 cubic meters per house per year. Additionally, wood was consumed for the construction of houses (timber framing, shingles, etc.) and the production of everyday goods (household furnishings). Larger amounts of wood were also needed for reconstruction after fires. The total wood consumption of a settler in the mid-16th century amounted to over 500 kilograms per year. The settlement-related strain on the forest was further intensified by iron ore mining in the region around Berggießhübel and Bad Gottleuba and tin ore mining in Altenberg and Zinnwald. Both mining itself and smelting were existentially dependent on wood as a building material or on charcoal as an energy source. For example, the production of just one kilogram of iron required the use of 29 to 46 kilograms of wood. The required amounts of wood were largely harvested without regard for the regenerative capacity of the forests, leading to their depletion and devastation. During its peak period (16th century), iron ore mining and smelting in the central Gottleuba area alone consumed one to two square kilometers of forest per year. The fact is that forests can mitigate the effects of floods. They have an intensive and extensive root system, which is highly effective in conducting and storing water. While about 65 to 70 liters of water per square meter can seep into a flat forest floor, only 20 liters can do so on an equally sized pasture area. Another portion of the precipitation can be retained by the canopy and evaporates back from there. In the coniferous forests predominant in the Eastern Ore Mountains, about 30 to 40% of the precipitation does not even reach the ground, as it is converted into water vapor by the trees and released back into the atmosphere.

The flood originated from a thunderstorm front that moved from the southwest, from Bohemia (region around Tetschen (Děčín)), across the Ore Mountains ridge. At Mückenberg (Komáří hůrka) and Sattelberg (Špičák u Krásného Lesa), it split and poured down in the Müglitz and Gottleuba valleys. Part of this thunderstorm was held back by the Schneeberg (Děčínský Sněžník) and later poured into the source areas of the Müglitz and Gottleuba. Between 10:00 a.m. and 11:00 a.m., the thunderstorm settled in the Sattelberg area after having struck the town of Schönwald. The Gottleuba, which normally has a width of three meters, widened to 80 to 100 meters. Flood waves up to six meters high rushed into the valleys. The amount of water that fell was estimated at 120 to 150 liters per square meter. In Schönwald (Krásný Les), 209 millimeters of precipitation fell. Further precise data is not known, as several weather stations of the state weather service fell victim to the storm.

The high number of fatalities was primarily due to the rapid rise in water levels, the high flow velocities, the debris carried along, and the short warning times. Additionally, many people were caught off guard by the second flood wave, which broke in around midnight, while they were asleep. A particular tragedy arose from the partial wiping out of entire families. However, the exact number of people who lost their lives in the devastating storm cannot be precisely determined to this day, as the number of guests, day-trippers, and workers present in the area (including those working on laying a telephone line towards Vienna) remains uncertain. Therefore, the literature varies in estimating the number of victims between 146 and 158 deaths. It seems realistic to assume about 160 victims. The numbers provided below include all flood victims who lost their lives in the municipalities, i.e., both residents and guests (spa guests, workers, etc.).

Damage also occurred to tributaries and streams such as the Bahra, the Trebnitz, the Rotes Wasser, as well as the Fürstenwälder, Liebenauer, and Hartmannsbacher village streams. The rainfall, which poured down in a very short time, was often blocked by driftwood at narrow valleys and bridges. This created reservoirs up to 8 meters high, which repeatedly broke and further intensified the flooding through tidal waves. The disaster surpassed the severe flood of July 30/31, 1897, which had occurred only 30 years earlier, by many times. Property damage to buildings and infrastructure amounted to over 100 million Reichsmarks. The following places were particularly affected:
In the municipality of Schönwald, 26 houses were severely damaged or destroyed.

On the railway lines from Pirna to Gottleuba and Großcotta, seven and two bridges respectively were completely destroyed. Continuous rail traffic between Pirna and Gottleuba was only possible again in September. In the Gottleuba Valley, ten bridges on the valley road and its connecting roads were severely damaged or completely torn away. The town of Berggießhübel was almost completely destroyed along the Gottleuba.

In the Oelsengrund, a large amount of wood and debris was washed up. The water swept away rocks weighing 17 hundredweight. The Köhler Mill (Friedrich Gotthard Köhler) disappeared completely, as did the utility building of the Meisel Mill. The barn and side building of the Paust Mill and the Clemens Mill were also destroyed. The Haselberg forestry house and the Hammer estate were almost completely destroyed as well. The connecting road from the Bährmühle to Gottleuba and the bridge to Hartmannsbach no longer exist. Two residents died.

The road leading from Bährmühle to Bad Gottleuba was completely destroyed. The Zimmermann property, along with the feed and grain supplies located there, was severely damaged and had to be demolished. In the city center, residents had to be evacuated from the upper floors using ladders, as the ground floors of numerous buildings were completely silted. Several buildings collapsed during the flood, while others were so severely damaged that they had to be demolished afterward. This included the Gottleuba school building. The Gottleuba bridges to Helleberg and Giesenstein collapsed under the force of the water masses. A total of nine fatalities were reported, including two summer guests. The victims of the disaster in Gottleuba were buried in the municipal cemetery on July 12, 1927.

With thunder and lightning, the storm began around 4:00 PM and lasted approximately ten hours. Around 9:00 PM, heavy rain started, and by 10:00 PM, the riverbanks were already half a meter underwater. Upstream of the town, the water accumulated at the railway bridge of the Gottleubatalbahn, which was blocked by driftwood, reaching a height of seven meters. Around 11:30 PM, the water broke through this barrier and poured over the town as a flood wave two to three meters high, with an estimated flow rate of 400 m³/s, without warning. The Gottleuba left only a field of debris in the town center. Fifteen houses were immediately destroyed, another 22 had to be demolished later, and 23 houses were severely damaged. All streets and bridges in the town were completely destroyed. A food shortage loomed, as, for example, all three butchers lost their lives, and the grocery stores and bakeries were destroyed. Of the approximately 1,300 residents, 88, including 12 children, lost their lives. In the Zwiesel district, two buildings were swept away, and a third was so severely damaged that it had to be demolished. Seven deaths were reported here.

The millstream of the Schmidt & Co mill is destroyed. At the Hering sawmill, the power plant and the mill residence have disappeared. A four-meter debris pile was located in the courtyard of the Bähr mill.

On July 8th, around 8:45 PM, flooding was reported from Gottleuba. Around 2:30 AM, residents were awakened by fire department sirens and the calls of "Flood is coming." Between the Carolabad and the former rowing club house, a hole approximately fifteen meters wide and four meters deep was torn open. The following streets (some of them former) were completely flooded: Breite Straße (Dohnaische Vorstadt), Dohnaische Straße (Altstadt), Gartenstraße, Reichsstraße, Klosterstraße (Westvorstadt), Bahnhofsstraße, Grohmannstraße, Schmiedestraße, Lange Straße, and Rottwerndorfer Straße (Südvorstadt). Extensive damage occurred at the former Rottwerndorf manor, which belonged to the city at the time. Rough estimates indicated 25,000 marks in material damage, 35,000–40,000 marks in structural damage, and 15,000–20,000 marks in crop damage. In the Neundorf district, the floodwaters rose one and a half meters higher than in 1897. The flood wave was temporarily up to three meters high. Around 11:30 PM, the telephone connection to Berggießhübel was interrupted, and the lights also went out. During the subsequent flood, several people were killed. The former smithy and the associated residential house were swept away. Some residents managed to hold onto drifting wood and building materials and thus escaped the flood.

The railway facilities of the Müglitztalbahn, which runs alongside the Müglitz in large sections, were largely destroyed or severely damaged in the section between Lauenstein and Dohna. The evening train standing in Glashütte was carried over 300 meters by the second flood wave. Overall, the flood destroyed about 20 kilometers of track, and the remaining sections were largely impassable due to undermining, silting, and the deposition of debris. Of the 28 railway bridges between Köttewitz and Lauenstein, 24 collapsed. As a result, one of the main traffic routes in the Eastern Ore Mountains was out of service for an extended period. Rail replacement bus services via Dippoldiswalde were set up for passenger transport. Freight transport was also shifted to the road (as far as this was possible and still necessary given the destroyed industrial sites). The reconstruction of the line resembled a new construction due to the financial and material effort. The first section between Heidenau and Köttewitz was already reopened on July 26, with the remaining sections following step by step: August 15: Lauenstein–Altenberg, August 18: Köttewitz–Weesenstein, October 3: Weesenstein–Häselich, October 13: Häselich–Oberschlottwitz, November 15: Oberschlottwitz–Glashütte. The line was not fully operational again until December 1. The reopening of the valley's "lifeline" was enthusiastically celebrated in the neighboring communities. At the same time, the severe destruction and the extensive reconstruction efforts initiated considerations for converting the narrow-gauge line to standard gauge. The goal of these considerations was to raise the route by up to 15 meters to reduce future flood damage.

The Hammergut Kratzhammer, located at the northern end of Fürstenwalde, was one of the first settlements affected by the Müglitz flood. The masses of water turned the valley into a wasteland of rubble and completely destroyed two houses. Eight people died in one of the two houses.

In Lauenstein, the flood raged as severely as in Berggießhübel. However, since the center of the town is located on a terrace above the Müglitz and there were no continuous rows of houses along the river in the town, the flood damage was far less dramatic than in the neighboring Gottleuba Valley. However, the railway facilities located in the valley were severely damaged. Thanks to the efforts of the two Lauenstein railway officials, the evening train of the Müglitztalbahn could be stopped in Glashütte, which likely saved the lives of many more people. However, the two officials themselves perished in the floods.

In the watchmaking town of Glashütte, located at the confluence of the Prießnitz and Müglitz rivers, a flood alarm was triggered at around 7:30 PM. Shortly thereafter, an initial flood wave rapidly entered the lower part of the town. However, this caused "only" property damage. The second flood wave, which reached the town at around 11:45 PM, was significantly more devastating. Within minutes, the water once again surged into the town with great force. The Müglitz, carrying large amounts of debris and driftwood, swelled to a width of 100 meters and a height of two meters in the lower part of the town near the train station. Individual flood waves are said to have reached heights of up to six meters. The evening train of the Müglitztalbahn, standing at the station, was completely surrounded by the floodwaters, with some carriages swept away up to 300 meters. Two of the swept-away carriages destroyed the Kurfürst-Moritz Bridge over the Müglitz, built in 1545, which had withstood the severe flood of July 31, 1897. Passengers trapped in the carriages were rescued by the fire department at around 2:30 AM. After the flood subsided, the station area was covered with about one meter of mud, debris, and sludge. The town estimated the flood damage at approximately 100,000 Reichsmarks. A total of twelve people lost their lives in the floodwaters in Glashütte.

Many cellars were flooded, and a shed and stables were swept away by the flood. Many bridges were severely damaged. The Ploschwitz Bridge, which carried the main water and gas pipelines, was heavily damaged, causing both pipelines to burst and the electricity and gas supply to come to a halt. Hundreds of meters of wood were washed away from the Köttewitz paper factory.
A large number of residential and commercial buildings were affected. Mühlenstraße was heavily damaged. The bridge that spanned the Müglitz at the Elbe estuary was completely torn away.

A flood wave of the Seidewitz and its tributaries poured into Liebstadt, located in a narrow valley basin below Kuckuckstein Castle, at around 11:30 PM, completely flooding the town within two minutes. The water masses likely stood about one and a half meters high in the streets and houses, as eyewitnesses reported that residents, standing up to their necks in water, tried to save their belongings. By this time, Liebstadt had already been cut off from the power supply and was in complete darkness. The water masses, enriched with extensive debris, receded after midnight but caused such severe damage to the town's streets and bridges within this short time that the place was initially cut off from the outside world. Several houses suffered severe damage due to collapsed gables and torn-away walls, and smaller outbuildings (sheds, storage facilities), including parts of the Carlowitz manor, were completely washed away. One residential house had to be demolished following the flood. The Niedermühle and Mittelmühle mills were heavily devastated by the floods, and the old sawmill of the Niedermühle was subsequently demolished. In total, about 100 residents in Liebstadt were affected by flood damage. However, unlike the towns in the neighboring valleys, there were no fatalities in the city, as the Seidewitz, unlike the Gottleuba and Müglitz rivers, is still a relatively small river within the town, and people were able to quickly flee to the valley slopes through the back exits of their houses due to the narrowness of the valley.

The so-called Thuringian Flood was a flood disaster in the year 1613, during which parts of Thuringia were affected by high water. On May 29, 1613, severe thunderstorms broke out over parts of Thuringia, causing many rivers to rise by several meters within a few hours. The affected area stretched from Mühlhausen, Langensalza, and Artern in the north to Stadtilm and Ichtershausen in the south, from Erfurt and Gotha in the west to Naumburg in the east. The storm disaster is described as the "Thuringian Flood" in the chronicles of many localities:  
In Kahla, there were several fatalities, and large parts of Jena were flooded. In Zottelstedt near Apolda, the water level of the Ilm rose by 6 to 8 meters, almost completely destroying the village in the riverside area. In Apolda itself, eight houses were swept away, and 24 animals drowned. In Weimar, 44 houses were destroyed in the flood disaster, 23 houses in Bad Berka, and 125 houses in Erfurt. In Mattstedt, the water level of the Ilm rose by 6 meters and flooded the entire lower village. The disaster resulted in the further development of the village shifting to higher ground. In Bad Sulza, the saline, which had been built on the Ilm only a few years earlier, fell victim to the flood but was rebuilt in the same location. The total number of fatalities is reported to be 2,261 people. Historical flood events like the Thuringian Flood play an important role as hydrological-meteorological extreme situations in current research on this topic. See also: Century Flood

In the year 1720, Georg Wilhelm von Lage published the work "The Complete Acts of the Thuringian Flood of 1613," which was published by the Lackische Buchhandlung in Weimar and Leipzig (format 4°, i.e., quarto) Digital copy. This book was part of the estate of the mining councilor Johann Karl Wilhelm Voigt, who passed away in Ilmenau in 1821 ("Catalog of the Mineralogical Library left behind by the mining councilor Voigt, who passed away on January 1," published by his son, the bookseller and later publisher Bernhard Friedrich Voigt, Sondershausen, Ilmenau, or Weimar). Another copy is located in the central church archive of the Johannesgemeinde. The meteorologist Gustav Hellmann compiled a bibliography on the Thuringian Flood, listing the writings available at his time along with reprints of the title pages. The July flood of 1956 was a catastrophic flood on the Upper and Middle Weser as well as the Aller and Leine due to days of continuous rain in the mountainous regions of Thuringia, Lower Saxony, Hesse, and East Westphalia.

As early as June 1956, there had been heavy rainfall. In Lower Saxony, precipitation reached over 300 percent of the long-term average in some areas. Between July 14 and 16, 1956, nearly 50 hours of continuous heavy rain occurred in the mountainous regions of Lower Saxony, Thuringia, Hesse, and East Westphalia, accompanied by storm-like downpours in the lowlands. These rains fell on water-saturated ground, causing the precipitation to flow exclusively on the surface. Within a very short time, water levels rose dramatically, leading to widespread flooding. By July 16, 1956, the water level of the Weser in Minden had risen to 4.50 m above the average water level, halting navigation on the Upper and Middle Weser. In the city of Braunschweig, 681 hectares of grassland and farmland in the Wabe and Mittelriede areas were flooded by July 17. In the lignite mine of Retterode near Hessisch Lichtenau (Werra-Meißner district), massive water ingress occurred on July 15 due to the rainfall, partially flooding the underground facilities. The situation worsened in the Aller and Leine rivers and the Hessian highlands after further storm-like rains on July 18 and 19, 1956, leading to dike breaches, riverbed shifts, and uncontrolled overflow of the Eder Dam. The Free Hanseatic City of Bremen narrowly avoided a severe flood disaster only because the floodwaters were diverted via the then-existing overflow routes near Thedinghausen into the Ochtum lowlands west of the city, which, however, caused flooding in the municipalities of Stuhr and Hasbergen. By July 25, over 240,000 hectares were flooded due to the flooding of the Middle Weser. The estimated property damage amounted to over 170 million DM. On July 17, 1956, the Porta Westfalica gauge of the state WSA recorded an extreme value of 1180 m³/s and 629 cm, which nearly approached the century flood of the Weser on February 10, 1946, with 2300 m³/s and 790 cm.

The Oder flood disaster of 1947 was the most consequential flood caused by an Oder high water in modern times in Germany.

The heaviest Oder flood disaster of the 20th century in the Oderbruch occurred in the spring of 1947. On the evening of March 21 into the night of March 22, drifting ice due to ice flow formed an ice barrier near the flood channel at Küstrin-Kietz. Ice jams also formed north of Reitwein. These quickly dammed large amounts of water. In the early morning of March 22, 1947, at 1 a.m., the Oder dike near Reitwein was finally flooded. The dike crest was overtopped by water in two places over a length of more than 100 meters. Sections of the dike crest, approximately 300 meters wide and one meter deep, were quickly destroyed. The flood even reached Bad Freienwalde (Oder), several kilometers away from the river, including the main post office building in the city center, where a memorial stone is located today. More than 20,000 people were left homeless at the time. The head of the disaster protection department of the Märkisch-Oderland district administration also confirmed an ultimately unsuccessful deployment of Red Army bombers against the dangerous ice jams on the Oder in 1947. On the morning of March 22, eight bombs were dropped by Soviet aircraft, followed by four more in the afternoon. Further bombings were carried out on March 23. However, none of the measures achieved the desired result. The jam finally dissolved on March 24 at around 9 p.m.

The floods in Thailand in 2011 began at the end of March 2011 due to heavy rain. At least 51 people lost their lives. The hardest-hit area was Southern Thailand, where many mudslides also occurred. The heavy rain and mudslides were very unusual for this time of year because the monsoon rains usually become active in the summer, and it should have been bone dry at that time.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs advised against traveling to the affected area unless absolutely necessary. The airport on Ko Samui was also temporarily closed, leaving thousands of tourists stranded. It is estimated that approximately 265,000 people were affected by the floods. At the end of July, new floods occurred, this time in the north, which slowly spread toward the north (and mainly toward the capital, Bangkok). These floods were of significantly larger scale and claimed more lives.

Whole_Text.content: The extreme winter of 1783/1784 in the Northern Hemisphere was part of a natural climate fluctuation and is considered one of the harshest ever in Central Europe, but it was also unusual in North America and Asia. It was followed by extreme floods in February and March 1784 in Central Europe, which are regarded as one of the greatest natural disasters of the early modern period in this region. The cause is attributed to particularly sulfur-rich or especially intense and ash-rich volcanic eruptions that occurred in Iceland.

During the eruption of the Laki craters in Iceland (beginning on June 8, 1783, lasting about 8 months), a total of approximately 130 craters produced a total volume of about 12 to 15 km³ of lava. In addition, there were clouds of gas and ash. The extensive amounts of emitted sulfur dioxide reacted with the water droplets in the clouds to form sulfurous acid and sulfuric acid. In addition to an estimated 122 million tons of sulfur dioxide, 15 million tons of hydrogen fluoride (HF) and 7 million tons of hydrogen chloride (HCl) were released. This had devastating consequences for the entire country: due to poisoning, livestock perished (→ fluorosis); and the resulting famine caused an estimated 9,350 people to die in the following years, more than one-fifth of Iceland's population. In Western Europe, the eruption also had an impact; the toxic aerosol cloud spread across the entire continent, particularly over the British Isles, and was perceived as high-altitude haze or "dry fog." Records report that the smog lingered in the sky for weeks. Symptoms of poisoning manifested as shortness of breath, making it difficult, for example, for farmers to continue their fieldwork. On the British Isles alone, around 25,000 people died. The eruption of Mount Asama in Japan in 1783 had only a minor impact on climate changes compared to the eruption of the Laki craters.

Benjamin Franklin reports a remarkably cold winter in Philadelphia. At the time, he was the American ambassador in Paris and suspected that the cold was the result of a dust haze in the atmosphere over Europe and North America. The cold was so severe that the harbor of New York City froze over for ten days, and sleds were able to cross the Long Island Sound.

Throughout the European region, the winter was exceptionally cold and snowy. Scientists assume that in 1784 the average temperature was one degree Celsius lower than usual. The frost period lasted a total of 13 weeks in Mainfranken. The cold began in December 1783, and almost all bodies of water in Central Europe subsequently froze over. The Great Belt in Denmark was already so heavily frozen that it could be crossed with sleds and wagons. Around December 26/27, 1783, there was a brief improvement in temperatures, but by the end of the year, they dropped sharply again. This extreme cold lasted until mid-January 1784. From mid-January to February 21/22, this cold phase was repeatedly interrupted by short periods of slightly milder temperatures. During this time, snow also fell frequently. The winter was very snowy from December to February. For example, from December 24, 1783, to February 21, 29 snowfall events were observed in Mannheim, some of which lasted for days. In some regions, the snow grew to more than 150 centimeters in height, with around 45 centimeters of snow falling in the Rhine-Neckar region on December 27 and 28, 1783. February also brought a lot of snow and ice. All of Europe was hit by a cold wave from late December 1783 to January, stretching from the Black Sea to the Atlantic. In France, it was so cold that wolves appeared in villages to prey on livestock. The snow masses in the winter of 1783/84 restricted agricultural production in various German states to such an extent that severe supply shortages occurred. To bridge these shortages, the respective governments intervened with controls. In Königsberg, so much grain was stored that there was not enough space for it. In Darmstadt, several people froze to death. On the Saxon Elbe, ice floes formed, becoming increasingly dense, and on the night of December 28 to 29, the river in front of the Augustus Bridge in Dresden froze over. In Frankfurt am Main, bread and wood collections were organized in January 1784 due to the persistent severe cold and to support the poor. A total of 14,752 loaves of bread, each weighing six pounds, were distributed. In Speyer, modest celebrations were held on the frozen Rhine to use the proceeds from this charity event to combat poverty. Out of fear of possible ice drift, public prayers were ordered in Cologne and Bamberg. In Stuttgart, a balloon was launched in the courtyard of the military academy, illuminated and equipped with a small fireworks display. The proceeds from this event were used to buy wood for the city's poor, as prices for it were very high. On January 7, temperatures of minus 17.5 degrees Réaumur (−21.9 °C) were measured in Leipzig at seven in the morning. In Weida in Vogtland, the Réaumur thermometer also showed minus 21 degrees Réaumur (−26.3 °C) on the morning of January 7. However, even in the cold January of 1784, warmer periods were recorded in Saxony. From January 15 to 17, thawing weather prevailed, with a maximum temperature of +5 °C. This meteorological pattern, alternating between colder and warmer periods, continued in February 1784 and led to an accumulation of ice on the Elbe, as the cold January period over Germany was followed by a cold period until February 21/22, repeatedly interrupted by short warmer phases. The severe frost lasted until the end of February 1784, causing the ice masses on the Elbe to pile up to 110 centimeters. In addition, significant snowfall in the Electorate made the supply situation more difficult.

Around February 23, a sudden influx of warm air caused the enormous snow masses that had accumulated during the winter to melt. This warm air was triggered by a blocking high-pressure system over Eastern Europe, which resulted in a southward-oriented circulation in Central Europe. The change in the large-scale weather pattern brought warm air masses from western and southern directions to Mainfranken and large parts of Europe. The winter had previously been characterized for an unusually long time by the large-scale weather patterns of High Central Europe and East, which had brought very cold air masses from northern and eastern directions. The warm air influx was marked by widespread precipitation due to large-scale overrunning movements. Due to the rapid and intense warming, accompanied by heavy rainfall, the ice in Germany's rivers broke and jammed in the last days of February 1784. Because of the enormous meltwater masses, ice jams, and heavy precipitation, water levels began to rise very quickly. Ice movement occurred simultaneously on all major main and tributary rivers. Compounding the situation was the fact that, during intermittent thawing phases, several layers of ice had pushed over one another and then refrozen. Shortly after this warm air influx, cold weather returned due to another change in the large-scale weather pattern, precipitation decreased, and water levels quickly dropped. The blocking high had dissolved, and the previous weather patterns were able to reestablish themselves. Cold air once again flowed into Central Europe from northern and eastern directions.

The flood event is considered one of the greatest natural disasters of the early modern period in Central Europe. The flood devastated entire valleys, countless bridges were destroyed. It is also referred to as the "century ice drift" or "ice flood" or "winter flood of 1784." Cologne was struck by the worst flood ever recorded. During the mentioned temperature jump, the Rhine was completely frozen, while the snowmelt and breaking ice caused a record level of 13.55 meters – for comparison, the normal level is 3.48 meters. The floods, carrying heavy ice floes, devastated large parts of the riverside buildings and destroyed all ships. Individual buildings, including fortifications, collapsed due to the ice floes. 65 deaths were reported. In Beuel, only very few buildings with stone foundations survived the ice chunks; all half-timbered houses were washed away. The old Bergisch town of Mülheim am Rhein, located on the right bank of the Rhine and now a district of Cologne, was completely destroyed. Even the trees of the famous walnut grove on the Namedyer Werth (a peninsula since 1857) near Andernach were literally cut off above their roots by the ice floes. The Andernach Old Crane escaped the disaster thanks to the basalt icebreaker built upstream. On the Moselle, the ice flood of 1784 remains the highest winter flood documented by flood marks to this day. In Trier, the water's peak level was observed on February 28, 1784. The water reached as far as the Pferdemarkt and Jakobsgasse. A plaque on a building at the Großer Markt in Saarlouis marks the water level of the Saar from 1784. The Neckar caused the largest flood in historical times in Heidelberg. The effects of the flood were exacerbated by the ice drift. In addition to the Old Bridge, 39 buildings were destroyed and 290 damaged. Similarly affected were other communities, especially Neckarhausen, along the Neckar's further course toward its mouth, including downtown Mannheim. After Seckenheim, the river partially followed the path of an old branch and flooded Neckarau, several kilometers away. The natural disaster prompted the construction of the first flood protection measures between Edingen and Mannheim. Among other things, under the rule of Elector Karl Friedrich of Baden, a sandstone icebreaker was installed on the Neckar bank in Edingen. The Main also experienced extreme flooding. This flood, second only to the Magdalene Flood of 1342, is classified as a 300- to 500-year event in the central Main region. The flood mark on the Würzburg town hall portal shows a maximum level of 173.83 m above sea level for this flood, which is 94 cm above the 1845 value. Compared to the flood recorded at the gauge in 1845, the 1784 flood had a level of 928 centimeters, with a discharge of 2600 m³/s. In Bamberg, the largest flood of all time destroyed the riverside buildings in the Mühlenviertel. The bridges were also heavily damaged. In particular, the Seesbrücke, completed in 1756 and now the Kettenbrücke, with its baroque features, was destroyed by ice floes and uprooted tree trunks. In Marktbreit, the then half-timbered loading crane was destroyed and later replaced by a stone structure with an icebreaker. At the end of February / beginning of March 1784, one of the most severe spring floods ever recorded occurred in the Bohemian and Saxon Elbe Valley. The Elbe, frozen for weeks, broke up within a very short time, rising by up to 32 cm per hour and reaching a level of 8.57 m in Dresden on March 1 (discharge 5200 m³/s). This was the highest level since 1655. Throughout the Elbe Valley, towns and villages were extensively flooded. In Dresden, the water stood one meter high in the courtyard of the Zwinger. The destructive power of the flood was particularly great due to the force of the debris and ice floes it carried. In Wegstädtl in Bohemia, the Gothic church collapsed. In Dresden and Meissen, the Elbe bridges were severely damaged. While livestock could not be saved in many places, the number of fatalities was relatively low given the severity of the flood. In Meissen, nine people lost their lives in the floods. The old postal road between Meissen and Dresden was relocated to flood-safe areas due to the flood. Although the Elbe returned to its original course on March 6, cleanup efforts were difficult as the onset of frost covered the flooded houses and areas with a layer of ice. The flood levels of that time were only surpassed in many places during the Elbe flood of 1845. Further downstream on the Elbe, in the Duchy of Magdeburg between Aken and Sandau, extreme floods with dike breaches occurred only in early April, including between Cracau and Prester near Magdeburg. The area around the confluence of the Saale and Elbe near Calbe (Saale) and the section north of the town of Jerichow to Sandau, all areas also particularly affected by the 2013 flood, were also severely hit. After the Lahn destroyed a bridge with a water pipeline in Weilburg, the first chain bridge on the European continent was built here after reconstruction. Smaller rivers such as the Glan in Ulmet (Palatinate) or the Paar in Baar-Ebenhausen (Bavaria) also experienced flooding.
