On November 5 and 6, 1994, the provinces of Cuneo, Turin, Asti, and Alessandria were heavily affected by a violent flood event that caused the overflow of the Po, Tanaro rivers, and many of their tributaries (in particular the Belbo stream, an important right tributary of the Tanaro), resulting in 69 victims and 2,226 displaced persons.

It is possible to characterize the event through three successive phases, phases that involved distinct territorial areas (ARPA Piemonte). The first phase, which occurred on 11/4, was characterized by heavy thunderstorms and mainly affected the southernmost sectors of Piedmont and the Ligurian territory: the maximum rainfall intensity was reached during the night between November 4 and 5 with hourly values exceeding 35 mm/hour and a peak of 55 mm/hour around midnight (Cairo Montenotte, Acqui Terme). Subsequently, on the 5th (second phase), the rainfall extended to the areas of Astigiano and Cuneese. In many locations in the Tanaro, Bormida, and Belbo basins, rainfall heights of over 200 mm in 24 hours were exceeded. The maximum cumulative rainfall over two days occurred in Levice (CN) with 293.8 mm; the maximum for one day was also recorded in Levice with 264.6 mm (Luino, 1999). In the third phase of the event, the most intense rainfall affected the pre-Alpine belt between the Pellice Valley and the Sesia Valley in the afternoon and evening of the 5th, subsiding in the morning of the 6th. On the 6th, the rainfall practically ceased in the southern part of the region, while it continued in the central-northern part, with modest hourly intensity but still significant daily totals.

After several days of continuous rain, the Tanaro rose to terrifying levels.  
A flood wave formed on November 5 upstream of Ormea and, rushing downstream, devastated with unprecedented fury its entire course and the dozens of inhabited centers along its banks until reaching the confluence with the Po in the early hours of November 7.  
During the flood event, the Tanaro reached record flow levels never before seen in the century.  
The entire stretch between the municipality of Ormea and the confluence with the Stura di Demonte near Cherasco was particularly affected by the flood event, where the Tanaro almost completely destroyed most of the existing civil structures (houses, bridges, roads, etc.), also permanently altering the shape of its bed and the valley floor in many areas.  
The municipalities affected by the flood wave were: Particularly affected were the cities of Ceva, Alba, and Asti, flooded over 1/3 of their surface, and especially Alessandria, submerged by almost 50%, where 14 people lost their lives.

In those 3 days of rain (over 200 mm in 24 hours on November 5 alone), the stream swelled excessively, reaching exceptional flow rates of 1,330 m³/s in Santo Stefano Belbo and almost 1,000 m³/s in Castelnuovo Belbo (respectively 220 and 167 times the normal flow), overflowing along its entire course and brutally devastating almost all of its valley floor. Particularly affected by the fury of the waters were the municipalities of Rocchetta Belbo, Cossano Belbo, Santo Stefano Belbo, Canelli (the hardest-hit center, which also counted 3 victims), and Incisa Scapaccino; only Nizza Monferrato was spared from the disaster, though it suffered heavy damage to roads adjacent to the watercourse and flooding of some basements.

Due to the heavy rains, the river level rose significantly, and in addition to the damage caused by the contribution of the Tanaro downstream, upstream the river, swollen particularly by the contributions of the Orco and Dora Baltea tributaries, overflowed in various areas causing significant damage and widespread flooding. Areas heavily affected included Chivasso, where the confluence with the Orco created a flood wave that caused the collapse of the bridge over the Po during the night between November 5 and 6, and Trino, where the entire town center was submerged, and damage was reported at the former Enrico Fermi nuclear power plant. Other affected or submerged areas included Verolengo, Crescentino, Palazzolo Vercellese, and Morano sul Po.

The affected areas also included those of Canavese; on the Dora Baltea basin, as previously mentioned, the flood was over 3000 m³/s. The Mazzè power plant and the Depretis Canal intake in Villareggia were severely affected, causing damage to the structure.

Whole_Text.content: The 2010 Veneto flood occurred as a result of a strong Atlantic disturbance that brought persistent rains to the region starting from October 31, 2010. Added to this was the warm sirocco wind which, in addition to melting the snow that had fallen on the mountains in the previous weeks, prevented the normal outflow of rivers into the Adriatic Sea.

The flood affected 130 municipalities in Veneto across all provinces and flooded 140 km² of territory; the most affected areas were those of Vicenza and its province, the province of Padua, and the province of Verona. The heavy rains caused the rivers Timonchio, Bacchiglione, Retrone, Alpone, Tramigna, and Frassine to overflow. In the provinces of Treviso and Belluno, there were numerous landslides. The number of people affected was 500,000. In the province of Padua alone, 4,500 people were displaced, and in the Vicenza area, two people died.

20% of the city of Vicenza was flooded by the waters of the Bacchiglione and Retrone rivers. The first river overflowed in the early hours of the morning on November 1st, affecting the area around the old Araceli church and Viale Rumor, along with the nearby Querini Park, which was turned into a swamp. Consequently, the provincial headquarters of the Red Cross and UNICEF located in Contrà Torretti were evacuated. At 7:30 AM, the Bacchiglione also overflowed at Ponte degli Angeli, blocking northern and eastern access to the historic center; however, the Olympic Theatre was spared thanks to the activation of three water pumps (in addition to the two always present in the famous Palladian structure). Water also invaded Contrà San Pietro, Corso Padova, Via IV Novembre, the riverside Contrà areas of San Biagio/San Marco, and the Stadio Menti area. The Bacchiglione also overflowed at the Viale Diaz bridge, blocking traffic on one of the main arteries of the outer ring road, flooding the San Paolo district (sports hall, swimming pools, athletics field) and the Carmini area, along with the northern part of Corso Fogazzaro. The Santa Bertilla area (customs and fruit and vegetable market) was also flooded, as was the Viale Trento area. In the afternoon, the Retrone overflowed in the S. Agostino district, and all ground-floor residents of the Debba district were evacuated. Traffic in the city was paralyzed: the A4 motorway was closed, as were the South Bypass and all railway lines starting from or passing through the city. Urban bus lines operated by AIM were also affected, with some routes canceled due to the inability to transit through city streets. Twenty-one electrical cabins were submerged, leaving over 3,000 users without power. These are the flood data: As soon as the waters receded, Mayor Achille Variati issued a call for volunteers who could help the city and its residents return to normalcy. The following day, more than 200 people showed up to assist, first helping AIM Valore Ambiente workers clean the streets and then aiding citizens. Within four days, the number of volunteers reached 2,483, who, in three daily shifts meeting in Piazza Matteotti, were dispatched to the city's most critical points. On November 3rd, almost all schools reopened, and the usual Thursday city market was confirmed; on the same day, Guido Bertolaso arrived in Vicenza, declared a state of emergency, and brought the army to the city. Bertolaso's visit was followed by those of Silvio Berlusconi and Umberto Bossi on November 9th. On November 11th, the President of the Italian Republic, Giorgio Napolitano, arrived in the Berico capital at the explicit invitation of the mayor. The President first visited Piazza Matteotti (where volunteers awaited him and presented him with a personalized vest) and then the town hall. "You have shown that it is not true that you wait for state aid, that you do not ask but act, that you have understood how, in a moment like this, cleaning is a noble job. No one was ashamed to get their hands dirty in the mud and use a broom" (Giorgio Napolitano in his speech to volunteers during his visit to the city on November 11th). Following the flood, 46 Vicenza artists (including Los Locos, Stefano Centomo, and Lost) came together in the style of "Artists United for Abruzzo," recording the song "Un cuore grande così," with proceeds going to flood victims.

The city found itself managing new flood alarms on November 16, December 23, 2010, March 16, 2011, November 11, 2012, and May 16, 2013. In all five cases, the municipal emergency plan was activated, which includes advising (through the loudspeakers of local police patrols) to secure belongings and cars located on lower floors, positioning pallets of sandbags ready or to be prepared at 11 strategic points in the city, and speeding up any flood prevention work through technical supplies of AIM Vicenza and Valore Città vehicles by patrols of various public safety entities. On November 16, 2010 (given the critical situation just 15 days earlier), volunteers were called in to prepare sandbags, and precautionary evacuation of some schools affected by flooding on November 1 was carried out. On December 24, 2010, given the imminent Christmas holidays, the municipality turned to the American army stationed at the Ederle barracks, as it did on March 16, 2011 (when the unification of Italy was being celebrated). Fortunately, all alarms subsided fairly quickly, with flooding limited to the areas "historically" more vulnerable.

In the Vicenza area, the Bacchiglione River overflowed in several places, although the most difficult situation was recorded in the outskirts of Vicenza, particularly in Caldogno in the districts of Rettorgole and especially Cresole, which was completely submerged and where the first victim was recorded (a man who drowned in his home garage). In Valli del Pasubio, Torrebelvicino, and Recoaro Terme, several landslides forced the evacuation of about forty families. Numerous landslides occurred in the Chiampo Valley.

In the Padua area, the Bacchiglione river broke near the Ponte San Nicolò landfill, flooding not only the Roncajette district of Ponte San Nicolò but also the municipalities of Casalserugo, Bovolenta, and Maserà in the Pratiarcati area in the Bertipaglia district. The Frassine also overflowed, causing numerous floods. On the night between November 1 and 2, 2010, in Veggiano, the Tesina Padovano broke the right bank before its confluence with the Bacchiglione, just after the Fratta pump station, flooding much of the municipal territory during the day of November 2, 2010.

The force of the waters flattened 40 meters of the embankment (which was only partially patched up days later with cyclopean boulders brought in by helicopter), forcing 880 people to evacuate. Also in the territory of the municipality of Veggiano, the Tesinella (which originates from the municipality of Grisignano di Zocco) overflowed, and numerous springs opened along the banks of other tributaries (Ceresone). For over a week, water levels exceeded one and a half meters, with peaks over two meters in the lowest areas. One of the areas most affected by the flood was the Bassa Padovana, where 22% of the territory was submerged. The embankment of the Frassine river suddenly gave way in the locality of Prà di Botte (a collapse of 150 meters of embankment wall), flooding the municipal territories of Megliadino San Fidenzio, Saletto, Montagnana, Ospedaletto Euganeo, and Este; 23 million cubic meters of water poured into the area. A couple of hours after the disaster, another drainage channel, the Vampadore, overflowed, flooding Megliadino San Vitale and Casale di Scodosia. Subsequently, the municipalities of Carceri and Vighizzolo d'Este were also invaded by the waters of the Brancaglia canal (albeit to a much lesser extent).

The landfill present in Este was immediately closed as water managed to enter the facilities. During the flood period, a vast lake several kilometers long and wide could be observed from the Euganean Hills. On November 17 and 18, there were new floods, particularly of the Bacchiglione river, which especially flooded Bovolenta. The same occurred on December 25, again in Bovolenta.

In the Veronese area, the two municipalities most affected were Monteforte d'Alpone and Soave. The water overflowing from the Alpone stream led to the closure of the A4 highway. On the morning of November 1, 2010, after the breach of the Alpone stream's embankment in San Bonifacio (at the point where the Chiampo flows into the Alpone), the waters flooded the entire southern part of Monteforte d'Alpone, reaching nearly two meters in height on some streets. In Monteforte, 6 million cubic meters of water and mud poured in, causing damage to 759 private properties, 146 businesses, and 25 farms. On the morning of November 1, 2010, the water from the Tramigna stream, a tributary of the Alpone, broke its embankment and began overflowing in Soave. Part of the area within the medieval walls and the entire external area extending to the middle school were flooded by water, which flowed back from the Alpone along the Tramigna. With this flood in Soave, approximately 600 private properties, 120 businesses, and 22 farms suffered damage. Numerous landslides occurred in Malcesine on Lake Garda, where one particularly threatened the inhabited area.

The contribution of Civil Protection volunteers was fundamental for the quick resolution of the emergency. Approximately 6,801 volunteers registered in the regional register of Volunteer Organizations operated in their respective provinces. A significant contribution also came from mobile units of other Italian regions that intervened to assist Veneto, coordinated by the Civil Protection Department.

Article_Name: Alluvione della Maremma grossetana del novembre 2012

Whole_Text.header: Flood of the Maremma Grossetana in November 2012
Whole_Text.content: The flood of the Maremma Grossetana in November 2012 was a severe calamity that affected the central-southern part of the province of Grosseto on November 12, 2012, causing the loss of 6 human lives: one due to the overflow of the Chiarone River, one due to the overflow of a canal near Lake Burano in the vicinity of Capalbio, and the other three due to the collapse of a bridge over the Albegna River near Marsiliana, in addition to two people gravely injured, one of whom died on December 30 of the same year. Due to the overflow of various watercourses, flooding and extensive damage occurred in the countryside between the basins of the Ombrone, Albegna, Fiora, Nestore, and Paglia rivers and in the town of Albinia in the municipality of Orbetello, a hamlet that was completely flooded with about 150 displaced people due to the overflow of the Albegna River, out of a total of about 700 displaced people throughout the province. Cultural heritage was also affected, with the collapse of a Renaissance bastion and a section of the walls of Magliano in Toscana. Numerous infrastructures were rendered unusable, including State Road 1 Via Aurelia and the Tyrrhenian Railway (reopened in the afternoon of November 16, 2012), which were interrupted near Albinia, as well as numerous local roads, following the severe damage caused by the disastrous effects of the bad weather. In Grosseto, a record flood of the Ombrone River was recorded, remaining in the floodplain for three days, lasting longer than the one in 1966 but without major damage in the city, despite panic in the hamlet of Istia d'Ombrone where water reached some houses near the bridge; the hamlets of Rispescia and Alberese were also isolated for two days. At the provincial level, the event is comparable to the Grosseto flood of November 4, 1966, with the difference that the 2012 event hit the southern sector of the province harder, while the 1966 event caused the most damage along the Ombrone Valley in the central-northern part of the provincial territory. Intense rainfall also affected the Monte Amiata area, including the Sienese side, as well as a vast area of Lazio and Umbria straddling the Lazio Maremma, Tuscia, and Orvietano, where exceptional floods occurred, with consequent overflows of some right tributaries of the Tiber, including the Nestore, with 1000 m³/sec at Marsciano, submerged by the overflow with extensive damage, and especially the Paglia, its main right tributary, which with an extraordinary flood of 1,500 m³/sec completely submerged the lower part of the municipality of Orvieto, causing extensive damage.

On the morning of November 11, 2012, the Regional Hydrological Service of Tuscany issued a maximum-level criticality warning valid until midnight on November 12, 2012, for various areas of central-southern Tuscany, including the Ombrone Valley, the Val d'Orcia, the valleys of the Bruna, Albegna, and Fiora rivers, areas later affected by the tragic flood event, as well as other areas such as the islands of the Tuscan Archipelago, the Valtiberina, the Casentino, the Upper Valdarno, the Valdichiana, the Cecina River valley, and the Val di Cornia. Given the high level of the issued alert, which anticipated the risk of accumulations exceeding 250 mm in 24 hours in the affected areas, the Province of Grosseto requested individual municipalities to adopt all preventive measures to address the situation and to adequately inform the population about the risks associated with the anticipated event.

Whole_Text.header: Genesis and evolution of the event
Whole_Text.content:
On November 10, 2012, a complex system of low pressure and disturbances formed between the Atlantic Ocean and Spain, moving rapidly towards the western Mediterranean and beginning to affect northwestern Italy, causing rather heavy rainfall in Liguria during the second part of the day.  
At the same time, an extensive high-pressure field was strengthening over the Balkans, acting as a block for the eastward movement of the disturbances, thereby reinforcing the warm and humid sirocco wind drawn towards Italy by the low pressure present in the western Mediterranean. Consequently, in the evening, the disturbance intensified, fueled by the sirocco, generating strong thunderstorms during the night hours between Versilia, Garfagnana, Lunigiana, and the Pisa coastline, reaching the city of Livorno, all areas where rainfall accumulations between 100 and 250 millimeters were recorded within a few hours.  
Between the morning and early afternoon of Sunday, November 11, 2012, cooler and drier air arriving from the Atlantic managed to invade Tuscany for a few hours, bringing a temporary and relative improvement in the weather; however, the blocking action of the high pressure over the Balkans, opposing the now deep low pressure in the western Mediterranean, sustained a strong and humid sirocco wind between the Strait of Sicily and the southern Tyrrhenian Sea.  
By late afternoon, the sirocco once again reached southern Tuscany through a warm front that—due to the relative positions of low and high pressures near Italy and the presence of a jet stream at high altitude aligned with the front—remained stationary in the area for about 30 hours.  
Along the warm front, a very intense mesoscale linear convective system developed, a particularly extensive thunderstorm that brought heavy rainfall and downpours between the Maremma region of Grosseto, parts of the provinces of Siena and Viterbo, and the Tyrrhenian Umbria. The thunderstorm continuously regenerated its structure from 6:00 PM on Sunday, November 11, until 11:00 PM on Monday, November 12, 2012, when the bad weather rapidly subsided. The improvement in weather was facilitated by the formation of a new low-pressure system over Morocco, which redirected the humid air driven by the sirocco away from Tuscany and towards Sardinia (initially) and the Balearic Islands (later).

In terms of rainfall, numerous stations of the Regional Hydrological Service of Tuscany recorded record rainfall accumulations, never previously recorded in their respective historical series, even surpassing the peaks of November 1966; at the same time, some rain gauges, including those of Orbetello-San Donato and Magliano in Toscana-Poggio Perotto, recorded in just 24 hours between the evening of November 11 and the evening of November 12, 2012, precipitation accumulations exceeding half of the total annual average rainfall (part of the area most affected by the intense phenomena has historical annual rainfall averages between 500 and 600 mm). Below are some rainfall records registered during the flood event by some stations of the Regional Hydrological Service of Tuscany: In addition to the aforementioned daily rainfall records, following the precipitation of November 12, 2012, various rain gauges in the affected area recorded new monthly total rainfall records with 18 days still available to further increase the record: among them are the hydrological stations of Abbadia San Salvatore and Piancastagnaio in the province of Siena, on the slope of Mount Amiata from which the Paglia River valley originates, as well as the already mentioned rain gauges of Orbetello-San Donato, Scansano-Pomonte, and Roccalbegna-Usi, and the hydrological stations of Magliano in Toscana-Poggio Perotto, Manciano, Marsiliana, Manciano-Capanne, Pitigliano in the Tufo Area, and Santa Fiora on the Grosseto side of Amiata; other stations nonetheless reached precipitation accumulations between November 1 and 12, 2012, close to the historical monthly record, which could be surpassed by the end of the month in case of further rainfall. We also report the data recorded in the immediate vicinity of the Grosseto borders, for example, the two meteorological stations related to Acquapendente (VT) managed by MeteoAquesio. The first, located at an altitude of 340 meters above sea level (locality Fornace), recorded an accumulation of 256 mm in just under 40 hours. The second, located at an altitude of 734 meters above sea level (located within the Monte Rufeno Nature Reserve), recorded a rainfall accumulation of 465 mm in just under 40 hours. This latter station was, for several hours, right in the most active part of the trajectory of the self-regenerating thunderstorm, recording a record accumulation accompanied by very high rain rate values.

The Public Prosecutor's Office at the Court of Grosseto has launched investigations to shed light on all criminal responsibilities, opening four separate files following the flood event that affected a large part of the provincial territory[21].

Whole_Text.content: The Versilia flood was a severe flooding event that affected part of the historic region of Versilia in Tuscany on June 19, 1996, following a particularly violent thunderstorm phenomenon occurring during the transition between spring and summer.

On the morning of June 19, 1996, the sky over Versilia was clear; however, that day, a clash of cold air from northern Italy with warm, humid air from the coast was taking place over the crests of the Apuan Alps, causing a very rapid meteorological evolution. This favored the formation of an apparently modest storm cell, 12 km high and about half as wide, heavily loaded with precipitation (convective storm). Extremely violent downpours broke out starting early in the morning over the Apuan Alps, affecting the entire upper basin of the Serra and Vezza streams (the latter converging into a single watercourse at Seravezza, the Versilia) on the western watershed, and the entire upper basin of the Turrite di Gallicano stream on the eastern watershed. The precipitation also affected part of the Camaiore river basin. All this occurred while only a few drops of rain fell on the Versilia plain. In a short time, the extraordinary rainfall (with peaks of over 150 mm in an hour in the upper Vezza basin) caused several landslides, and the watercourses swelled rapidly. Following a brief pause in late morning, the rains resumed even more intensely throughout the day, from noon until early afternoon, culminating in a deluge. Torrential rains shook the mountains and ravines near the village of Cardoso, where various smaller streams converge near the settlement to form the Vezza stream. Meanwhile, in the plain, no one could remotely predict what was happening: in the Pietrasanta area, near the short stretch of plain of the Versilia river, only 5–10 mm of rain had fallen. Civil protection was activated, taking care around 2:00 PM to check the rainfall values in the Apuan Alps, discovering that one of the hydrometers at the Pomezzana center in the upper Vezza valley recorded a record cumulative rainfall value, with 440 mm in just 8 hours and a peak of 157 mm in one hour. Fearing the possibility of a sudden flood wave, river levels were immediately checked, especially the Versilia, which, upon initial observation, appeared to be deceptively receding after the large flood wave of the morning.

Around 1:00 PM in the upper valley, the Vezza stream (upper section of the Versilia River) began its devastating course downstream near the center of Cardoso: here, according to eyewitnesses, numerous booms were first heard coming from the mountains, followed by repeated waves of water, mud, and debris up to 4-5 meters high coming from the ravines of the streams converging near the village, which was almost completely overwhelmed and destroyed. The sudden speed and violence of the event were explained by the fact that, since the morning, the heavy rains, combined with the drought that had afflicted the area for months, had further weakened the already unstable slopes of the Apuan Alps, causing massive landslides of earth, debris, and logs that had temporarily blocked all the valleys of the watercourses upstream of Cardoso, which feed the Vezza stream. Several ephemeral water basins were thus created, which all collapsed together in the early afternoon under the relentless rainfall, resulting in a catastrophic flood wave. Among the people who lost their lives was young Alessio Ricci, after whom the elementary school on Via Pontenuovo in Pietrasanta has been named since 2020: he was only 8 years old when he was swept away by the river's flood. After devastating Cardoso, the flood continued along the Vezza stream, first hitting the center of Ponte Stazzemese (where it reached the second floor of houses, partially collapsing an entire hotel) and then reaching Ruosina, where it submerged the entire village, almost completely erasing the valley floor road. Additional water inflows reached the Vezza from every lateral valley, further feeding its flood. Around 3:00 PM, the flood furiously reached the town of Seravezza, which was largely submerged by 2-3 meters of water; in this section, the Vezza stream also received the floodwaters of its main tributary, the Serra stream, from the right. From this confluence onward, it changed its name to the "Versilia River" and continued impetuously, overflowing with debris downstream, literally overwhelming the only hydrometer along its river course (which recorded a value of 4.50 meters above zero). Therefore, no other data on the maximum flood height is known, except for the peak flow rate, estimated after the event at about 571 m³/s, an absolutely exceptional and uncontainable value for a modest river like the Versilia. After Seravezza, the Versilia River overtopped and destroyed all the bridges near the centers of Ripa, Corvaia, and Vallecchia, leaving its valley section and finding an outlet in the Versilia plain. In this section, the river (channeled and diverted into an artificial bed centuries ago, which flows near Cinquale di Montignoso) literally overflowed near the locality of San Bartolomeo in Pietrasanta due to the overtopping and subsequent collapse of a large section of its left bank, creating a new course to the south, following the ancient path of its old riverbed, thus causing extensive flooding of the entire western portion of the municipality of Pietrasanta up to the Marina di Pietrasanta, Forte dei Marmi, and part of the municipality of Montignoso. Meanwhile, the tragedy also struck the eastern side of the Apuan Alps in Garfagnana: in the upper valley of the Turrite stream, the center of Fornovolasco was literally devastated by the flood of the watercourse. Further downstream, however, the damage was minimal thanks to the presence of an artificial lake on the watercourse, which, being completely empty for maintenance, was able to absorb much of the flood's force, saving the downstream center of Gallicano. Around 6:00 PM, the rain gauges in Pomezzana and Retignano, in Alta Versilia, showed cumulative precipitation values of 478 and 401 mm in 13 hours, respectively. The one in Fornovolasco, in Garfagnana, recorded 408 mm. This tragedy, considered one of the worst floods ever to hit Tuscany after the Florence flood of 1966, also caused a high number of casualties: by the end of the emergency, 13 deaths, almost all in Cardoso, and one missing person were counted.
The technician Marco Fornaciari (41 years old) died during an inspection of the areas affected by the flood.

Article_Name: Alluvione dello Spezzino e della Lunigiana del 25 ottobre 2011

Whole_Text.header: Flood of the Spezzino and Lunigiana on October 25, 2011
Whole_Text.content: The flood of the Spezzino and Lunigiana on October 25, 2011, occurred following heavy rainfall that poured 542 mm of rain in six hours on the provinces of La Spezia and Massa and Carrara. This meteorological event caused the overflow of the Vara and Magra rivers and their tributary streams in the affected areas, with flooding of varying degrees throughout the Val di Vara and Val di Magra. The most affected towns were Borghetto di Vara, Brugnato, Bonassola, Levanto, Monterosso al Mare, Vernazza in the province of La Spezia, and Aulla in the province of Massa-Carrara. This event was followed, a few days later, by the Genoa flood of November 4, 2011, also caused by very heavy rainfall (Mediterranean low Rolf) that recorded peaks exceeding 500 mm in a few hours in various areas of Genoa and its province, causing the overflow of the Bisagno and Fereggiano streams and the flooding of the Sturla, Scrivia, and Entella streams, resulting in 6 deaths.

In the early morning of October 25, 2011, a weather disturbance began to concentrate in the northern area of the provinces of La Spezia and Massa and Carrara. Within a few hours, an enormous amount of rain fell. In a very short time, the tributary streams of the main rivers became uncontrollable and overflowed, carrying all sorts of debris downstream. The flood wave effect spread to the major rivers, Vara and Magra, which overflowed into the plains around the villages of Borghetto di Vara, Brugnato, Ameglia, Pontremoli, Villafranca in Lunigiana, and Aulla. The disaster also struck the nearby Cinque Terre in the province of La Spezia: water carried huge amounts of mud and debris along the natural drainage channels in the villages of Vernazza and Monterosso, and the main streets turned into raging rivers, dragging everything into the sea. The resulting flood deposit on the main street of Vernazza measured several meters thick. Communications immediately became very difficult: there was also significant damage to road infrastructure with landslides and collapses on several provincial roads (resulting in the isolation of some inland locations), closure of the A12 highway section between the Sestri Levante and Deiva Marina toll booths due to a landslide on the southbound lane, and disruptions on the Levante railway line. On the A12, the landslide involved a truck, and rescuers managed to extract the driver, who was miraculously saved. The state road 1 Via Aurelia was interrupted by multiple landslides, and the railway was blocked by a landslide in Vernazza. Dozens of villages in the Val di Vara became unreachable except by helicopter, and telecommunications were interrupted. Further south in the reference river basin, the effects of the flood occurred in the municipality of Ameglia, at the mouth of the Magra River: in three years, this was the fourth flood, and this time the most significant damage (in addition to houses completely invaded by mud) was suffered by the Colombiera bridge, which collapsed for the second time. A yacht was unmoored by the river's fury and struck the central span of the bridge, destroying it. Over a week after the flood event, in anticipation of a new and maximum weather alert throughout the region (classified as "Alert 2" by the meteorological-hydrological functional center of the Liguria Region Civil Protection, forecasted from 10 PM on November 3 to 6 PM on November 6 in the Ligurian maritime basins of Ponente, Centro, Levante, and Padani di Ponente), evacuation orders were issued by the respective mayors of Vernazza and Borghetto di Vara as a precautionary measure. In Val di Vara, landslides continued for days, blocking road communications. On November 5, Camisano (Ameglia) and Pignone were evacuated, Corvara and Bracelli (in the municipality of Beverino) were reported as isolated, and new evacuations occurred in Calice al Cornoviglio, where roads had now opened into frightening chasms. In ten days, four bridges collapsed, and 20 roads were closed between Montemarcello, Rocchetta di Vara, Brugnato, Calice, Pignone, Beverino, Corniglia, Monterosso, and Vernazza.
Main towns affected by the flood.
Other municipalities affected, albeit with less intensity, had to deal with landslides and flooding of watercourses.

One of the factors of exasperation for the affected citizens is the recurrence of these events in the area: the flood of October 25, 2011, marks the peak of three catastrophic years, where every rainfall above average intensity results in incalculable disasters between floods and landslides. After the 1960s, the riverbanks were raised twice, reaching a total height of 5 meters, through the application of two layers of unreinforced concrete that were not statically connected to each other. The foundations of the riverbanks were reinforced with the insertion of a protective layer of rocks.

From the beginning, the exceptional nature of the climatic variable is evident, but the disastrous effects raise many questions about the hydrogeological structure of the Spezzino territory, already heavily affected in previous years.  
The combined effect of global warming and recent changes in land use has led to an increased flood risk, worsened by the growing likelihood of highly intense events. The recent cases of floods in Liguria confirm that this circumstance occurs in Mediterranean environments, but not only, of the Italian peninsula.

The significant abandonment of crops, the neglect of undergrowth, the disease of non-native plants, have been the causes of aggravating factors of the climatic situation, causing a decrease in the geotechnical resistance of the land, the formation of organic and inorganic debris material, and blockages in water regulation systems.

The Magra Basin Authority had foreseen everything, declaring the flood levels in the Hydrogeological Structure Plan (PAI) or Basin Plan, approved in 2003; however, in the flooded areas, there were constructions erected from the 1950s onwards. In Monterosso al Mare and Vernazza, the focus of controversy is the covering of canals, which, with the rainfall, became pressurized. Even in the Cinque Terre, cementification is not ruled out as a cause of the lack of water regulation: in Monterosso, the council allowed the construction of 30 villas in the Meschi area. 

In Brugnato, the Friday before the tragedy, the municipal council voted to approve the construction of a massive outlet that was supposed to be built right in the plain devastated by the flood. The outlet was then regularly built and inaugurated in 2014. The method of cementification of the territory is also under discussion in Aulla, where much of the construction over the past fifty years has been built within the natural riverbed of the Magra River. At the beginning of the flood wave that invaded the town's streets, it seems there was a collapse of the containment basin dam to the north, near Villafranca in Lunigiana. In the days following October 25, institutional authorities visiting Aulla were heavily contested by the locals, including the mayor of Pontremoli, Lucia Baracchini, and Minister Altero Matteoli.

The floods of the Vara and the estuarine part of the Magra represent another controversy: public opinion points to the lack of dredging of riverbeds, regulated by Law 183/1989, which classifies the extraction of inert materials along rivers among soil defense interventions, thus establishing, in principle, the public interest in proper hydraulic maintenance as the sole act allowing extractive activities in rivers. As a result, pending the adoption of Basin Plans, extractive activity has been suspended. According to popular beliefs, the rivers would be overloaded with sedimentation material; however, there is a study commissioned by the Interregional Basin Authority of the Magra River, developed by the Faculty of Civil Engineering of the University of Florence, which states that the valley sections of the rivers have not increased sediment levels; on the contrary, they are eroded. Another important point seems to be the lack of maintenance of secondary waterways and tributaries of the Vara and Magra rivers. According to some testimonies, in the municipality of Follo, affected by the flood in the plain, it seems that the water did not come directly from the riverbed but rather from the inability of tributary streams to flow into it. This would have caused damage to culverts (some literally exploded), and their overflow would have flooded buildings located in an area classified by the PAI as flood-prone.

The causes of the flood events have been the subject of legal proceedings: Subsequently, the construction works of a multi-story parking lot in Monterosso were suspended, and the site was seized by the Spezia prosecutor's office[23].

The case of the Brugnato outlet flared up in the weeks following the disaster, dividing public opinion between supporters of the project, which would guarantee the economic revival of the area, and opponents, due to the danger of the area and the failing economic model it would support. The Liguria region issued a resolution, called "safeguard," which halts construction in areas affected by the flood, pending safety checks. This measure follows a similar one by the Tuscany region. In fact, this decision freezes the outlet project. However, the outlet is not the only point of contention; in Monterosso, controversy erupted over the mayor's decision to continue work on a multi-story parking lot. The outlet was then regularly built and inaugurated on April 10, 2014.

From the day of the disaster to November 9, 2011, 10 people were reported dead (7 in Borghetto di Vara, 2 in Aulla, and 1 in Monterosso) and 3 missing (in Vernazza): Sauro Picconcelli (50 years old), Pino Giannoni (70), and Giuseppina Carro (80). On November 10, the identity of a body found off the coast of Saint Tropez was confirmed to be Sauro Picconcelli. On November 11, a second body found off the coast of France was identified as Pino Giannoni: the toll was 12 victims and 1 missing. On December 16, DNA testing confirmed that the three bodies found in France were those of Pino Giannoni, Sauro Picconcelli, and Pina Carro: the final toll was 13 victims. The victim from Monterosso, Sandro Usai, was swept away by the wave of mud while trying to save some people from the river's flood. In recognition of his act, the President of the Republic, Giorgio Napolitano, will present his widow with the Gold Medal for Civil Valor in his memory.

Following the event, the A12 and the La Spezia-Genoa railway were closed, and 43% of provincial roads were declared impassable. A total of 1,183 people were evacuated: 238 in Monterosso, 150 in Vernazza (all transferred to Levanto), 196 in Borghetto, 199 in Brugnato, 25 in Sesta Godano, 27 in Pignone, 152 in Beverino, 75 in Rocchetta Vara, 18 in Ameglia, plus 49 in Bocca di Magra, 34 in Arcola, and 22 in Calice al Cornoviglio. The economic damages were initially estimated at around 1.5 billion euros. 

On November 19, 2011, it was announced that 947 applications had been filed, reporting total damages of 116,213,535 euros. These reports were later supplemented by applications received in the following days due to the extension to November 30 and those from agricultural businesses submitted to the Agricultural Inspectorate. For the most urgent funds, i.e., for immediate interventions, Vernazza allocated 50.9 million, Monterosso 35 million, Brugnato 17.9 million, Borghetto 12.9 million, Sesta Godano 4.1 million, Beverino 6 million, Calice 4.1 million, and Ameglia 2.1 million. A total of twenty-five municipalities submitted damage reports to the commissioner. The province's soil defense and road network reported damages amounting to 47.5 million. 

As of December 20, 2011, 1,481 businesses in the La Spezia area requested aid for damages caused by the flood, including 269 agricultural businesses, with a total compensation of 169 million euros; 203 requests came from Monterosso, 145 from Brugnato, 109 from Vernazza, and 80 from Borghetto. To address the damages caused by the flood, the Berlusconi government increased fuel excise taxes by 0.0089%. 

To fund the flood relief fund, the Liguria Region also decided to increase gasoline excise taxes (+0.5 cents), a measure mandated by the previous government, which, at the initiative of Minister Giulio Tremonti, requested Liguria and Tuscany to raise taxes to support the 40 million allocated for damages.

Thousands of volunteers mobilized to help the affected population. Many of them responded to appeals launched on social networks like Facebook: students, workers, spiritual heirs of those "mud angels" of Florence. A particular case was that of the "red bands," nearly 400 volunteers from all over Italy (Como, Naples, Pavia, Trento, Parma, Rome, Livorno, etc.) who are identified by a red band on their arm. The idea reproduces an ancient custom of the Lunigiana workers' movement, which, in a late 19th-century photo, depicted workers' teams from Pontremolese with red bands around their waists and arms. Particular attention was paid, from the beginning, to the nature of the aid, especially financial. An example is the Monterosso case, where a fundraising campaign was launched by Repubblica and Sky for the "rescue" of the "Enrico Fermi" elementary school, but some testimonies revealed that the school building had not suffered significant damage to prevent its use. The question arises as to what the school will be saved from. A year after that tragedy, the first assessments began on the reconstruction and securing of the Spezzino territory. For example, according to some sources, the media and top authorities portrayed the reconstruction of Vernazza as a virtuous example. However, some citizens drafted a dossier showing that the situation is far from virtuous. 

In general, the commitment to safeguarding the territory does not appear particularly significant, with emergency works, a lack of planning interventions, and continuous issuance of building permits for large, highly invasive projects. A shocking example is the collapse of a landslide on the Via dell'Amore in Riomaggiore, following just a few hours of rain.

Article_Name: Alluvione di Campi Bisenzio del 15 novembre 1991

Whole_Text.header: Flood of Campi Bisenzio on November 15, 1991
Whole_Text.content: The flood of November 15, 1991, in Campi Bisenzio, caused by the breaking of the Bisenzio River's banks, was the third major flood to hit the Tuscan town in the 20th century, after those of 1926 and 1966. Unlike the previous ones, this flood did not affect the outlying districts or neighborhoods but the town center and was not an unforeseen event. The alarm had already been raised in the early afternoon of November 15, and the situation became serious around 8 p.m., when the level of the Bisenzio became truly concerning, leading to the decision to close the historic bridge in the town center. Around 10 p.m., the waters of the Bisenzio overflowed into the Santa Maria neighborhood, passing through the houses along the bank, but about twenty minutes later, the Bisenzio broke the embankment-road on the opposite side, in the area of the Corti district, and the flooding of the town center began. The waters inundated a large part of the town center, particularly the districts of Corti and Case Nove and the area of the Central Post Office, reaching the areas of Maccione and Via Palagetta. The only victim of the flood was an 83-year-old woman, Dina Nistri, residing in the Corti area, not far from the breach, who was swept away by the waters in her garden. The damages from the flood, which later sparked a fierce controversy, were estimated at 144 billion lire of the time. From that November 1991, hydraulic restoration and the care of the territory's waterways would become one of the top priorities of the various municipal administrations.

Article_Name: Alluvione di Campi Bisenzio del 22 novembre 1926

Whole_Text.header: Flood of Campi Bisenzio on November 22, 1926
Whole_Text.content: The flood of November 22, 1926, was the first of three major floods that struck the municipality of Campi Bisenzio in the 20th century and was caused by the breaking of the banks of the Bisenzio River, the Ombrone Pistoiese, and the Marinella stream. The Bisenzio flood unexpectedly reached the town center late in the evening of November 21, when the river level became alarming, and shortly after, the waters began to overflow into the city streets through the windows of houses along the river. The fate of the municipal capital seemed sealed when the Bisenzio broke its bank at the curve of Via XXIV Maggio near the first houses of the San Martino district. The breach was about fifty meters long, and through it, the river's waters poured into San Martino itself, then reaching San Piero a Ponti and the plain of Sant'Angelo a Lecore, where in the meantime, the Ombrone Pistoiese had also broken its banks. In some areas, the waters reached a level of two meters. At the same time, the Bisenzio and the Marinella stream also broke their banks near the Capalle district, and their waters reached the level of the first floor of houses. The only victim of the flood was a forty-year-old farmer from San Piero a Ponti, Emilio Scuffi, who suffered a heart attack at the sight of the waters flooding his home. The rescue efforts were quite ineffective, although the now-dominant Fascist regime did not allow protests or excessive demands, partly due to the absolute unpreparedness of the municipal administration, which in previous years had even sold two boats purchased for potential emergencies because they had never been used. The flood damage was extensive, and there were no reimbursements, although the repair of the banks by the Civil Engineering Corps was swift and effective. The pedestrian bridge in San Martino, which collapsed, was permanently restored only in 1939. The poor organization of the rescue efforts was ultimately fatal to the last mayor, Emilio Cioppi, who in the following months was replaced by a government-appointed podestà.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Crotone on October 14, 1996, was a disaster caused by a surge of the Esaro stream, resulting in the flooding of a large area of the city of Crotone, especially near its industrial area, which caused the death of 6 people, thousands of displaced individuals, and damage to 358 businesses amounting to 126 billion lire in 1996.

On October 14, 1996, the city of Crotone, on the Ionian side of Calabria, experienced a violent flood following heavy rainfall that added to the already significant rains that had affected the province the previous week, saturating the land and causing overflows and flooding of several watercourses in the area, including the Passovecchio stream and the Esaro River. In the morning, approximately 120 mm of rain fell specifically on the basin of the latter (bringing the total for the week to 330 mm), which further fed all the tributaries of the Esaro coming from the Cutro area. In the locality of "Isola Capo Rizzuto station," an uncontrollable and violent flood of the same river formed (later calculated with a flow rate of over 1000 m³/s). The flood reached the "Gabelluccia" district, on the western outskirts of Crotone, around noon: a mass of water and mud submerged the ground floors of the neighborhood's houses, subsequently spreading toward the industrial area, affecting both the buildings on the left bank, already flooded earlier due to the overflow of the Papaniciaro tributary, and those on the right bank, near the "Gesù" district. The water then also reached the historic city center, channeling along Via Nicoletta. The flood caused six fatalities (Paolo Pupa, Angela Trovato, Luca Buscema, Michela Cicchetto, Luca Tavano, and Bruno Comisso) and enormous damage: numerous industrial prefabricated buildings were swept away by the water, and the city's commercial and industrial area was heavily devastated. In some streets of the town center, the water even reached four meters in height. 

The effects of the overflow were further exacerbated by extensive illegal construction: the Gabelluccia and Gesù districts, the latter built near the Montecatini plant, had in fact developed in the 1980s in the river's flood expansion areas. Almost all the bridges were destroyed. A total of 358 businesses were affected, with damages amounting to 126 billion lire in 1996.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Genoa on October 7, 1970, which continued on October 8, occurred as a result of very heavy rainfall. This led to the overflow of the Bisagno, Fereggiano, and Leira streams and the flooding of the Sturla, Polcevera, Chiaravagna, and Cantarena streams. Very intense and localized rains, typical of the Ligurian coast and the autumn period, accumulated 948 mm of water in 24 hours. The most affected area was Genoa, but severe damage also occurred in 20 other municipalities in the province, with Masone being the hardest hit. The victims were 43, including 35 dead and 8 missing. Over 2,000 people were displaced. On November 4, 2011, a similar event struck essentially the same area, and on October 9 and 10, 2014, an even more violent one occurred. The neighborhoods of Quezzi, Foce, Molassana, San Fruttuoso, Marassi, Brignole, Sestri Ponente, and Voltri were heavily affected.

The events were predominantly due to the heavy rainfall that occurred on October 7 and 8. On the evening of the first day in Voltri, the violent overflow of the Leira stream occurred, resulting in 13 confirmed victims. The rainfall continued, eventually causing the violent overflow of the Bisagno and Fereggiano streams in the afternoon; the overflow of the former, in particular, caused many and countless victims, mainly affecting Marassi and Quezzi (an entire wing of one of the Biscione buildings also collapsed), but the districts of Foce and Brignole were also affected, with the floods amplified by simultaneous storm surges that prevented the water from flowing into the sea. Numerous people were displaced, and there were interruptions to gas, electricity, and water supplies.

Whole_Text.header: The collapse of the Sant'Agata Bridge
Whole_Text.content: Due to the destructive flood of the Bisagno, the ancient Ponte di Sant'Agata, facing the Borgo Incrociati, partially collapsed, remaining with only the central arches, isolated from the two banks of the stream. Built in the Middle Ages, it had been used as a pedestrian crossing until then.
The Genoese singer-songwriter Fabrizio De André dedicated one of his most famous songs, Dolcenera, to the event, included in his last album Anime salve from 1996.

Whole_Text.content: The Grosseto flood of November 4, 1966, was a catastrophic event that affected the city of Grosseto, the surrounding plain, and part of the Ombrone Valley. The causes were the intense rains that also occurred in the preceding days along the Ombrone River basin and its tributary Orcia. This was part of a widespread event of heavy rains that occurred in much of Italy during those days, leading on the same day to similar floods in Florence, Venice and Chioggia, Pisa, and other cities in central-northern Italy. The waters of the Ombrone broke the banks on the morning of November 4, 1966, and overflowed, flooding the countryside and causing significant damage in the Maremma capital, where in some places the water reached three and a half meters in height. The flood was not an overflow but rather a collapse at four points of the Ombrone River's embankment; it was partly caused by the sirocco winds that slowed the outflow to the sea and by the embankment of the bridge on the Aurelia state road, commonly called the Mussolini bridge. There was only one fatality because November 4 was a holiday at the time, and therefore all major activities were halted. To understand the scale of the phenomenon, it should be noted that the average flow rate of the Ombrone River is 25 m³/s, and on that day it exceeded 4000 m³/s. At the Acquisti Farm, in the countryside of Braccagni north of the city, one victim was recorded, the cowboy Santi Quadalti, swept away by the flood while trying to save his herds, awarded the gold medal.

Whole_Text.content: The Palermo flood of 1931 is the last major flood (with loss of human lives) recorded that struck the city of Palermo.

In Palermo, five different floods are documented between the 19th and 20th centuries. In fact, the floods of 1557, 1666, 1689, 1769, 1772, 1778, 1851, 1862, 1907, 1925, and finally the peak flood of 1931 are remembered. From that moment on, no further catastrophes of this magnitude have been recorded.

Between February 20 and 24, 618 mm of rain fell on the city, 395 of which fell during 50 hours of uninterrupted rain between February 21 and 23. The layout of Palermo, a basin located at the base of high mountains, facilitated the rise in water levels, which varied in different parts of the city from 2 meters on Via Roma to 6 meters in Piazza Sant'Onofrio: in fact, the Conca d'Oro is not homogeneous but characterized in several areas by large depressions. Another factor that contributed was the presence, above and below the city level, of four main water flows: the Canale Passo di Rigano, the Papireto, the Kemonia, and the Oreto River; some of these channels were artificially diverted below street level. In addition to the large volume of water, the city was hit by a very strong tramontana wind that destroyed several walls.

The flood caused the death of 10 people and injured 21 others. Several houses and roads were destroyed, many historic buildings suffered severe damage, and the railway line was torn up. Significant damage also occurred in the countryside, where rural homes were swept away. Additionally, the crane used for the construction of the Post Office building was torn down by the strong wind, collapsing onto an adjacent building.

Due to the high water level, the rescue efforts were delayed; boats and temporary bridges were organized to transport to safety the people who had taken refuge on the upper floors of the buildings. The wind also made it difficult to construct floating bridges.

Whole_Text.content: The Salerno flood of October 25-26, 1954, was a severe catastrophe caused by exceptionally heavy rainfall; the tragedy was sometimes worsened in the affected areas by reckless deforestation, which facilitated some extensive and destructive landslides.
The rain began to fall at 1:00 PM with 175mm of water, then towards the evening it increased by 684 times. On October 26, however, it fell 450 times more, reaching 1309mm of water.

The area most affected was the Campania region, from the Amalfi Coast to the city of Salerno, specifically the localities of Vietri sul Mare, Cava de' Tirreni, Salerno, Maiori, Minori, Tramonti.  
The devastation was immense: landslides, sinkholes, collapsed bridges, roads and railways destroyed in multiple points, houses swept away, flooded basements. The damages were estimated to exceed 45 billion lire. The fury of the waters caused extensive landslides, one of which, detaching from the slope of a recently deforested mountain, swept away the village of Molina and a nearby monumental aqueduct bridge called the "Devil's Bridge." The two streams, Bonea and Cavaiola, originating from Cava de' Tirreni, carried such a quantity of debris downstream that they expanded and increased the current beach of Vietri sul Mare, known as Marina. The entire Salerno coastline changed its appearance, advancing in many areas due to the deposit of debris. In Maiori, the upper hamlets, much of the historic center, and some buildings along the Reginna stream were damaged. The stream, obstructed by tree trunks carried downstream by the waters, eroded the foundations of the buildings along its course, causing their facades to collapse.  
Subsequently, the destroyed houses were replaced with modern buildings, which now characterize the center of Maiori.  
In the Town Hall, there is a plaque commemorating and listing the names of the 37 victims of the October 1954 flood.

In total, there were 318 victims (including dead and missing), 250 injured, and about 5,500 homeless.  
In Salerno, there were about a hundred victims and around 100 injured; in Vietri sul Mare, the victims were over 100; in Cava de' Tirreni, 37; in Maiori, 37; in Tramonti, 35.

Article_Name: Alluvione di Sarno e Quindici del 1998

Whole_Text.header: Flood of Sarno and Quindici in 1998
Whole_Text.content: The Sarno and Quindici flood, or Sarno landslide, was a large-scale landslide that, between May 5 and 6, 1998, particularly affected the urban areas of Sarno (SA), Quindici (AV), Siano (SA), Bracigliano (SA), and San Felice a Cancello (CE), causing the death of 161 people. Following these events, the Prefecture of Naples decided to activate an environmental monitoring network, designed and installed by a specialized company, to ensure the monitoring of rainfall and its effects on the evolution of the flood.

The area of the Sarno district, like all the heights surrounding the plain of the same name, consists of two distinctly separate geological domains. The base substrate is composed of limestone rocks, above which the various historical eruptions of Vesuvius have deposited successive layers of pyroclasts. These two domains are well differentiated and described by numerous geological surveys conducted in both historical and recent times. They constitute two sets with different densities, with compact limestone and the layers of pyroclasts being looser and more incoherent. These two layers were held together by natural vegetation and also by terraced farming practices. The abandonment of the latter has allowed the slopes to be invaded by ruderal vegetation, which has often been burned and does not, in fact, ensure the same continuity between limestone and pyroclasts.

In May 1998, the Sarno district area was hit by an exceptional rainfall event, with over 240/300 millimeters of rain falling within 72 hours. This event caused the dissolution of the continuity between limestone and pyroclasts, leading to the catastrophic sliding of the latter over the former. On May 5 at 3:00 PM, the first landslide detached from Mount Pizzo d'Alvano, narrowly missing the underlying settlements, while rain relentlessly poured over Sarno, Bracigliano, and Siano. The Salerno prefecture was informed of the landslides only around 4:30 PM. At 5:00 PM, several landslides and debris flows began sliding downhill, overwhelming Sarno and nearby locations, destroying dozens of homes. Meanwhile, reports of a landslide in Siano also arrived. The first rescue teams reached the valley about an hour later, just as a mud and debris avalanche struck Quindici, located on the opposite side of Pizzo d'Alvano, burying the center and the Casamanzi hamlet. Shortly after, the Episcopio hamlet of Sarno was hit by a massive flow that destroyed the entire settlement. During the evening, as other landslides struck Sarno and Quindici, causing some blackouts, several dead and injured were pulled from the mud; the injured were transported to the area's main hospital, Villa Malta in Sarno. However, the situation reached catastrophic proportions between 11:31 PM and midnight on May 6, when a massive landslide once again overwhelmed Sarno, invading the Villa Malta hospital and burying under the mud two doctors, three nurses, the hospital porter, and five patients (including two children). The first helicopters flew over the area only after 6:00 AM.

After days of digging through mud and rubble, the final toll reached 161 dead. Among the victims of the disaster was also a rescuer, firefighter Marco Mattiucci, who - for the heroism demonstrated during the rescue efforts - was awarded the gold medal for civil valor.

According to some sources, only ten hours after the incident, the environmental councilor of the Campania Region, Angelo Grillo, sent a fax to the mayors of the area predicting the possibility of catastrophic events: "It is reported that the orographic conformation and geo-environmental characteristics of your municipal territory, in conjunction with particular rainy events occurring at this time, may result in unpredictable instability situations with consequent catastrophic landslides. This is communicated for the purpose of activating all necessary measures to ensure the safeguarding of public and private safety." Once the severity of the situation was confirmed, numerous detachments of law enforcement, firefighters, and volunteers from all over Italy rushed to the site to assist the affected populations. In addition to the high number of victims - including several children - many people were rescued from the mudslide; among them was the current deputy mayor Roberto Robustelli, then a student in his early twenties, who was pulled out alive after more than three days from the basement where he had been dragged by the force of the mud. After the initial emergency phase was over, some criminal proceedings were initiated against members of the Sarno city administration to ascertain any responsibilities. On May 5, 2010, Mayor Gerardo Basile, initially found not guilty of the charge of multiple manslaughter in the first two levels of judgment, had the appeal sentence annulled by the Court of Cassation. This judgment - motivated by the fact that, according to the Court, the mayor's conduct was "passive" in managing the events - referred the case back to the Naples Court of Appeal for a new trial. In December 2011, the Court of Appeal sentenced Basile to five years of imprisonment, confirmed by the Court of Cassation in 2013 (Cass. pen., sez. III, n. 19507/2013); the sentence was then reduced by three years due to the 2006 pardon, while the remaining two years were served under probationary supervision in social services.

Whole_Text.content: The flood of Verona in 1882 was a flood of the Adige River that struck the city in September 1882. It was one of the most devastating floods of the river and caused numerous damages and casualties. As a result, Verona began, a few years later, the construction of high walls as a barrier.

Verona has certainly gained great advantages from its position in the bend of the river, but it has also suffered significant destruction due to its floods. Paul the Deacon and Pope Gregory I recount the disastrous flood of October 17, 589, which submerged the city and destroyed part of the city walls. On the facade of the Church of Santo Stefano, there is a graffiti that recalls the flood of 1195, and on a fresco in San Zeno, the memory of the one in 1239. Subsequently, other floods are remembered in 1512 and 1568. In the 19th century, the Adige also overflowed in 1835 and 1868, culminating in the most devastating flood, that of 1882.

As early as the first days of September 1882, the water level of the Adige began to rise more and more due to the heavy rains. The warm winds blowing over the mountains also melted the early snowfalls that had occurred. The millers and residents in houses along the riverbanks were therefore prepared to face the flood but not the extent it would reach. Measures were taken to reinforce the moorings at San Lorenzo, the Filippini area, Via Sottoriva, and other more exposed areas, and barriers were used to protect doors and windows on the ground floors. Among the causes of the violent flood were the modifications to the river's course in the Trentino area, carried out during the construction of the Brenner railway, and the regulation of many streams, which increased the speed of the flood wave. There was also talk of agricultural works that had altered the river's hydrography upstream of the city. September 14 was the most frightening day. Many mills broke the chains with which they had been previously secured and were swept away by the current. One crashed into the Ponte Nuovo, destroying it. By September 17, over two-thirds of Verona were submerged; boats could not even pass under the arches of Porta Borsari. At Ponte Pietra, the water had reached a height of 4.5 meters above the warning mark, while the estimated current speed was 20 km/h. The immediate and crucial mobilization of the army brought landing craft and military engineering units from as far as Legnago and Peschiera del Garda. The city was plunged into darkness, many people were isolated, and some houses collapsed. In the Piazza Isolo area, 11 residents died in the collapse of their home. On September 27, the city was visited by King Umberto I, who came from Rome to witness the catastrophe and bring comfort to the people of Verona.

The damage assessment was extremely severe. The most striking ones can be summarized as follows. Even the printing house of the newspaper L'Arena was flooded and had to suspend publications for a few days. After the waters receded, the city was submerged in mud and other sediments up to human height. Work immediately began to restore things to normal. Despite expectations of years of work or even doubts about the city's ultimate survival, remedies were achieved in relatively short times. These city restoration works culminated in securing the Adige River through the filling of the Dead Water Canal and the construction of embankments as river barriers.

Whole_Text.content: During the flooding of the Meuse in 1993, large parts of Dutch Limburg were flooded. In Belgium and France, small rivers also overflowed their banks. Six people died. In the Meuse basin, high water levels occurred after a period of persistent rain. On December 20, 1993, the Meuse overflowed its banks for the first time, and on December 22, this happened in multiple places in the province of Limburg. The areas around Roermond and Venlo, and specifically the villages of Gennep, Itteren, and Borgharen, located on the eastern bank, were affected. On the western bank, Neer was the hardest hit. Approximately 8% (18,000 hectares) of the surface area of the province of Limburg was underwater. Some municipalities in Brabant along the Meuse also experienced flooding. About 12,000 people were evacuated. The total damage amounted to 254 million guilders. Such a high discharge had never been measured before: 3,120 m3/s. In Borgharen, the Meuse reached a record height of 45.90 meters above NAP. Just over a year later, in January 1995, the areas along the Meuse were again hit by large-scale flooding.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in 1845 was one of the largest floods in the territory of Bohemia and Moravia in modern times. It was surpassed (and not everywhere) only after more than 150 years by the flood in 2002. The maximum water flow through Prague during the 1845 flood is estimated at 4500 m³/s[1].

The flood affected the construction of railways: since most of the tracks were built relatively shortly after it, the tracks were designed to avoid being impacted. Therefore, the tracks remained largely operational even during later floods. In Moravia, a large part of Břeclav was flooded during these floods due to a poorly designed railway embankment. This was also reflected in later transportation construction projects.
Drought in the Czech Republic 2015–2020

The Oder flood of 2010 was one of the largest floods of the Oder since the beginning of water level recordings. Since all three neighboring countries had made enormous efforts for flood protection after the devastating Oder flood of 1997, the damages remained far below those of the summer of 1997. At the same time, and caused by the same rainfall event, the Vistula basin was also hit by a catastrophic flood with enormous damages and loss of life.

Already in the upper Oder catchment area, the flood developed into the second largest since the end of the war. Between May 15 and May 20, 2010, 350 to 370 mm of rain fell in the Czech catchment area of the Oder. This quickly led to the formation of an extreme flood. At the Czech-Polish border, the second largest flow rate since records began was recorded on May 17, with approximately 2,100 cubic meters per second. In 1997, over 2,800 cubic meters per second were discharged here. The third largest flood is considered to be that of August 1985, with 1,155 cubic meters per second. The Buków flood polder (Oder km 29–32.5), completed in 2002, was opened during the night of May 17 to 18 and relieved the Oder by approximately 300 cubic meters per second, reducing the flow in the Oder from 74% to now 63% of the peak flow of 1997. At the downstream Oder gauge in Miedonia, the peak level on May 18 was accordingly 1.6 m below the peak value of 1997, but it is still the second highest water level recorded there since 1947.

The Brandenburg State Environmental Agency compiled and published the highest water levels in 2012. In the upper German Oder section from Ratzdorf to Frankfurt (Oder), the reference values for the highest alert level were reached and exceeded. Alert level IV was declared on May 26 and 28 for these river sections and remained in effect until the end of May. Alert level III applied to the entire lower Oder section. It was not until June 23, 2010, that the entire German/Polish Oder section was free of alert levels again.

Whole_Text.content: The Magdalene flood of 1480 was a devastating flood disaster that struck the surroundings of the Aare and Rhine rivers as well as other rivers in the Swiss Plateau and Upper Rhine region in July 1480.

As with other extreme flood events, such as the Magdalene Flood of 1342, the Oder Flood of 1997, the Elbe Flood of 2002, or the Central European Flood of 2013, the flood was likely triggered by a Vb weather pattern. After the water levels of the rivers were already very high due to prolonged rain in May and June, hot days in early summer followed, causing intense snowmelt. In mid-July, continuous rain set in (according to the Bern Chronicle by Diebold Schilling, it rained torrentially for three days without interruption), which led to the flood.[1]

The beginning of the flood is to be set for July 21 for the Bernese Oberland and Fribourg in Üechtland. In Bern, the Aare overflowed its banks in the Matte district and Marzili on July 22 – during the night of July 23 – flooding the streets, gardens, and apartments. In Basel, the peak of the flood was on July 24.
According to the chronicles, all Aare and Rhine bridges between Bern and Strasbourg were completely or partially destroyed.
The Magdalene flood of 1480 was rated as the largest flood disaster in Switzerland. According to researchers, water levels were up to 90 centimeters higher than during the great Alpine flood of 2005.
