The Tarn flood in 1930 was a centennial flood of the Tarn, its tributaries the Agout and the Aveyron, its sub-tributaries the Thoré and the Arnette, and also the Garonne. It caused a devastating flood from March 1 to 4, 1930, in several departments of southwestern France.

Thousands of houses, dozens of bridges, and kilometers of roads and railways are damaged or destroyed; hundreds of deaths are reported. In Montauban, the capital of Tarn-et-Garonne, Arthur Poncelet, Adolphe Poult, his friend René Bousquet, and Marcel Lefranc save dozens of people from drowning. In the same department, the town of Moissac is the most affected by these devastating floods. The departments of Aude, Lot-et-Garonne (notably Agen), and Tarn are also particularly impacted. These catastrophic events led to a national day of mourning on March 9, 1930 — the first in France in the 20th century — after the then-President of the Republic, Gaston Doumergue, himself a native of southern France, visited the affected areas, accompanied by André Tardieu. The French government allocated significant financial aid to rebuild the devastated areas, supported by national and international solidarity (Yugoslavia, the Netherlands, Morocco), particularly in Moissac, the most severely affected town by these exceptional floods described as the "flood of the century." François Coty contributed to the efforts by building four model farms designed by architects to withstand future floods, offering them outright to deserving families. Pope Pius XI sent a check to the Bishop of Montauban to assist the victims. The number of deaths caused by these floods is now estimated at around 700.

Article_Name: Inondation de Vaison-la-Romaine en septembre 1992 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Modify - modify the code - modify Wikidata The flooding of Vaison-la-Romaine in September 1992 is a submersion phenomenon caused by heavy rainfall and significant ground impermeability. This disaster occurred on Monday, September 21, and Tuesday, September 22, 1992, in Vaison-la-Romaine, in the French department of Vaucluse in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region. It resulted in 37 deaths and 4 disappearances, in four municipalities.

The floods in Vaison-la-Romaine are due to a large-scale meteorological phenomenon in the southeastern region of France, affecting several departments: on September 21, 1992, heavy rains poured over the departments of Hérault, Gard, Lozère, and Ardèche, particularly on the Cévennes mountains. The commune of Le Caylar received 448 mm of rainfall in 24 hours, which was a record for the Hérault department until September 16, 2023, when Roqueredonde received 550 mm in 24 hours. These rains followed weather conditions above the norms for the region, with average temperatures higher than normal, coupled with a low-pressure area in the Bay of Biscay. The next day, the rains continued in Gard, particularly in the morning, where the regions of Sommières and Nîmes were swept by a brief and violent storm accompanied by strong wind gusts, as well as part of Ardèche. The rain front then crossed the Rhône to affect the departments of Vaucluse and Drôme. The showers on September 22 resulted from a west/east storm front blocked on the western flank of Mont Ventoux from the afternoon. With this stationary storm system over part of the Ouvèze watershed, the commune of Orange, in the northwest of the Vaucluse department, received 51 mm of cumulative rainfall, while Carpentras, south of the Dentelles de Montmirail, received 212 mm.

The first weather alert bulletin from Météo-France, sent to the Ministry of the Interior and then to local authorities, dates back to September 21, 1992. That same evening, the prefect of Vaucluse relayed this alert to set up security and protection services. On September 22, 1992, two other messages from Météo-France in Marignane, late at night and early in the morning, confirmed the alert, announcing storms of rare violence. Despite this, the rain, which was heavy over Vaison-la-Romaine in the middle of the morning, stopped around noon. The city's emergency services faced several challenges: the events occurred on a Tuesday, the day of the weekly market, with increased crowds; evacuation requests made to customers and tourists (then numerous at the end of the summer season) at the municipal campsite, located upstream of the Roman bridge, had little effect. The first moderate downpour (17.8 mm) fell between 10 a.m. and noon. It was followed, in the early afternoon, by a second much more violent one (182.7 mm) that lasted until 3:15 p.m. The teachers at Jules Ferry School, then located near the Ouvèze river, secured the students on the first floor of the building farthest from the river. The total rainfall in Entrechaux was 300 mm (300 liters of water per square meter) in six hours (possibly slightly more locally). For comparison, the annual average rainfall in Paris is 637 mm. During this meteorological event, nearly 1,320 km² received more than 100 mm of precipitation. The storm, of unprecedented violence, stagnated over the slopes of Mont Ventoux for several hours. It poured 215 mm of water in Malaucène, 179 mm in Vaison, and 143 mm in Buis-les-Baronnies. The heavy rains upstream of Vaison-la-Romaine were such that a mudslide, about 50 cm thick, invaded and completely covered the municipal campsite around 3 p.m. A water height of 10 cm already covered the streets of the lower town. The first news arrived: there were deaths at the Moulin de César campsite. The section reserved for the À cœur joie associative campsite—450 pitches—was swept away. It was learned that there were numerous victims in the Théos neighborhood subdivision, located on the right bank, which was submerged by the floodwaters. At the same time, a torrent of mud swept through the municipal campsite, carrying everything in its path: caravans, vehicles, and campers. In the minutes that followed, at the level of the Roman bridge, whose deck is less than twenty meters above the river's normal level, the water reached 17 meters, 15 meters above its normal course. Images of caravans crashing against the Roman bridge remain etched in memories. The fire station, located near the Ouvèze riverbed, was flooded, including the building and rescue equipment. The ORSEC Plan was activated at 5 p.m. The water level only began to recede after 10 p.m. Of the three bridges over the Ouvèze, only the ancient Roman bridge withstood the flood, despite some damage to its parapet.

Later, it will be learned that the same phenomenon had already occurred, at least once, in Vaison. In the municipal archives of the city, a deliberation dated August 1616 indicates that "the city council had to repair the parapet of the Roman bridge destroyed by a flood that also swept away several houses." No victims were reported. In the 17th century, the inhabitants of Vaison lived in the upper town, and around the cathedral, covering the ruins of ancient Vasio, there were only gardens. The risk was, however, known but neglected. Before the tragedy, following the disaster of October 3, 1988, in Nîmes, engineer Ponton mentioned in his April 1989 report 62 towns, including Vaison-la-Romaine, likely to be affected by floods caused by rainwater runoff. Jean-Pierre Mazeillier had described Vaison's Land Use Plan (POS) as "completely insane" when he took over the technical services of the town hall and could not find any trace of Ponton's report. The 1982 Deferre decentralization law had transferred urban planning authority from the prefect to the mayors. On October 14, 1983, the then-mayor, André Thès, revised the POS and declared the right bank of the Ouvèze constructible over more than a kilometer. The area had not even been classified as a "minor flood zone." The price of the land had increased by a factor of more than 10. Scientific studies were conducted on the centennial flood of 1992. They provide the reasons for the extent of the damage. In the area of the Salette torrent, a tributary of the Brégoux, itself a tributary of the Ouvèze, in the heart of the Dentelles de Montmirail, 200.5 millimeters of rain fell within five hours. The figures are known thanks to the Bernardins station in Beaumes-de-Venise. This represented a volume of 4.2 million cubic meters of water falling into the watershed of this torrent, which has an area of only 28 km². The report of the commission of inquiry on "the causes of floods and ways to remedy them" also mentions other reasons such as a specific geological impermeability in this Ouvèze valley but also aggravating anthropogenic modifications: "an impermeabilization of the soil causing urban rainwater runoff and finally the presence of constructions in the very bed of the river." The Ouvèze is a 123 km river, originating in Montauban-sur-Ouvèze, in the Drôme department, and flowing into the Rhône at Sorgues, after passing through 28 municipalities. Many watercourses are tributaries of the Ouvèze, notably the Toulourenc, between Mollans-sur-Ouvèze and Entrechaux. Of the 820 km² of the Ouvèze watershed, 580 km² are located upstream of Vaison-la-Romaine.

This tragedy of September 22 caused the death of more than 40 people, swept away by the Ouvèze or its tributaries. The most commonly reported number of victims is 46 deaths, plus one in Beaumes-de-Venise, regularly omitted from statistics. Thirty-eight people lost their lives that day in Haut-Vaucluse, including 34 in Vaison-la-Romaine. Among them were fifteen residents of the Theos housing estate and at least eleven residents of the Moulin de César campsite. This extraordinary flood struck many villages downstream of Vaison, also causing deaths: three in Séguret; an elderly farmer who went to fetch his cow in Gigondas, which was found alive; four campers swept away by the Brégoux waters in Aubignan; a pedestrian who tried to cross the bridge swept away by the Salette flood in Beaumes-de-Venise, as well as four missing persons, including a six-month-old baby. Nine months later, in 1993, a body was found in the commune of Roaix by a firefighter and his search dog from Vaison. Without the courage of a firefighter who saved 36 people with a borrowed boat, the death toll would have been much higher. As the waters receded on the morning of September 23, bulldozers and trucks were able to work in the streets to remove vehicle carcasses covered in river silt and all the debris it had carried. To prevent looting, the flooded area was cordoned off by the army, with soldiers monitoring the entrances to the city and the main affected villages and patrolling in front of houses. In the five years following the disaster, the investigation stalled. Only the prefect of Vaucluse, who was in office in 1965, was implicated in 1995. The judge closed the investigation at the beginning of 1998 after ordering new investigations into the studies conducted for building permits. These "clearly implicated the systematic concreting of risk areas, particularly the natural flood expansion basins of rivers and streams." Two years after the disaster, building permit applications were submitted to construct in the city's flood-prone areas. Some survivors in Vaison were able to resettle in Clos d'Ariston, a plot purchased and developed by the municipality. Few of them left the city, as insurance compensated them well, and others were able to purchase older properties.

The material damage was estimated at 500 million francs (a little over 76 million euros). Despite spontaneous solidarity, subsidies, and insurance reimbursements, the municipality became heavily indebted. More than 19,000 F per inhabitant (around 2,890 €). In the five years following the disaster, 115 million francs of work were carried out, equivalent to 17.5 million euros. Furthermore, this renovation had an increased cost. The final bill amounted to nearly 460 million euros in damages, including 20 million for Vaison alone. Ultimately, for this single municipality, the work amounted to approximately 26 million euros, of which nearly 8 million was borne by Vaison and its 6,000 inhabitants. While everything was done to prevent another disaster, it came at the cost of heavy indebtedness.

It is true that Vaison, being a tourist town, needed to quickly restore an image in line with its objectives. The first measure taken was to make the areas along the Ouvèze non-buildable. Seventy homes, including an entire housing development, were demolished. The riverbed was widened, and the banks were reinforced. Upstream, the municipal campsite was relocated and elevated. Where the Théos housing development once stood, massive stone blocks reinforced the bank, and a natural area was created. Further along, a fitness trail now covers the former Jardins de l'Ouvèze neighborhood, and the Eminées and Magnans housing developments have been turned into green spaces. The school was rebuilt. It is protected, like the lower town, by a long wall serving as a levee. Evacuation drills are held every year in all classes. If intervention were needed, the Vaison firefighters, thanks to alert systems, are notified of a flood in T + 2. Two non-compressible hours, but enough to evacuate everyone. The alert is given thanks to the installation of weather radars in Bollène and in the Gard. In 1992, according to the mayor at the time, there were none, although there was one in Nîmes named Mélody, but it had been struck by lightning the evening before...

On the left bank of the Ouvèze, the industrial area has healed its wounds, but it has not relocated. Many have reopened their businesses on-site for economic reasons: relocating would have required both purchasing new land and rebuilding, and insurance did not cover it. However, a new business area was created on higher ground but attracted only two companies. Moreover, "local media regularly report on local urban planning (PLU) being challenged and most often annulled a few months later by the courts. The main reasons are almost systematically, aside from procedural irregularities, the transformation of agricultural land, often located in flood-prone areas or adjacent to them, into building plots." The primary cause is that land prices have skyrocketed throughout the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region. Due to quality of life and sunshine, it is the region in France with the fastest-growing population, attracting retirees as well as active families. Thus, for some, the temptation is great to multiply the value of agricultural land by twenty or thirty times simply by reclassifying it as building land. In the event of a flood, even less severe than that of September 22, everyone knows that the damage would be considerable, including loss of human life.

Whole_Text.header: The floods in Vaucluse, Ardèche, and Drôme
Whole_Text.content: Sixty-three municipalities were affected in Vaucluse, the most impacted being, besides Vaison, Séguret, Gigondas, Beaumes-de-Venise, and Aubignan, including Violès, Bédarrides, Jonquières, and Sarrians. The next day, the extent of the damage was discovered: roads washed away, vineyards disappeared, bridges destroyed such as those in Roaix and Beaumes-de-Venise. A desolation that worsened in the municipalities of Vaucluse affected by the flood, with 2,300 houses or businesses damaged in the department, including 320 in Vaison that were either destroyed or required repairs. But Vaucluse was not the only affected department. On September 22, there was a centennial flood of the Ardèche, which caused five deaths in the southern part of this department, between Pont-de-Labeaume and Aubenas. The Drôme department was also severely affected, with water rising over 2 meters in some villages along the Ouvèze. The commune of Sainte-Jalle was particularly affected.

The flood of Genoa - Sestri Ponente on October 4, 2010, occurred due to a very violent and persistent self-regenerating maritime storm that struck with extreme force a relatively small area of the western part of the city and Varazze. It caused the overflow of the Chiaravagna, Cantarena, and Molinassi streams, one fatality, and significant material damage.

The thunderstorm cell that formed in the early morning of October 4 initially remained stationary for a few hours (between 4:00 and 8:00) in the Varazze area, pouring nearly 300 mm of water onto the ground and thus causing the overflow of major streams and several landslides on the hills in the area. It then moved eastward, stopping over the western districts of the city between Pegli, Sestri Ponente, and the Polcevera Valley, where it unleashed its full power, causing a true flash flood. In about five hours, between 8:00 and 13:00, over 400 mm of water fell on the heights of Sestri Ponente, 380 mm on those of Pegli, and about 300 mm on the lower Polcevera Valley between Pontedecimo and the mouth of the stream. A few dozen millimeters more of rain could have caused the overflow of the Polcevera and many other secondary streams, resulting in significant damage.

Following the heavy rainfall, in the early afternoon, the Chiaravagna, Cantarena, and Molinassi streams overflowed, while the Marotto stream and the Zanino and Monferrato creeks, which were culverted, broke through the asphalt of the roads under which they flowed. Almost the entire lower part of Sestri Ponente and Multedo was flooded: shops, garages, basements, squares, and streets were damaged, and the water flow carried away parked cars. A worker from the nearby Monte Gazzo quarries fell along with an embankment swallowed by the fury of the Chiaravagna stream and was found a few days later in the sea off Sestri Ponente: he was the only victim of the flood event. The Molinassi stream, which flows covered by the Fincantieri warehouses for the last 440 meters, broke its right bank, an old stone wall, near Piazza Clavarino, flooding the western part of Sestri Ponente and merging its waters with those that had overflowed from the Cantarena stream in Via Leoncavallo, a street under which it flows for the last 300 meters of its course. In the eastern part of the district, it was instead the Chiaravagna stream that overflowed at the dam created by the building at Via Giotto 15, constructed directly over its bed and later demolished in March 2013. The westernmost part was also flooded by the Marotto stream and the Zanino and Monferrato creeks, which violently emerged from the network of tunnels into which they had been channeled during the first half of the 20th century under the abandoned industrial warehouses of the former Multedo foundry and those that now house the Coop and other productive activities, and discharged into the sea beyond the Genoa-Ventimiglia railway line, a short distance from the oil port docks. Other floods, fortunately without serious consequences, occurred in other low-lying areas of the west, such as the Multedo railway underpass, the one near Piazza Brin in Certosa, and the entire Fiumara area in Sampierdarena.

Whole_Text.content: The Bauska floods of 1928 were among the most devastating floods in Bauska's history. The rise in the level of the Mēmele River caused by heavy summer rains on June 20 swept along logs floated down the river, flooded the streets of Bauska's old town near the river, and destroyed part of the Mēmele Bridge. The rainy summer of 1928 caused floods in many parts of Latvia and southern Estonia. During these years, there was active floating of logs cut in forests down rivers to sawmills in Bauska, Jelgava, and Riga. By early June, a dangerously large accumulation of logs had formed near the Mēmele Bridge. However, the major floods began a couple of weeks later when the pressure of the Mēmele waters broke through the log jams about four kilometers before Bauska, and the logs carried by the current piled up at the Mēmele Bridge. Due to the rains on June 20 and 21, the water volume in the Mēmele had doubled. The massive log jam blocked the river and raised the water level by 6 meters above normal, flooding many city streets. The overflowing river carried along poorly secured log rafts, which accumulated at the Mēmele Bridge, forming a wooden dam. Riverside buildings and streets were flooded. On Friday, June 22, at 4:00 a.m., the logs carried by the current broke through about a 10-meter section of the bridge. The water and logs partially destroyed several buildings. The river water carved a path along the riverbank on the old town side, washing away and partially destroying riverside sheds, the Jewish synagogue, and several other buildings. The most affected by the floods were the Lower Mill owned by the German Steben, with damages amounting to 8 million rubles, while Theodor Lodiņš's brewery suffered losses of 300,000 rubles.

Starting from the evening of June 23, the water had already receded by 3 meters, leaving behind log debris. The removal of logs was organized by the Bauska municipality, involving 350 workers for this task. Under the leadership of the city's ladies, Mrs. Jura Varenā, a notary and head of the Latvian Red Cross Bauska branch, a relief committee was established, which used the funds allocated by the Red Cross to distribute food—soup, bread, butter, meat, fish, sugar, etc.—to those affected by the floods for a couple of weeks. In the first days, 300 people received aid, with each person being allocated assistance worth 64 santims per day. The destroyed bridge meant that Bauska no longer had land connections with 16 out of the 20 parishes in the district. Trade in the market stopped, and industrial production decreased. Just a few weeks later, a raft bridge was opened for horse traffic, and a wooden footbridge was built for pedestrians.

Whole_Text.header: Flood on the island of Madeira in 1803
Whole_Text.content:
The flood of 1803 was the most severe natural calamity on record to strike the island of Madeira since its settlement. This natural disaster, which occurred on October 9, 1803, resulted in the death of hundreds of people, mainly in the municipalities of Funchal, Machico, Ribeira Brava, Santa Cruz, and Calheta. Its destructive capacity would only be equaled 206 years later, on February 20, 2010, by the Madeira Island storm.  
Due to its tragic circumstances, it remains in the Madeiran collective memory and is still remembered today on the municipal holiday of Machico, October 9.

October 9, 1803, was one of the most fateful days in the history of Madeira Island, but the series of events that led to it began ten to twelve days earlier, during which the island experienced intense, though intermittent, rainfall. On the morning of October 9, around eight o'clock, a period of rainfall began, although not very heavy, which lasted for 12 hours, until about 8 p.m. Shortly after 8 p.m., weather conditions worsened, precipitation levels increased significantly, and stronger winds began to blow. Around 8:30 p.m., the situation escalated, and the flow of the streams increased noticeably until they finally violently overflowed their banks. The conditions were set for one of the worst natural disasters ever to strike Madeira Island. The origin of such a great tragedy lay in an atmospheric situation characterized by southwesterly winds, thunderstorms, and heavy rainfall. The deforestation of the mountains overlooking Funchal, clearly visible in engravings of the time, and the lack of channeling of the streams within urban areas contributed to the worsening of the catastrophe. Faced with the seriousness of the situation, many inhabitants, caught by surprise, were unable to escape the danger and ended up dying. Some were caught in their escape by the strong currents that had meanwhile overflowed the banks of the streams, while many did not even attempt to flee, perishing when their own houses collapsed or being crushed by falling walls.

The municipality of Funchal was one of the most affected by this catastrophe and the one that suffered the most in terms of the number of victims. One of the particularly affected areas was the neighborhood of Santa Maria Maior. The walls of the Ribeira de João Gomes, whose flow had already increased due to the intense rainfall of the previous days, burst in three locations. The water that overflows the banks at these three points forms currents so violent that they destroy almost everything in their path and are responsible for the deaths of dozens of people. According to accounts from the time, entire streets and numerous buildings were swept into the sea. The Parish Church of Nossa Senhora do Calhau itself, located on the left bank of the stream, succumbed to the violence of the waters. In a single house in this area, 21 inhabitants died. In another building in Pelourinho, an English subject and 15 other family members perished. The estimated number of victims in this neighborhood is shocking; it is calculated that, in this area alone, the flood claimed the lives of around 200 people. The streams of Santa Luzia and Bom Jesus were also unable to withstand the high water flow, which ended up overflowing the banks and causing great destruction. Rua dos Ferreiros suffered considerable damage, with several residential and commercial buildings destroyed. The description is similar for Rua dos Tanoeiros and Rua Direita, where the scene of destruction was repeated.

In the village of Machico, it can be read in the Parish Archive that the river wall was destroyed, as well as the existing bridge, and that the water struck the village with such intensity that it reached a height of three cubits in the Church and in all the streets. The same archive describes as "prodigious" the fact that only 14 people perished (swept away by the intensity of the currents or buried in their own homes), given the intensity of the catastrophe. The historic Chapel of the Lord of Miracles (at the time called the Chapel of Christ), one of the oldest on Madeira Island, was also affected, being almost completely destroyed by the currents. From the original chapel, only the ogival door and the crosses on the façade remained. The image of the crucified Christ was swept out to sea and presumed lost; however, it was eventually recovered, almost intact, by an American galleon that delivered it to the Funchal Cathedral. This event, considered miraculous by the region's inhabitants, led to the chapel being renamed the Chapel of the Lord of Miracles, as well as to a pilgrimage (one of the largest on the island) that takes place every year on October 9th in honor of the Lord of Miracles. In addition to the Chapel of the Lord of Miracles, some churches were also damaged, as well as the archives of Foros, chapels, and brotherhoods.

The number of deaths resulting from this tragedy is not consensual. Some sources point to a number very close to 1,000 fatalities. According to Cabral Nascimento, in a long study on these events published in the Madeira Historical Archive (Volumes 1 and 5), this flood is said to have caused more than 700 fatalities, and beyond the city, there was also significant damage in other parishes in the south of the island, namely in Campanário, Calheta, Tabua, Ribeira Brava, Santa Cruz, and especially in Machico, where fourteen people died. The governor and captain general D. José Manuel da Câmara, given the severity of the events, issued a decree adopting the necessary measures to mitigate the effects of the catastrophe. One of the first measures adopted was, naturally, to seek shelter for the many people who had been left homeless. Temporary accommodation was provided in various public buildings, state service offices, churches, chapels, fortresses, as well as many private homes. Another urgent measure was the prohibition of price increases for essential goods under the penalty of severe punishments for offenders. Not remaining insensitive to the suffering of the Madeirans, the metropolitan government, in February 1804, sent Brigadier Reinaldo Oudinot to Madeira with the task of overseeing the much-needed recovery works. On February 19, 1804, Brigadier Reinaldo Oudinot, a reputed engineering specialist, arrived in Madeira with the mission of directing the recovery work for the damage caused by the great flood and guiding the construction of the lateral walls of the streams. From the beginning, he demonstrated high competence in performing his duties. In a short period, he managed to channel the three streams that cross Funchal. He is also responsible for one of the great moments of urban planning in the city of Funchal, drafting a plan for its reconstruction, which referred to the expansion of the city to the north, east, and west. Outside Funchal, he also carried out laborious activities, promoting the widening and reinforcement of the walls along the banks of the Machico stream. He promoted the rapid reconstruction of many damaged structures in various parts of the island, relying on the free manual labor of many Madeirans who only received basic necessities and exemption from certain taxes, all in accordance with the old "Ordinances," which had been in force since the beginning of settlement to address exceptional events. Reinaldo Oudinot would pass away in the city of Funchal on February 11, 1807, but his services were not forgotten by the inhabitants of this city, who named a street after him on the left bank of the João Gomes stream, between Campo da Barca and Praça dos Lavradores.

The Carrara flood of September 23, 2003, was a violent storm that struck the city of Carrara and the Avenza district, causing the death of 2 people and significant damage to property. Additionally, 70 people were involved in the disaster and went to the emergency room, 30 were displaced, and another 15 refused to leave their homes. Shops were flooded with 1 meter of water, and businesses were also affected (sawmills closed and quarries inaccessible). There was much unrest among people, and there were also issues in the areas of Colonnata with the temporary suspension of gas in homes, Forno, and Torano. The maximum rainfall capacity reached 140 millimeters within an hour and a half, which was not predicted by weather reports.

On the evening of September 23, 2003, a violent storm hit Carrara, causing only one victim. During the evening, in fact, an extremely violent thunderstorm developed, striking the entire Massa area and particularly the Apuan Alps, unleashing as much as 200 mm of rain in just two and a half hours. In a short time, the entire Carrione basin became saturated, overflowing at various points along its main course. The historic center of Carrara was fully affected by the flooding, which inundated the streets with nearly 2 meters of water, sweeping away cars and causing the death of a woman. Subsequently, the waters also invaded the Avenza district.

Northern Italy was affected by a humid southwesterly flow, moving along the ascending branch of a vast trough stretching from Scandinavia to cover all of central Europe. The associated disturbance caused showers and thunderstorms passing through northern Italy, affecting the southern area, including the central regions, Tuscany included. The influx of very warm and humid air from the Mediterranean, the strong southwesterly flow, and the orography of upper Tuscany, highly exposed to this flow, were among the triggering causes of the violent thunderstorm's propagation.

The Municipality of Carrara implemented a plan on November 22, 2010, to collect applications for compensation for damages suffered in 2003 at the former districts of Bonascola, Avenza, and Marina di Carrara.
On January 14, 2010, legal proceedings were initiated for the 2003 Carrara flood disaster, in which 24 people were under investigation, including two former mayors, for manslaughter and flooding.

September 2003 already became part of history for at least 4 sad events, from Val Canale to Taranto, from Syracuse to Carrara. A truly worrying frequency that affected geographically distant and also orographically different areas.

Whole_Text.content:
Polish flood July 2001  
The flood in Poland (2001) – a flood that struck the Vistula River basin in July 2001. Its cause was heavy rainfall and storms. In southern Poland, high water levels persisted for 2-3 days, causing seepage and breaches in the Vistula levees. There were also failures of hydrotechnical structures (including the breach of the cofferdam of the under-construction Wióry reservoir on the Świślina River, which consequently flooded the southern part of Ostrowiec Świętokrzyski).  

The damages from the flood were estimated at 4 billion zlotys[1]. In Gdańsk, the flood occurred on July 9, 2001[2]. As a result, significant areas of the city were affected, including those along the Radunia Canal in the districts of Orunia-Św. Wojciech-Lipce and Śródmieście, as well as areas in the Wrzeszcz Górny and Wrzeszcz Dolny districts located along the Strzyża stream. Heavy rainfall also affected areas such as Maków Podhalański, where 94.6 mm of rain fell on July 24, and as much as 190.8 mm on July 25. This caused a rise in water levels in rivers and streams, resulting in, among other things, the destruction of the market square, damage to municipal infrastructure, railway track breaches, and damage to numerous homes. According to estimates, damages to public property exceeded 20 million zlotys[3].

Whole_Text.content: The Lech flood of 1910 was the strongest known flood of the Lech. It caused significant damage along the entire Lech. The city of Augsburg was hit hardest by the disaster.

The Alpine river Lech, the second-largest tributary of the Bavarian Danube after the Inn in terms of water flow, has experienced severe flooding since time immemorial. Its riverbed was originally mostly flat, kilometers wide, and braided. Almost every year, it swelled to many times its normal width and repeatedly carved out a new bed in its gravel deposits. Corrections to its riverbed from the late Middle Ages to the 19th century were primarily intended to make it navigable for timber rafting, which increased its flow velocity, causing it to deepen its bed more and more. From Augsburg to its confluence with the Danube, the Lech had already been flowing in an artificially regulated bed since the 1850s, but upstream it remained largely natural. In June 1910, there was still a lot of snow in the Tyrolean mountains, which melted within a short time due to heavy downpours on June 14. The simultaneous inflow of precipitation and meltwater caused the Lech to swell into a raging torrent. In the Tyrolean Lech Valley, it swept away seven bridges, and numerous timber rafting weirs and barriers fell victim to it. Near Steeg, it carried almost 300 cubic meters of water per second—compared to an average of only 12 cubic meters per second. At that time, the Forggensee, which could have absorbed the flood peaks, did not yet exist. On the evening of June 15, the Lech reached a flow rate of over 1,000 cubic meters per second according to measurements at the time, or over 1,400 cubic meters per second according to today's estimates, at Landsberg and destroyed the Karolinenwehr there. In the lowlands of the Lechfeld, it flowed up to four kilometers wide. It reached almost to the settlement edge of Mering on the right and into the town of Haunstetten on the left. In Rain, located five kilometers before its confluence with the Danube, the entire area north of the old town was flooded, causing significant damage in the so-called Vorstadt (Donauwörther Straße area). In Oberndorf am Lech, all local streets were under water. The peak flow at the Lech's confluence on June 16, 1910, was measured at 1,250 cubic meters per second (average flow 116 cubic meters). Other rivers, such as the Iller, also experienced severe flooding at the same time, causing significant damage.

Whole_Text.header: The destruction of the Hochablass weir
Whole_Text.content: At the Augsburger Hochablass, the yellow-brown flood initially tore away a section of the weir, which was made of wood but generally resistant to high water, at the two gravel outlets. Then, due to the resulting gap, it destroyed further parts of the weir up to the raft channel. Subsequently, the water destroyed the Stadtbach main sluice, the historic main sluice building from 1798, and the restoration building. With the greatest efforts, the deployed military and fire brigade managed to protect the fountain works at the Hochablass—a structure on which Augsburg's drinking water supply completely depended—from destruction by reinforcing the bank there with felled trees, gravel-filled crates, sandbags, and other natural materials. To reduce the risk of further damage, the entire Hochablass weir was blown up, leaving only a small remaining stump on the eastern bank. Below the weir, where the riverbed was deeply eroded, the river tore away large stretches of the bank and destroyed seven properties on the Hochzoll bank. Parts of Hochzoll, Lechhausen, and the Jakobervorstadt were flooded. The tracks of Line I of the Augsburger Localbahn were undermined and damaged. The 52-meter-high church tower of St. Pankratius in Lechhausen was severely damaged. The railway weir broke, putting the railway bridge near Hochzoll in great danger as its central pillar was at risk of being undermined. In Gersthofen, a large section of the railway bridge, which was only seven years old, was torn away.

The total damage caused by the Lech flood of 1910 for the city of Augsburg is estimated at around 5 million marks. Following the flood disaster, Augsburg faced great hardship due to a lack of water, as the breach of the Hochablass weir caused the main city canal and the Lech canals supplied by it to dry up. All hydropower plants on these canals came to a standstill. Large companies switched to coal-powered steam engines, while many smaller ones ceased operations entirely. Since all of the city's wastewater also flowed through these canals, their drying up posed a threat to the health of the population. A short-term reconstruction of the Hochablass weir was out of the question. Therefore, a new temporary Lech diversion was created further upstream to supply the main city canal with water again.

In February 1911, work began on the construction of a new high weir, which was built for the first time in reinforced concrete and according to the latest state of the art. It was erected about 200 meters from the old location, and the construction costs amounted to 1.5 million marks. On July 28, 1912, the official water diversion took place. In 1914, King Ludwig III, along with the royal family, visited the completed new high weir, which is still commemorated today by a monument on the left bank of the weir.

Article_Name: 明治十八年の淀川洪水

Whole_Text.header: The Yodo River flood of Meiji 18 (1885).
Whole_Text.content: The Yodo River Flood of Meiji 18 (1885) refers to the flood of the Yodo River that occurred from mid-June to July 1885 (Meiji 18). It is also called the Great Meiji Flood. It caused damage second only to the Yodo River Flood of Kyowa 2 (1802).

In June 1885 (Meiji 18), continuous rain fell due to the influence of two low-pressure systems from early in the month, and on the night of the 15th, heavy rain finally began. The Yodo River rapidly swelled. On the 16th, tributaries on the right bank of the Yodo River, including the Hio River (Takatsuki City), Akuta River (Takatsuki City), Aii River (Ibaraki City), and Ibaraki River (Ibaraki City), overflowed. On the 17th, the embankment of the Amano River, a tributary on the left bank in Okashinmachi, Hirakata City, collapsed. Later that night, the main embankment of the Yodo River in Ikaga, Hirakata City, broke over a span of 30 ken (approximately 182 meters), an event known as the "Ikaga Break." This breach eventually expanded to 60 ken (approximately 364 meters), causing water to flood the southern side of the Yodo River. Embankments on the left bank of the Yodo River collapsed in various locations, and water from tributaries and irrigation channels also overflowed, inundating the northern part of the Kawachi Plain. The water reached the embankment of the Neyagawa River, where it temporarily stopped, preventing damage south of the Neyagawa River. However, on the 20th, the Onji River in Nakakawachi District overflowed.  

The flooded area extended over a wide range, including present-day Osaka City’s Miyakojima Ward, Asahi Ward, Joto Ward, Tsurumi Ward, Moriguchi City, Kadoma City, Neyagawa City, Hirakata City, Settsu City, Ibaraki City, and Takatsuki City.  

As the floodwaters temporarily subsided, Osaka Prefecture Governor Genzaburo Tateno decided to intentionally breach the embankment of the Okawa River to release the massive amount of water, employing a method known as "intentional break," which had been used repeatedly since the Edo period. From the 20th to the 23rd, a 26-ken section of the left bank embankment of the Okawa River behind Daicho-ji Temple (currently the site of Fujita Residence Memorial Park) in Amijimacho, Miyakojima Ward, where the Okawa and Neyagawa Rivers converge, was intentionally breached to drain the water.  

On the 25th, embankment repairs began in Ikaga, Hirakata City, and on the 28th, Minister of Finance Masayoshi Matsukata inspected the construction work.

From the night of the 27th, when drainage in the flooded areas had not yet been completed, thunderstorms began, and on the 28th, heavy rain occurred due to the influence of a typhoon. On the 29th, the wind intensified, and on July 1st, a storm hit, causing the Ikaga embankment, which was under repair, to collapse again on the 2nd, leading to the Yodo River overflowing to the south once more. Furthermore, three sections of the embankment in Sakuranomiya, now part of Miyakojima Ward, also collapsed, and water from the Okawa River entered through the embankment behind Daicho-ji, which had been intentionally breached. 

This flood did not stop there. The embankment of the Neyagawa River, which had prevented further damage during the previous flood, collapsed at Tokuan in the current Tsurumi Ward. As other rivers flowing into the Neyagawa River also overflowed, the flood expanded south of the Neyagawa River. By early July, a large lake, larger than the now-vanished Fukano and Shinkai Ponds from the Edo period reclamation, and resembling the former Kawachi Lake, reappeared on the surface. 

Additionally, a storm surge caused water from Osaka Bay to flow back up the Ajigawa River, flooding the current Kita and Nishi Wards. However, the area around Osaka Tenmangu Shrine, being slightly elevated, escaped flooding. 

Due to the July flood, areas that had been flooded in June were inundated again, and new areas, including the current Kita, Fukushima, Konohana, Nishi, Minato, Higashinari, and Ikuno Wards of Osaka City, as well as Higashi-Osaka City, Daito City, and Shijonawate City, were flooded. The flooded area covered approximately 15,269 chobu (15,142 hectares), with 72,509 households, about 20% of the total households in Osaka Prefecture at the time, experiencing flooding up to 4 meters deep. Additionally, 1,749 houses were washed away, about 15,000 houses were damaged, 512 bridges were washed away, 224 embankments collapsed, and there were 81 deaths or missing persons, with 304,199 people affected. 

Of the houses washed away, 739 were in the Barada District and 836 in the Higashinari District, accounting for 90% of the total. Of the deaths and missing persons, 49 were in the Barada District and 13 in the Higashinari District, making up 77% of the total. However, in terms of the number of flooded houses, Nishi Ward had 23,116, Nishinari District had 14,253, and Kita Ward had 8,691, surpassing the Barada District's 6,996 and Higashinari District's 4,421. This was mainly due to the storm surge caused by the typhoon. 

Ultimately, in Osaka City, except for the area north of the Yodo River, which suffered less damage, most low-lying areas, excluding the vicinity of Osaka Tenmangu Shrine, the Uemachi Plateau between Osaka Castle and Tennoji, the Semba area, and the southern part of Osaka City, were affected by the flood. 

In addition to the Kawasaki Bridge upstream on the Okawa River, the three major bridges of Naniwa—Tenmabashi, Tenjinbashi, and the southern half of Naniwabashi (the northern half was an iron bridge)—as well as Yodoyabashi, were washed away. The Ajigawa Bridge, a state-of-the-art movable iron bridge, became clogged with drifting debris, blocking the river, and was hastily blown up by the army. In this way, more than 30 of Osaka's famous "808 bridges" were washed away, cutting off almost all city traffic. On the 7th, the army set up a pontoon bridge on the south side of Naniwabashi. 

When the storm subsided, the flood finally stopped moving. As the water level of the Yodo River gradually decreased, the water accumulated in the flooded areas was drained through the repaired embankments, including the one behind Daicho-ji, though it took a long time. 

After this flood, the surrounding districts launched a petition movement to Osaka Prefecture and the national government for the improvement of the Yodo River. Eventually, the Osaka Prefectural Assembly also submitted a proposal to the national government. These efforts, led by Fusataro Ohashi, bore fruit, and in 1896 (Meiji 29), after the First Sino-Japanese War, the Public River Law, which included the improvement of the Yodo River, was enacted, and the budget for the Yodo River improvement was approved. From that year, improvement work on the Yodo River began. 

Daicho-ji, whose main hall was washed away and precincts devastated (the setting for Chikamatsu Monzaemon's puppet play "The Love Suicides at Amijima"), sold its land to Denzaemon Fujita around 1887 (Meiji 20) and relocated to rebuild. On the site where Daicho-ji once stood, Fujita built a residence called the Amijima Palace, which is now the Fujita Art Museum, Fujita Residence Park, Taiko-en, and the Osaka City Guest House. 

Nearby Sakuranomiya Park has a stone monument commemorating this flood.

Article_Name: Inundaciones en San Juan de 2014, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The floods in San Juan in 2014 were an extreme weather event that affected the south and east of the province of San Juan (Argentina) for several days in February 2014. It intensely affected the departments of Pocito, 25 de Mayo, and Valle Fértil. It also affected Caucete, 9 de Julio, Santa Lucía, Rawson, Angaco, Chimbas, Zonda, 9 de Julio, Ullum, San Martín, and Sarmiento. During the event, the rainfall set a historical record for the province (where the annual average is 100 mm), recording 137.6 mm, surpassing the annual average. According to the Ministry of Human Development of the Government of the Province of San Juan, the number of evacuated people was 3,000.

One of the most affected areas was Pocito, where there were evacuated people and collapsed houses; another affected area was 25 de Mayo, in the localities of Casuarinas, Tupelí, and La Chimbera. Likewise, in Valle Fértil, it caused the overflow of a series of temporary rivers such as Las Tumanas and Del Valle, obstructing circulation on provincial route No. 510, where the localities of Usno, Astica, La Majadita, and Los Valencianos were heavily affected. Other affected areas were Caucete, where 350 people were evacuated; in Rawson, where there were 310 affected people; in Santa Lucía, with 200 affected people; in Angaco, with 150 affected; and Chimbas, with 17 flooded. Other affected departments were: Zonda, where 60 were evacuated; 9 de Julio, where the number reached 56; Ullum, where 50 were evacuated; San Martín, where the number reached 25; and Sarmiento, where 20 evacuees were recorded.

Whole_Text.header: The flood in the Sandvik watercourse 1987
Whole_Text.content: The flood in the Sandviksvassdraget in 1987 was a 100-year flood due to both heavy rain and storm surge in October 1987. Both were caused by a powerful low-pressure system that led to enormous damage in Western Europe (The Great Storm of 1987 in Western Europe). The Sandvikselva river overflowed the Tangen Bridge, which was later raised by one meter. On October 16, 1987, 145 m³ of water per second passed by Bjørnegårdsvingen. The storm surge in the Oslofjord flooded Kadettangen.

The Flood of Deucalion is the ancient Greek version of the flood mentioned in the traditions of many ancient civilizations. According to the myth, during the time when Deucalion reigned in Phthia in Thessaly, Zeus decided to destroy the entire generation of humans who were corrupt, except for the just king and his wife, Pyrrha. Deucalion, following his father's advice, built a ship, gathered the necessary supplies for their survival, and boarded the vessel with his wife. Meanwhile, Zeus opened the waterfalls of the heavens, and the land of Greece was filled with water, causing the people to perish. For nine days and nine nights, the royal couple drifted on the waters in the vessel.

On the tenth day, however, they landed on Mount Othrys or, according to another version, on Mount Parnassus or Mount Athos. There, when the rains stopped and the waters receded, Deucalion and Pyrrha disembarked onto dry land, and the first thing they did was offer a sacrifice to Zeus Phyxios (protector of fugitives). The god, invoked by the pious Deucalion, sent Hermes to convey the promise that Zeus would grant their first wish. And the first wish of Deucalion and Pyrrha was none other than for Zeus to give life to the human race once again. According to another version originating from Phocis, Deucalion and Pyrrha went to Delphi and to the sanctuary of Themis to express the same desire. The goddess heard them and responded with an oracle, telling them that if they wanted to bring new humans to life, they should cover their faces and throw behind their backs the bones of their mother. They understood the interpretation of the oracle, and after doing as instructed, they began throwing stones behind their backs, as these came from the bowels of Mother Earth.

The stones thrown by Deucalion transformed into men, and those thrown by Pyrrha transformed into women. From the first stone thrown by Deucalion came Hellen, the progenitor of the Greeks. There are other variations of the flood of Deucalion, such as the one stating that it occurred when Ogygus was king in Boeotia, the first king of the land of the Boeotians, or according to the Megarians, only Megarus survived the flood by fleeing to the summit of the Geraneia mountains. Nevertheless, the version of Deucalion and Pyrrha is the one that spread widely and prevailed over all others, and during the time of Plutarch, it was enriched with additional elements and details derived from Asian traditions, bearing many similarities to the version recounted in the Bible.

Article_Name: Alluvione di Genova del 9 e 10 ottobre 2014

Whole_Text.header: Flood of Genoa on October 9 and 10, 2014
Whole_Text.content:
The flood in Genoa on October 9 and 10, 2014, occurred as a result of heavy rainfall, which caused about 395 mm in 24 hours. In the city of Genoa, the Bisagno, Sturla, Fereggiano, Noce, and Torbella streams overflowed; in the metropolitan city of Genoa, the Scrivia, Stura, Entella, and Carpi streams. The weather event affected many of the most populated areas of Genoa, including the neighborhoods of the middle and lower Bisagno Valley such as Molassana, Staglieno, Marassi, Quezzi, San Fruttuoso, and many areas of the city center, including the Genoa Brignole station, the Borgo Incrociati area, the Foce neighborhood, and many points in the historic center. The eastern districts of the city, including Nervi, Apparizione, and Sturla, as well as the western districts such as Bolzaneto, Rivarolo, Sampierdarena, Cornigliano, Sestri Ponente, Multedo, Pegli, and Voltri, were also heavily affected.  
In total, 43 municipalities in the province of Genoa were affected, including Montoggio, Rossiglione, Masone, Campo Ligure, and Bogliasco.

In the afternoon of October 9 in Chiavari, the Entella stream overflows at its mouth, in a safety area without causing damage. At 9 PM in Montoggio, a municipality in the province of Genoa, the Carpi stream and the Scrivia river overflow, causing significant damage. Due to the flooding, there is a power outage, water reaches the first floor of houses, drags some cars with people trapped inside due to the water pressure on the doors, and three people are rescued. In the municipality of Genoa, intense rainfall occurs in the morning. In the afternoon, the rain stops, only to resume late in the evening with greater intensity during the night. At around 11:30 PM, the Bisagno stream overflows. Water floods the streets and drags parked cars. Until 3 AM, part of the city remains without power due to the flooding. In some areas, the outage lasts for one to two days. The Fereggiano stream, already responsible for the 2011 flood, also overflows and floods the area of Via Fereggiano and Corso Sardegna. The waters of the Bisagno stream reach almost two meters in height beyond the banks, dragging many cars and wedging them near pedestrian and road tunnels next to the Brignole station.

Shortly after midnight, the Sturla stream overflows, flooding numerous streets and dragging parked cars. Around 12:30 AM, the Brignole area is completely flooded, as in the 2011 flood and previous ones, with water also invading the lower part of Via XX Settembre. Shortly after, at 12:45 AM, firefighters recover the body of a man, who drowned, in the flooded tunnel between Via Canevari and Brignole station, who will be identified two hours later. At around 1:00 AM, firefighters rescue a person trapped in a car, a few meters outside the tunnel between Via Canevari and Brignole station, stuck among other cars dragged by the Bisagno. The A12 highway is closed between the junction for the A7 and Genoa Nervi due to the flooding of Corso Europa in the direction of Genoa at 2:00 AM.

In the early hours of October 11, a storm hits the western part of Genoa, particularly Cornigliano, Coronata, Sestri Ponente, Multedo, Pegli, and Voltri, causing flooding. In Cornigliano, the Polcevera, in Pegli, the Varenna, and in Voltri, the Leira exceed warning levels. The Genoa hinterland is also affected by heavy rains between Campo Ligure, where the Ponzema stream, a tributary of the Stura, overflows, Masone, and Rossiglione. Around 3:00 AM, another storm, with strong gusts of wind and intense, violent rains, hits the center of Genoa, particularly in the mid-eastern districts and the Bisagno valley. There are fears of new overflows of the Bisagno and Fereggiano, which, however, remain within limits. At 3:30 AM in Rivarolo, the Torbella overflows. Around 4:00 AM in San Fruttuoso, the Noce stream overflows again. As the hours pass, the storm increasingly affects the eastern areas, initially limited to the city of Genoa in the districts of Foce, Sturla, Nervi, and then extending to the Golfo Paradiso, the Golfo del Tigullio, and their hinterlands. At 12:00 PM, Civil Protection declares a state of "Alert 2" (maximum level) until midnight on Monday, October 13, 2014, for all Ligurian provinces except Imperia.

The flooding of the Bisagno stream caused one victim: a 57-year-old man, found drowned by the Fire Brigade in the tunnel between Via Canevari and Brignole station at 01:06 on October 10. The Municipality of Genoa declared a day of mourning on October 16, 2014, the day the man's funeral was held. The estimated damages amounted to 250 million euros, 25 million of which were for the city of Genoa alone. The other affected municipalities were 43 in the province of Genoa and four in the province of La Spezia. Montoggio was the most affected municipality after Genoa. Resources for flood-affected businesses amounted to 40 million euros. With the stabilization of weather conditions in the flood-affected areas, the city witnessed a strong reaction of spontaneous social solidarity, with the participation of the population, including many young people and children, who took part in rescuing and helping those affected and restoring normalcy. In the following days, many volunteers, referred to as "mud angels" (a term historically used by Italian media to describe volunteers intervening in flood-affected areas), including people of all ages, Genoese citizens, flood victims, immigrants, and individuals from other parts of Italy, along with civil protection personnel, firefighters, and municipal employees, cleaned the streets and most of the affected structures.

The event was triggered by heavy rainfall, 395 mm in 24 hours[1], occurring in a restricted area between October 9 and October 10 and in various areas of Genoa and its province, causing the subsequent overflow of the Bisagno stream and other involved watercourses. A large-scale meteorological event, exacerbated by the strong self-regenerating thunderstorm[21]. The meeting of the two airflows, warm air with cold air, is the cause of the V-shape thunderstorm, so called in English for its V shape, and also referred to as self-regenerating. From the analysis of wind data, the southwesterly winds at altitudes above 700 hPa[1] and the southerly winds at 850 hPa[1] in the lower layers (925 and 1000 hPa),[1] it can be understood how the encounter between the cold northern currents of the Tramontana wind from the Po Valley and the warm humid southern currents of the Scirocco wind from the Tyrrhenian Sea resulted in a stationary microfront,[1] that is, a stall caused by the airflow due to the convective motion of the currents. The currents remained blocked over the area, consequently the stormy precipitation self-fed and fell over the same area.[1]

Starting from the second half of the 1920s, the area was affected by the expansion of the city. There was also the culverting of streams over which buildings and structures were constructed. The city's expansion and the covering of the Bisagno in the 1930s contributed to an increase in critical issues.

The 2014 flood that hit the Borgo Incrociati neighborhood is described in the events of the novel "Forty Nights and Then Tomorrow" by Sergio Grea. The event is mentioned in the song "Il filo rosso," a famous song by the Genoese singer-songwriter Alfa.

Whole_Text.content: The Great Flood of Meiji 43 (1910) was a major flood that struck 1 prefecture and 15 provinces in eastern Japan in August 1910 (Meiji 43). Due to the overlapping of the rainy season front and two typhoons, heavy rains caused rivers to overflow, resulting in 769 deaths, 78 missing persons, and approximately 5,000 houses completely destroyed or washed away in the Kanto region alone. In Tokyo Prefecture alone, about 1.5 million people were affected by this great disaster. As of August 8, "Heavy rains hit the Tokai, Kanto, and Tohoku regions, turning the entire Kanto area into a quagmire. Record-breaking torrential rains following prolonged rainfall caused river overflows and landslides to occur one after another, resulting in 1,357 deaths and missing persons, 2,765 houses completely destroyed, and 3,832 houses washed away."

The flatlands of present-day Tokyo's 23 wards were originally tidal flats and low wetlands, which were made habitable through land reclamation and flood control projects after Tokugawa Ieyasu's arrival. Tokyo (Edo) is inherently vulnerable to flooding, and as a result of projects like the Tone River eastward diversion, which aimed in part to address flood control, some areas, such as the former Katori Sea region downstream of the Tone River, became prone to flooding as a trade-off. Up until then, flood control, as seen in examples like the Nakajo embankment, was based on the premise of allowing flooding while protecting key areas, and although floods such as the Edo Flood of Kanpo 2 (1742) occurred frequently, they were not considered a major issue. However, after the Meiji Restoration, as modern infrastructure development progressed and the damage costs increased, it became increasingly difficult to gain understanding for such flood control measures based on the premise of flooding, as they imposed further burdens on regions already suffering from flood damage.

In August 1910 (Meiji 43), heavy rains caused by the rainy season front that had persisted since around August 5, combined with a typhoon that approached the Japanese archipelago on the 11th, grazed the Boso Peninsula, and moved out over the Pacific Ocean, as well as another typhoon that made landfall near Numazu on the 14th and passed through Kofu and western Gunma Prefecture, brought torrential downpours to various parts of the Kanto region. Rivers in the Tone, Arakawa, and Tama river systems overflowed extensively, causing levees to collapse in various locations. The damage in the Kanto region included 769 deaths, 78 missing persons, 2,121 houses completely destroyed, and 2,796 houses washed away. Gunma Prefecture, which suffered the most damage, recorded 283 deaths, 27 missing persons, and 1,249 houses completely destroyed or washed away. In addition to the left bank of the Tone River and downstream areas such as Gunma Prefecture, the right bank, which had been thoroughly reinforced after the major eruption of Mount Asama in 1783 (Tenmei 3), also saw the critical Nakajo levee collapse, causing floodwaters to flow through Saitama Prefecture and reach Tokyo Prefecture, leaving the entire Kanto Plain literally submerged. Even in Tokyo, the low-lying areas were flooded for some time, and records show that a relief station (now Asakusa Hospital) was established at Sensoji Temple.

In Saitama Prefecture, a dispute arose over the restoration of the Nakajo embankment, which had collapsed due to the flood. The conflict was between the group, including Shimogō in the Kitakatsushika District and the Minami and Kita Saitama Districts, advocating for reinforced restoration, and the Kamigō area, which demanded the traditional maintenance of the Nakajo embankment along with the construction of embankments on the upper Tone River. The prefectural assembly fell into chaos, and local residents dissatisfied with the mediation proposal presented by the governor clashed violently with the police force, leading to repeated disputes in the prefectural assembly. Ultimately, consideration was given to the demands of the Kamigō area, which had suffered from flood damage, and the height of the Nakajo embankment was maintained as before. For the reinforcement advocated by the Shimogō area, the width of the embankment was expanded, the narrow sections at Sakamaki and Setoi were widened, and the restoration was carried out based on a continuous embankment method. This necessitated revisions to the Tone River improvement project that had already begun, resulting in significant changes such as a review of the planned flood discharge volume and an increase in the diversion volume to the Edo River.

Additionally, this major flood caused significant damage in Tokyo, with 1.5 million victims, leading the Tokyo Prefecture, which had not previously borne the cost of flood control for the Tone River, to take on local flood control expenses like other prefectures in the basin. Regarding the Arakawa River, a large-scale improvement plan was formulated, and the following year, the Arakawa Floodway project was initiated, involving the excavation of a floodway 500 meters wide and 22 kilometers long from Iwabuchi to the Nakagawa River mouth. Although the project faced extreme difficulties due to the economic downturn caused by World War I and the Great Kanto Earthquake, it was completed in 1930 (Showa 5) with the mobilization of a total of 3.1 million workers, utilizing steam excavators and dredging ships.

Article_Name: Aiguats de la conca del Segre de 1982 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.header: Floods of the Segre basin in 1982
Whole_Text.content: The floods of the Segre basin in 1982 were a flood that took place between November 7 and 8, 1982, due to the rain that fell that night and culminated in the overflow of the Segre River and the Valira River. The affected areas were Andorra and the regions through which the Segre River flows, from Lleida to Cerdanya, also causing damage to the Noguera and Llobregat basins. It was especially tragic in Alt Urgell and Baixa Cerdanya. The floods left 14 fatalities, roads cut off, and collapsed bridges. Additionally, they caused a significant economic crisis. The Molina observatory reported figures of 600 liters per m², and in La Seu d'Urgell, 102 liters per m². In Alt Urgell, there were forty isolated villages and thirty collapsed bridges. Neither the Barcelona newspapers nor television reflected the magnitude of the catastrophe, focusing instead on the coverage of Pope John Paul II's visit. The airport of La Seu d'Urgell became the link between the city, the region, and Andorra with the outside world. The airport recorded up to 146 flights between planes and helicopters. In Baixa Cerdanya, the flood swept away the road from La Molina as it passed through Alp. In Martinet, it destroyed five or six houses. In Alt Urgell, the flood left the city of La Seu d'Urgell cut off, collapsing the bridges crossing the Valira and the Palanca bridge. The village that suffered the most damage was Pont de Bar, built in a narrow area near the Segre, which was completely submerged by the floods, forcing its reconstruction far from the old village. Half the village was buried by a mountain landslide, and the water also destroyed many houses; it also swept away the remains of the millennial bridge of Sant Ermengol, which gave the village its name. Years later, the river was channeled as it passed through the Segre River. In 2007, 25 years later, a plaque was placed in memory of the victims at the entrance of the Parc Olímpic del Segre, on the steps of the tannery. On the plaque, it is written, "Such a great deluge of water came..."

The river's rise began on November 7th. By three in the afternoon, firefighters were already on alert and started evacuating people living near the river. An hour later, news arrived from across the region about the abnormal rise of all springs and wells, with mentions of "water volcanoes." Three hours later, the water had already unleashed itself. At Pont de Bar (now Pont de Bar Vell), the doors of the power station were sealed, and at night, the water level suddenly rose by two meters, sweeping away the workers' house, though they were not there at the time. In the evening, given the magnitude of the rise, the Emergency Board was established, coordinated by the City Council of La Seu d'Urgell and other organizations. On November 8th, in the early morning, the Adrall bridge on the Cantó road collapsed, and at 1:45 PM, it was reported that the Oliana reservoir was completely full. Between La Seu d'Urgell and Alàs, the usual width of the Segre River is 30 meters; that day, it was 400 meters wide and exceeded its normal level by five meters, reaching fourteen meters in Organyà. Five people had been isolated since Sunday (the 7th) on a farm in Montferrer; they had to climb onto the roof as the river was eroding the house. The Civil Guard helicopter, which was supposed to come from Zaragoza, did not arrive, but they were eventually rescued, along with one person in Salit, by a second French helicopter mobilized through arrangements by the Mitra in Andorra. A firefighter boat rescued a girl who had climbed a tree in Ponts, and the French helicopter went to La Massana following reports of gas explosions and cars falling into the Valira while fleeing danger. On Monday, information was gathered about blocked roads, isolated towns, and the provision of essential services to the cut-off villages. In the evening, false rumors began circulating about the collapse of a dam in France, and in Oliana, the evacuation of the lower part of the town was ordered. On the 9th, efforts were made to secure raw materials, and an air bridge was established between La Seu d'Urgell airport and Barcelona. Among other actions, patients were evacuated, and medicines and food were delivered. A total of 10 helicopters were operational, with three soldiers equipped with radiotelephones in each village that was cut off from communication. To reach Andorra, alternative routes through the high mountains had to be used, and SAR helicopters evacuated tourists. In Alt Urgell, it was ensured that milk from isolated villages could reach tanker trucks. Some procedures were described as peculiar, such as the Taús hose, used to send milk down the ravine. On Wednesday, rumors circulated about a landslide at Pont de Bar, claiming that if it occurred, it would create a dam that would multiply the effects of the previous floods. As a result, the mountain was studied day and night by geologists. On the 11th, Os de Civís, Taús, Tuixent, and Ossera were still isolated. In Os, a group of forty soldiers cleared paths with picks and shovels. Complaints about the lack of television and political coverage were significant, although on that same day, Jordi Pujol, then president of the Generalitat of Catalonia, visited La Seu d'Urgell. On Friday, a public notice was issued refuting TVE's information about the risk of a landslide at Pont de Bar. The rumors had caused alarm downstream and even reached Lleida. In Balaguer, scenes of panic were experienced, and an evacuation order was issued. The area was declared a disaster zone through Decree-Law 21/1982. In the end, the total number of victims was twelve, although it had been said that in Andorra, there were about fifty.

The floods affected all the parishes of the country. The Valira River, from the East and the North, rose throughout the night, swallowing cars, buses, bridges, streetlights, buildings, and people. About 12 people were reported missing and 7 dead. Tourists who had come to visit the country were trapped in hotels, while the Andorran Fire Service's switchboard was overwhelmed with calls. People climbed onto the roofs of supermarkets (such as Hiper Andorra), and citizens had to be rescued with the help of tractors. Santa Coloma (parish of Andorra la Vella) was flooded. The road to Arinsal (parish of La Massana) was closed because the Andorgaz gas station had just exploded. An immediate evacuation order was issued for all buildings within 500 meters of the gas station. The country took a week to return to normal. Days after the events, there were still 1,800 tourists stranded in hotels waiting to be rescued. The disaster led to a surge in insurance claims after the floods. Policies multiplied, as did insurance companies. The country's first government, which was in the midst of transitioning to a Constitution, had to improvise. The head of government, Òscar Ribas, was caught off guard by the tragedy. While it was pouring rain in Andorra, he was in Geneva on an official trip. He was immediately informed of the chaos. It was the first time Andorra had a government and faced such a catastrophe. Poor planning in previous years regarding construction was one of the causes of the floods' severity. The headquarters of the local councils (casa comuna) were used as "control and coordination centers." The water swept away the headquarters of the Encamp council. Despite this, some citizens blamed the government and the councils for poor management. After all, four days later, Arinsal (La Massana) was still cut off. The situation fostered solidarity among the population. Everyone, to some extent, tried to help each other. Antoni Aleix, the police chief at the time, recalls that "looting in shops was minimal." It was an unprecedented situation. The head of government stayed in contact with ministers and the police until two in the morning. The Swiss Red Cross arranged a flight to Barcelona so the head of government could return to the country. Once in Barcelona, he took a helicopter. Four days after the flood, the helicopter service between Andorra and La Seu d'Urgell was suspended, and a forest track was opened as a precarious communication route. Some shopping centers offered water-damaged products at reduced prices for a long time. The situation caused by the floods raised concerns about theft. Some people took advantage of the situation, and at first, bottles of water were sold for more than double the normal price. The Central Park (Andorra la Vella) was flooded. The situation was one of hysteria and anguish, according to Jaume Bartumeu (former head of government). According to government estimates at the time, the reconstruction of damages and losses cost more than 1,000 million pesetas. Andorran schools, especially the Lycée Comte de Foix, took a long time to return to normal. The country observed several days of mourning.

Whole_Text.content: The Kaetsu Flood refers to the flood that occurred in the Kaetsu region of Niigata Prefecture on July 17, 1966 (Showa 41). In the affected areas, it is also called the 7/17 Flood.

Due to the heavy rain that occurred in the Kaetsu region from July 16 to 18, breaches occurred in various locations along the Kajikawa, Tainai River, and Arakawa, resulting in major flooding. The damage was particularly concentrated on the left bank of the Kajikawa. Floodwaters from the Kajikawa combined with overflow from Fukushima Swamp, causing prolonged inundation of nearby low-lying wetlands. The drainage at the Araigou River drainage pump station could not keep up, leading to the opening of the levee of the Aganogawa River for drainage, which was completed on August 4, 19 days later. Floodwaters on the right bank of the Kajikawa flowed toward the Ochibori River and inundated the remains of the Shiunjigata. On August 28 of the following year, 1967 (Showa 42), the Uetsu Flood (8/28 Flood, Uetsu Heavy Rain) occurred in the Kaetsu region and Yamagata Prefecture. The Kaetsu region suffered flood damage for the second consecutive year.
