Article_Name: Inundación en Santa Fe de 2007, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Santa Fe in 2007 was a meteorological event that occurred in March of that year, affecting the city of Santa Fe and surrounding areas due to heavy rainfall in the Argentine coastal region. A total of 437 millimeters of rain fell from March 26 to April 4, resulting in 26,000 evacuees.

The city of Santa Fe is located in an interfluvial zone with the Salado River to the west and the Paraná River system to the east, and features a set of streams, creeks, lagoons, and wetlands that represent 70% of the municipal district, framed within a floodplain. The rise of these has caused floods such as the one in 1983 by the Paraná and the one in 2003 by the Salado. On the other hand, the climate in Santa Fe is temperate without a dry season, according to the Köppen climate classification, with annual rainfall between 800 and 1100 mm, approximately half of which occurs between February and May. These terrestrial and climatic characteristics, along with the occupation of flood-prone lands, result in the continuous risk and water vulnerability experienced in the city.

Faced with the challenges of the water situation, the government has built a series of defenses to prevent floods and inundations. The first and most primitive of these is the defense embankment or lateral dike, an artificial earth barrier located on the riverbanks, separating the rivers from flood-prone areas. To prevent water accumulation, as it cannot flow back into the rivers due to the embankments, a set of river defense structures has been implemented, forming drainage works consisting of storm drains, pipes, and rainwater drains. This system channels water to reservoirs, areas adjacent to the embankments, which are depressed zones whose main function is to temporarily store water and later discharge it into nearby natural water currents. This discharge occurs in two ways: by gravity and by pumping. Gravity discharge is achieved through gates in the embankments that connect the reservoirs at their lowest point with a higher point in a water current. On the other hand, the pumping system operates through plants equipped with motor pumps capable of expelling water outside the defenses. By 2007, there were four pumping stations, known as pump houses, in operation, with two more lacking electrical connections. Pump house No. 1 was operating at 65% capacity, with two of its five pumps out of service; No. 3 was operating at 65%, and No. 4 at 80%. In pump house No. 2, on March 14, an explosion occurred in one of the two pumps, which, at the time of the flood's onset, had not yet been repaired. By then, 27 of the 45 available pumps were not functioning, representing 60% of the pumping system.

On April 20, 2005, the Justicialist mayor Martín Balbarrey, elected in 2003, presented the Contingency Plan for the city, detailing all the mechanisms to prevent crisis situations like the 2003 flood, with the aim of ensuring that every resident knew how to act in an emergency. The plan was prepared by official organizations and NGOs, along with neighborhood associations and specialists on the subject, and was directed by Venezuelan Pedro Zuccarini, a disaster specialist who had been assisting the city since the 2003 flood on behalf of the German Red Cross. The plan established action protocols for organizations and institutions, the dissemination of necessary knowledge among the population to know how to react, and the creation of the Risk Action Office, prepared to act before, during, and after a disaster. A year later, on March 20, 2006, Balbarrey ordered the creation of the Risk Management Subsecretariat, under the Secretariat of Water Resources, appointing Pedro Zuccarini as its head. In June 2006, Proyecto Santa Fe, a study center led by then-national Radical deputy Hugo Storero, conducted a survey of 360 people and 56 institutions in twelve neighborhoods in the west, the area most affected by the 2003 flood. According to the results, most people would not know what to do in the event of another flood, being unaware of the new Contingency Plan and the location of evacuation centers, although Zuccarini later denied the survey, claiming that "two out of five Santa Fe residents" knew the plan and were prepared. Another finding of the survey was that a majority of the institutions did not believe another flood was possible. Zuccarini traveled to his home country, Venezuela, in December 2006, initially for personal reasons and later, according to Balbarrey, to present the projects implemented in Santa Fe to other parts of the world. By February 1, 2007, he had not returned, leading to his suspension without pay, and he was ultimately removed from his position on February 21. The nine-person team of the subsecretariat continued working, divided into two groups, one in charge of fieldwork and the other of logistics. This occurred in the context of the Paraná River's rise in February 2007, which affected the residents of Vuelta del Paraguayo.

Between March 26 and April 4, the Santa Fe departments of Belgrano, Caseros, Castellanos, Constitución, Garay, Iriondo, La Capital, Las Colonias, Rosario, San Jerónimo, San Lorenzo, and San Martín; and the Entre Ríos departments of Islas del Ibicuy, Gualeguay, Gualeguaychú, and Paraná. During those days, the total rainfall was 437 mm. On March 30, 15,000 residents from the western neighborhoods of San Pantaleón, Barranquitas, Villa del Parque, San Lorenzo, Chalet, and Santa Rosa de Lima left their homes for temporary shelter centers, following Mayor Balbarrey's declaration of a red alert and preventive evacuation of the area, as it was the most affected. Although the rain had decreased, the connection between water reservoirs caused an increase in other areas of the city. The Santa Fe-Rosario highway and Route 11 were impassable. The Army, Gendarmerie, and Coast Guard were in the city to provide assistance with food supplies, relief, and security.

According to Mayor Balbarrey, the causes were the large amount of rain, which exceeded all prior precautions; and the lack of maintenance and looting of the extractor pumps installed in the western area. The proliferation of settlements in flood-prone areas, the lack of maintenance of reservoirs, and the pump system.

Whole_Text.content: The great flood in 1860, also called "ofsen," was an extreme flood that took place in Eastern Norway and had a flood peak between June 15 and 18, 1860. The flood was not as destructive as the "Storofsen" in 1789, but the water level in many places was higher or close to it. According to NVE, the flood had a volume 3-4 times that of Storofsen in parts of the Glomma River. At least twelve people are reported to have lost their lives. The flood may have been on the level of a 500-year flood. The flood occurred as a result of unusually large amounts of snow in the mountains during the winter of 1859/1860. When the snowmelt was at its peak, large amounts of rain also fell, leading to extreme flooding and widespread inundations in many parts of Eastern Norway. In this way, it resembled the "Vesleofsen" in 1995, while Storofsen was more of a rain flood. Buskerud was particularly badly affected, with loss of human lives, livestock, and bridges. Parts of Sweden also experienced major flooding. The Faluån River destroyed a large part of the buildings along its banks, and the water level in Lake Siljan rose to 3 meters above normal.

The Munich flood of 1899, referred to as the "century flood," is one of the largest natural disasters to hit the city of Munich. A flood wave of the Isar, triggered by heavy rainfall, destroyed riverbank structures in the city area as well as two large Isar bridges in September 1899, leading subsequently to a reorganization of the inner-city river area with significant riverbank fortification work and the construction of six new bridges.

Starting on September 8, 1899, heavy rainfall occurred in southern Bavaria. The rain originated from a large-scale low-pressure system that extended from North Africa to the Baltic region and from the Western Alps to the Black Sea. The transport of moist air from the north as well as from the entire Mediterranean region produced precipitation of over 500 mm at its peak across an area of more than 10,000 square kilometers. In the Isar region up to the Loisach estuary, the rainfall between September 9 and 14 averaged 400 mm, resulting in 990 million cubic meters of runoff from the 2,736 square kilometer area. Due to a relatively dry summer and a snow-poor winter in 1898/99, underground reservoirs were at a low water level, allowing parts of the rainwater to be naturally absorbed. Otherwise, the subsequent flooding would have been even more severe. Nevertheless, the rainfall led to flooding, especially in the Isar and Inn regions, by September 14. Other areas in the Alpine foothills were similarly affected, such as along the Danube and the Traun. Unlike the floods of 1954 and 2002, no double wave (resulting from separately discharged rainfall blocks) occurred in 1899, but rather a continuous, single wave. The water levels reached in 1899 were the highest ever recorded in the Isar and Inn regions.

The flood-bearing Isar caused significant damage in the Munich urban area starting on September 12. Particularly affected were the riverbank fortifications and weirs, such as the Neumüller and Montgelas dams. The young Maximilian facilities were also severely damaged. In these areas, as well as in the Isar floodplains, constructed ponds and lakes were destroyed. The Maximilianswerk hydroelectric power plant, built only in 1895, was also affected. All Isar bridges were damaged, with two collapsing. In addition to three wooden bridges, there were eight stone and two iron bridges in the city area before the flood. On September 13, the Max-Joseph Bridge (also called the Bogenhausen Bridge), a bridge built in 1876 in iron truss architecture, collapsed. The date is noteworthy, as on another September 13 during the flood of 1813, the Munich Swan Bridge (today: Ludwigs Bridge) near the present-day Museum Island also collapsed, resulting in the drowning of 100 people. After the piers of the Luitpold Bridge (also called the Prinzregenten Bridge) had already been undermined by the floodwaters for days, with significant amounts of soil at the abutments and parts of the riverbank protections washed away, it too collapsed into the Isar the following day. This steel bridge, built in a segmental arch design, had been constructed only eight years earlier. At approximately its location, the riverbed of the Isar widened from 45 to 65 meters during the flood due to bank erosion. No fatalities from the flood are known.

After the normalization of water levels, a pontoon temporary bridge was immediately constructed by military units from Munich and Ingolstadt. The destroyed Max-Joseph Bridge was replaced by an emergency bridge after the onset of winter. As a result of the destruction, the city administration decided on an extensive construction and renovation program, which between 1900 and 1905 included fundamental river regulation within the city area, the construction of extensive embankments and quay walls, as well as the renovation (profile expansion for greater water flow) or new construction of six bridges. In March 1901, the city council decided to announce a limited competition for the expansion and new construction of the bridges. The extensive new construction program included, in addition to the creation of six new Isar bridges in stone and (partially) concrete construction (Luitpold Bridge – 1901, Max-Joseph Bridge – 1902, Cornelius Bridge – 1903, Reichenbach Bridge – 1903, Wittelsbacher Bridge – 1904, and Outer Maximilian Bridge – 1905), a reorganization of the Isar area (almost continuously over a length of about 6 kilometers between the Thalkirchen rapids and the Prater weir) with regulation by enclosing the river with quay walls and dams. For cost reasons, the new bridges were constructed with a standard scaffolding and made of solid shell limestone blocks (from quarries in Lower Franconia), which is why they look similar in form with their wide-spanning bridge arches and are identical in material. The bridges were built by the construction company Sager & Woerner, and the designs were created by the architects Friedrich von Thiersch and Theodor Fischer. The previously regularly flooded Coal Island (today: Museum Island) was also fortified in such a way that it was now flood-proof.

Article_Name: Aiguat de Sant Miquel - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The Sant Miquel flood took place from September 28 to 29, 1913, and affected almost all of Catalonia, causing the overflow of numerous rivers and streams in the northeastern sector of the country. The most affected areas were Baix Llobregat, Empordà, and Penedès. The highest rainfall occurred on the 28th in Baix Llobregat with 262.0 mm in St. Feliu de Llobregat and 153.8 mm in Esplugues de Llobregat, and in Alt Penedès with 105.5 mm at the Foix Reservoir. On the 29th, the maximum values were recorded in Baix Empordà with 192.3 mm in Lladó, 181.0 mm in Peralada, and 150.6 mm in Empúries. Throughout the meteorological episode, the highlights were the 262.0 mm in St. Feliu de Llobregat and the 202.6 mm in Lladó. During those days, there was a marked surface flow, between the east and southeast, driven by a deep storm system located over Galicia with a secondary core off the coast of Algeria. Additionally, at higher altitudes, there was significant wind shear: southwest at 500 hPa, south at 850 hPa, and southeast at the surface. In general, this configuration is typically very unstable and leads to the advection of warm and very humid air into Catalonia, favoring the development of significant storms with heavy rainfall along the coast and pre-coastal areas, as occurred between September 28 and 29, 1913. Due to the large amount of rainfall, the Foix, Anoia, Cardener, Llobregat, Ripoll, Congost, Besòs, Muga, Manol, Llobregat d'Empordà, and numerous streams in Penedès, Garraf, Baix Llobregat, Barcelonès, and Empordà overflowed, causing significant damage in many places. Regarding the damage, the violent overflow of the Riera de la Salut in St. Feliu de Llobregat broke the walls of the municipal cemetery, dragging many coffins into the Llobregat River. In Vendrell, the Torrent del Lluc swept away the railway bridge, and in Cubelles, the Foix destroyed another bridge. Finally, in Empordà, all the bridges on the road from Roses to Vilajuïga collapsed due to the significant overflows of the various streams crossing that road. The consequences of this flood were visible for a long time, leaving a significant mark on the memory of the inhabitants of all the affected regions.

Article_Name: Aiguat de Santa Tecla - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The flood or torrent of Santa Tecla was a flood that occurred on the night of September 22 to 23, 1874, and mainly affected the regions of Camp de Tarragona, Conca de Barberà, Priorat, Urgell, and Garrigues. The heavy rains that fell that night caused the overflow of rivers and streams, and it is estimated that they caused around 570 deaths and the destruction of more than 700 houses. The name of this flood remained in the popular memory of the most affected regions as the flood of Santa Tecla, as this festivity falls on September 23.

Whole_Text.header: In the Camp de Tarragona and the Conca de Barberà
Whole_Text.content: The area most affected by this flood was the course of the Francolí River. In Vimbodí, the flood swept away the railway bridge, and in l'Espluga de Francolí, 24 fatalities were recorded. In Montblanc, 8 people drowned, and the force of the water carried away eleven houses, several mills, and the railway bridge. In Vilaverd, the current also swept away the railway bridge. In the Riba gorge, where the Brugent and Francolí rivers converge, the flood destroyed numerous houses and paper mills and caused fatalities. The streams running near the city of Valls also experienced surges, causing the collapse of walls and some houses. Two people were reported missing there. In the Valls area, the Francolí's surge spared the Goi bridge, a medieval-era construction. In the following days, in the areas of Rourell, Morell, Pobla de Mafumet, and Puigdelfí, numerous bodies carried away by the water were recovered. In Tarragona, it was the eve of the Santa Tecla Festival. Torrential rain fell from one to six in the morning. Around half-past two at night, the Francolí River overflowed, flooding nearby fields and demolishing an old wooden bridge and the iron bridges of the two railway lines (the Reus and Lleida line, and the Tortosa and Valencia line). The water entered the city and flooded the lower neighborhoods, causing severe damage. In the following days, numerous bodies carried away by the flood were found on the beaches and in the orchards along the Francolí River. The Gaià River also experienced a significant surge. In its upper course, the flood destroyed numerous houses in Pontils and those in the lower part of Santa Perpètua. The surge caused considerable damage along its entire course, leading to a severe flood in the Altafulla area, where it demolished the railway bridge. In Baix Camp, the streams also overflowed, destroying buildings in towns such as Reus, Riudoms, Cambrils, and Mont-roig. On the beaches between l'Hospitalet de l'Infant and Cambrils, seventeen bodies were recovered, and forty more between Cambrils and Salou.

In addition to the Camp de Tarragona, the downpour was also strongly felt in Urgell, especially in the city of Tàrrega, where the rise of the Ondara River swept away the entire Sant Agustí neighborhood, causing 150 fatalities and the collapse of 250 houses. The flood occurred at dawn, catching people inside their homes. Within the town, the water rose through the streets until it reached Sant Antoni Square. In the rest of Urgell, the Corb River also experienced a significant rise, causing destruction as it passed through Guimerà (35 deaths). In Tarròs, the water destroyed almost all the houses, causing 8 deaths. In Vilagrassa, 13 fatalities were recorded, and in Claravalls, 11. The downpour also swept away a section of the railway line between Tàrrega and Bellpuig and the bridge over the Vilagrassa stream. Between Bellpuig and Belianes, a small settlement, Eixaders, also disappeared. Near Agramunt, the Sió River carried away the aqueduct bridge, built in 1857, where the Urgell canal crossed elevated above the river. The waters, carrying all kinds of debris, blocked the arches, causing the river level to exceed 9 meters; the water flowed over the bridge and formed a large waterfall until the structure gave way. In Les Garrigues, the most affected locality was La Floresta, where the flood inundated several houses and caused the death of 10 people. Other affected towns included Vinaixa, Les Borges Blanques, and Juneda.

In Priorat, the Montsant and Siurana rivers and their tributaries also experienced significant rises. In Cornudella, the town was flooded, some houses collapsed, and half of a bridge was destroyed. In Porrera, the water uprooted vineyards and trees near the ravines. In La Vilella Baixa, the flood destroyed 14 houses and caused the death of a resident. The flow of the Ebro also increased, although not as much as on other occasions. In Ginestar, the Sant Isidre ravine flooded some houses, drowning three people. In Móra d'Ebre, two castle sentinels died from the impact of a lightning strike.

The only location with meteorological data from the downpour that day is Barcelona. Very intense NE and N winds were recorded, along with 63 mm of precipitation until 2 p.m. on the 23rd. In this city, the downpour caused a wall to collapse at the intersection of Riera Alta and Ronda de Sant Antoni, resulting in the death of a young woman. The Anoia River also experienced a significant rise, affecting numerous factories in Igualada. In Vilanova i la Geltrú, the Pastera torrent and the Miquelet stream overflowed, flooding houses, factories, and barns, but without causing any fatalities.

Article_Name: Aiguat del 10 d'octubre de 1994 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The flood of October 10, 1994, or the Sant Tomàs Flood, was an episode of torrential rains that particularly affected the regions of Camp de Tarragona, causing significant flooding and damage to road infrastructure. It began on the night of Sunday, October 9, and at 5:45 a.m. on Monday, October 10, 1994. At 8 a.m., the delegate of the Government of the Generalitat, Josep Maldonado, established the crisis coordination center with the heads of the affected departments of the regional and state administrations. By 10 a.m., there was a maximum alert, and many municipalities were already experiencing severe flooding.

The irregularity of the Mediterranean climate causes streams and ravines to go from carrying no water at all to carrying a significant amount, and at certain times of the year, especially in autumn, meteorological conditions favorable to intense downpours occur, leading to the dreaded floods. Meteorologists agree on the convergence of various conditions for them to occur: They have an orographic cause and characteristics similar to those of monsoon rains: they last a long time and can occur at any time of the day or night.

Alforja was the town that recorded the highest volume of rainfall, 403 liters/m2 in 24 hours. In the early morning, the most affected regions were Priorat, Baix and Alt Camp, and Tarragonès. In the afternoon, the heavy rains intensified in the regions of Montsià and Baix Ebre, in the southern part of the province. The heavy rains and the increase in river flow triggered Alert G – very heavy rains – across the entire province. The most affected areas were along the Francolí River, from its source in l'Espluga de Francolí to its mouth near the maritime district of Tarragona – El Serrallo. In some places, the river reached up to three meters in height, surpassing the height of some bridges and causing the collapse of five, such as in the town of la Riba, where the confluence of the Francolí and Brugent rivers caused a flood that destroyed the access bridge to the town. The PLASEQTA – Tarragona Chemical Industry Safety Plan – was also activated due to the collapse of the bridge providing access to the refinery and the municipalities of la Pobla de Mafumet and el Morell via the Valls road. The river's force caused the rupture of two pipelines in the rack transporting various chemical substances, leading to the spillage of these toxic products into the sea. In Reus, the PEM – Municipal Emergency Plan – was activated early in the morning, as most communication routes were cut off. Some flooding occurred – at the Casal de Sant Josep Obrer and Hall 4 of the Fira – the students of the Bon Soleil School (currently Collège Français de Reus) were evacuated, and two houses collapsed, but no personal injuries were reported. Water flowed with great force through all the streams, torrents, and ravines of many towns in Tarragona, but the streams of Alforja and Maspujols caused the most damage in Baix Camp. In Priorat, the need to open the gates of the Siurana reservoir increased the river flow and caused severe flooding in Porrera, which had to be partially evacuated. Power outages occurred – eight high-voltage towers fell in various municipalities – as well as disruptions to telephone, gas, train, and road services. The most significant evacuations took place in the maritime district of Tarragona – El Serrallo – and in Porrera and Poboleda in the Priorat region. Other municipalities were cut off due to the floods. Throughout the day, according to information from the delegate of the Generalitat Government, Josep Maldonado, and the civil governor, Ramón Sánchez, a total of 850 civil guards, 200 national police officers, 12 civil protection members, 80 Mossos d'Esquadra, 160 firefighters, and 4 firefighter helicopters were deployed to assist with evacuation tasks, along with personnel from various local police forces in the affected municipalities and road staff. The damage caused by the flood to the Generalitat's roads and bridges was estimated at 5,000 million pesetas, to which the regional administration added 2,000 million in damages to hydraulic works. The MOPTMA estimated losses of 1,598 million in roads and bridges under its jurisdiction, mostly in the province of Tarragona, along with the loss of construction machinery from the Tarragona park, valued at 325 million. The Tarragona Provincial Council, for its part, estimated damages to the local road network at 1,000 million pesetas.

Article_Name: Aiguats de novembre de 1983 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The November 1983 floods occurred on November 7, 1983, in the Llobregat basin with catastrophic consequences. These floods happened just one year after the torrential rain episode of November 6-8, 1982, which affected the entire country, but mainly the headwaters of the Llobregat and Segre basins with very severe overflows. The most affected areas in 1983 were the regions of Baix Llobregat, Barcelonès, and the eastern and western Vallesos, although in parts of Cerdanya, Garrotxa, and Osona, the total precipitation of the entire episode was also significant.

The most intense rainfall occurred during the early hours of November 7, especially from 03 to 07 UTC, with amounts exceeding 150 mm recorded in areas of Barcelonès, Vallesos, and Baix Llobregat during these 4 hours (220.0 mm in Terrassa-Placeta de la Creu, 217.3 mm in L'Hospitalet de Llobregat, and 188.0 mm in Terrassa-Casa Barba). The spatial distribution of the rain that morning was very irregular; for example, 217.3 mm fell in L'Hospitalet, 56 mm in Cornellà, and only 16 mm at the mouth of the Besòs. Precipitation continued to fall more moderately for the rest of the 7th and much of the 8th. The last showers, more localized, lasted until midday on November 9.[1] The maximum 24-hour precipitation values occurred on the 7th, exceeding 200 mm in parts of Vallès Occidental and Barcelonès. In Terrassa, 313.0 mm fell, and in L'Hospitalet de Llobregat, 249.1 mm fell over approximately 28 hours (from 03 UTC on 07/11/1983 to 07 UTC on 08/11/1983). Of the accumulated values during the episode (from 07 UTC on 06/11/1983 to 07 UTC on 09/11/1983), notable amounts include 333.0 mm in Terrassa, 254.8 mm in La Molina, and 252.8 mm in L'Hospitalet de Llobregat.[1] The meteorological situation during the episode was characterized by a strong surface storm from the southeast, caused by the passage of a deep disturbance present at all levels of the troposphere. This depression moved from the Gulf of Cádiz in the early hours of November 6 to Sardinia in the early hours of November 8, crossing the Balearic Islands to the south on the 7th. This storm caused a marked flow of humid and warm southeast winds at low levels and southerly winds at high levels, advecting a potentially very unstable air mass at all levels, resulting in the significant downpours of November 7 and 8.[1]

The floods on the 7th caused numerous tributary streams on the left bank of the Llobregat River to overflow violently, with the river itself also briefly overflowing in its lower course, flooding numerous fields. Notable overflows included the Riera Blanca in L'Hospitalet de Llobregat, the Riera de la Païssa in Sant Joan Despí, the Riera de la Salut in Sant Feliu de Llobregat, the Riera de Vallvidrera in Molins de Rei, and the Riera de les Arenes in Terrassa and Rubí. It is also worth noting that many streets in the city of Barcelona turned into torrents of water due to the heavy intensity of the rainfall, flooding basements and garages. This episode of torrential rains had a significant social impact, especially in the riverside towns of Baix Llobregat, as it occurred just one year after the major floods caused by the rains from November 6 to 8, 1982, the damages of which had only recently been repaired, with many improvement works still pending. All of this created a notable sense of helplessness among the entire population.

Article_Name: Rierada de Cambrils del 1994 - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The Cambrils Flood of 1994 was an overflow of the Alforja stream as it passed through Cambrils on October 10, 1994, during a series of heavy rains that particularly affected the Camp de Tarragona. The bridge crossing the mouth was cut off on both sides, as the water carried away a section of asphalt and caused the collapse of part of the terrain. The flood caused one fatality, Pere Torres Esteller.

From a quarter past 10 to a quarter to 12, the Alforja stream reached its maximum hydraulic flow, and consequently, the side roads were flooded. The water began to flow over the pedestrian walkways, which collapsed, and also reached the level of several bridges, which were left without railings. In the old town of Cambrils and some streets near the stream, such as Immolats del Setge Street, Hospital Street, and Sant Plàcid Street, were flooded. The Eixample area was also partially flooded, especially Santa Joaquima de Vedruna Street and Àngel Guimerà Street. In the port area, Jaume I Boulevard and all the streets leading to the port up to Aragó Square were also flooded. At half-past eleven in the morning, the water level began to recede. Firefighters assisted several people who had been trapped in the water currents.

There were also floods in houses and commercial premises on the affected streets, and several parking lots were completely covered with water and mud, burying the vehicles that were parked there. The streets were filled with debris and mud; specifically, Santa Joaquima de Vedruna Street was heavily affected in the initial section near the stream, which was rendered unusable for a few days, and the underground parking located there was filled to the ceiling with water and mud. A lot of debris floated in the sea, both inside and outside the port. The amount of sediment carried by the flood formed a small delta at its mouth. Likewise, the streambed suffered numerous damages: two collapsed bridges, broken walls, rows of trees swallowed, and collapsed sidewalks. The Maspujols stream also overflowed and caused a partial collapse of the bridge on the road leading to Salou and the destruction of part of the facilities of the Cambrils Beach campsite. In the afternoon, the city council convened an extraordinary meeting in which various alert measures were established in case another eventuality occurred, and it was decided, among other measures, to request the classification of Cambrils as a disaster area. The initial damage assessment estimated the cost at 500 million pesetas, as in addition to the destruction of part of the stream's channeling and the bridges crossing it, there was damage to the road network, electrical installations, potable water pipelines, and the sewage system. The channeling of the stream had to be completely rebuilt, and the opportunity was taken to improve the foundation of the retaining walls in the final section and to cement the last stretch of the streambed to prevent erosion.

Article_Name: Plena d'en Gelat - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The Plena d'en Gelat is the popular name given to an extraordinary flood of s'Albufera de Mallorca and sa Pobla, which took place in November 1852. As a result, a new outlet of the lagoon was opened, known since then as s'Oberta, and this event prompted the long-proposed project to drain s'Albufera to finally be carried out. At the time, it was estimated that 100 million m³ of water accumulated over s'Albufera, and at the Son Amer estate, the water mark reached 20 spans (4 meters) above the ground, 6 above sea level. The characteristics of the episode correspond to a combination of torrential flows from the headwaters, extreme rainfall over the affected area, and marine phenomena similar to those caused by a storm surge, all exacerbated by an insufficient outlet of s'Albufera.

The rain began on November 30, Saint Andrew's Day, and persisted the following day, and it must have been widespread across the island, as the torrents were full. The Torrent of Búger overflowed, flooding Sa Pobla through Carrer Major. Around the village, near the Muro road, the water reached a meter high (up to the bellies of the animals, according to witnesses). Simultaneously, there was a strong easterly or southeast storm at sea, with very high waves, which prevented the accumulated water and the water running through the torrents of Sant Miquel and Muro from flowing out through the natural outlet of S'Albufera at Els Ponts. Eventually, the enormous amount of water, trapped between S'Albufera and Sa Pobla, broke through a dune barrier, creating a breach 200 paces long and 5 fathoms deep (~260×~4 m.), at the same spot where the Canal Gran now flows out, more than three kilometers from the previous outlet. This allowed the accumulated water to drain. The flood did not cause human casualties, but many animals, especially oxen and mares, perished. The effects were felt as far as Ciutadella, where the red water (aigua roja) from the great flood reached. The ditches, which often served as boundaries between properties, were filled with silt, and it was not possible to identify the limits of rural properties until several days later.

The popular name given to the flood, a term that indicates the filling of the basin of s'Albufera rather than the overflow of the watercourse, is attributed to Bartomeu Company Serra, nicknamed Gelat. Gelat and his cousin Pere Serra, alias Garrut, who were shepherds by profession, were sent at midnight on the 30th to retrieve the mares grazing in s'Albufera by their owners. On their way back, at the Son Fornari marsh, the flood prevented them from continuing, and to save themselves, they climbed onto a haystack made up of 1,200 bundles of reeds they found at the Hort dels Noguers. They spent 30 hours up there, much of it standing, with water up to their chests and tied to each other with the halters they carried for the animals, until the water receded. The haystack was not moved by the runoff because it was supported by the buttress of a canal and secured with ropes tied to large perforated stones that anchored it. Surviving under such extreme conditions, when everyone thought they were dead, etched the episode into the collective memory of the locals, becoming part of the local collective imagination.

Whole_Text.content: The flood in Sochi was a natural disaster that occurred in the city of Sochi and throughout the Sochi and Adler districts of Russia in June 2015, when nearly two months' worth of rainfall fell within a day. As a result of the downpour, the maximum water level in local rivers was exceeded by more than 1.2 meters. The railway station and airport were flooded, and their operations were suspended. The most common explanation for the catastrophic scale of the flood is the malfunctioning storm drainage system, which was "reconstructed" during preparations for the Winter Olympics—reconstruction that was mostly done on paper, with funds embezzled. The chief editor of "BlogSochi," Alexander Valov, claims that during the construction of Olympic facilities, many natural water drainage channels, which could have carried away water during heavy rains, were destroyed. Additionally, one of the reasons for the catastrophic flood, he says, was that pumps meant to drain rainwater stopped working due to power outages. Sochi began experiencing flooding in September 2013—during the construction of Olympic facilities—and again in July 2014.

Whole_Text.content: The Alpine flood of 2000 is a natural disaster that occurred in October 2000 in the Central Alps. The damage event primarily affected the Italian region of Piedmont and the Swiss cantons of Ticino and Valais.

The general weather situation in mid-October 2000, with the stable low-pressure system Josefine over the British Isles, caused a continuous flow of mild, humid air from North Africa over the Mediterranean to the southern edge of the Alps from October 10 to 16. The air was forced to rise at the mountains, which led to prolonged, widespread heavy rainfall starting on October 11. Initially, the Piedmont region was primarily affected, but when the wind direction at the southern edge of the Alps shifted to the northwest on October 13, the rain also reached regions beyond the main Alpine ridge in Valais. The heaviest rainfall occurred on October 13 and 14 in the Domodossola region and at the Simplon Pass, and then from October 14 to 15 in some southern side valleys of Valais. A rainfall maximum of 580 mm was measured at Lago Paione on October 14. On October 16, the cold front moved eastward, and the precipitation subsided.

The rainfall caused one of the most severe flood events in recent history in Piedmont. It rained heavily and persistently in all the major Alpine valleys of Piedmont, from the Susa Valley through the Aosta Valley, the Lanzo Valley, and the Canavese to the Sesia Valley and the Eschen Valley, resulting in widespread flooding throughout the Po Basin. In addition to immense property damage, there were 23 fatalities, 128 injuries, 11 missing persons, and around 40 homeless individuals. In the upper reaches of the Po, the Pellice Valley was particularly affected by the flooding; in Moncalieri and Turin, city districts near the Po were flooded, with the river at Turin temporarily carrying 2,300 cubic meters of water per second, significantly exceeding the severe flood of 1994. It was the largest flood in Turin since 1839. During the flood, bridges over the Orco collapsed at Noasca and Bardonetto, the bridge over the Stura at Robassomero, a railway bridge at Ivrea (Settimo Vittone), and additional road bridges in the Canavese were destroyed by the water. In the Po plain below Turin, the side dikes of the Po broke in several places, and numerous towns were flooded; the flood zone extended downstream to an area in Lombardy and Emilia-Romagna.

The water level of Lake Maggiore reached its highest level since 1867. The lake flooding was due to the strong inflow of the Toce in Italy, in whose catchment area a rain center was located. In contrast, the Maggia and the Ticino did not bring any unusual floods to the lake. On October 14, the lake overflowed its banks and slowly flooded the old town of Locarno. By October 17, the water kept rising and eventually reached a record level that had not been measured in the 20th century. The flooding of Lake Maggiore affected not only Locarno in Ticino but also residential and commercial areas, sports facilities, public buildings, wastewater treatment plants, and clinics in the municipalities of Ascona, Brissago, Gordola, Minusio, Muralto, Tenero-Contra, and Gambarogno. It was only on October 25 that the water had flowed from Sesto Calende into the Ticino River towards the Po, allowing the lake to retreat back into its normal basin.

In the canton of Valais, the weather event affected the entire Rhone catchment area above Lake Geneva. The rain led to the most severe flooding in Valais in the 20th century. On October 14 and 15, numerous streams and rivers in the canton overflowed their banks, large areas were flooded, debris flows destroyed numerous houses and buried villages and transport infrastructure. Sixteen people lost their lives in Valais due to the event. Near Stalden-Neubrück, a debris flow destroyed five buildings and disrupted the cantonal road and the Brig-Visp-Zermatt railway line; the Vispa, which was dammed by the debris flow, flooded the Stalden wastewater treatment plant. Below Zermatt, a lake formed due to a debris flow, submerging several buildings. The BVZ railway line between Brig and Zermatt was interrupted in several places and could only be reopened after 24 days. Debris flows destroyed houses and disrupted transport routes in Mörel, the Binntal, Naters, and Baltschieder. In Baltschieder, the Baltschiederbach flooded a settlement area of 733,000 square meters, leaving debris deposits up to four meters high in the upper part of the village, while water and electricity supplies as well as telephone lines were destroyed. Between Brig-Glis and Visp, the Gamsa flowed onto the construction site of the A9 motorway and over the railway lines of the SBB and BVZ. As a secondary consequence of the heavy rainfall in Upper Valais, severe flooding occurred in Lower Valais. In Sion, the Vissingen Canal overflowed its banks and flooded a commercial district. Near Chamoson, the right bank of the Rhone levee broke, exposing the gas pipeline of the Gazoduc du Rhône, which lay unprotected above ground. Through the breach in the levee, water flowed into the Rhone plain, washing debris and mud onto agricultural land. A levee on the canal from Sion to Riddes also broke, and water overflowed from the canal from Leytron to Fully. The commercial district of Saillon, with several wineries, was flooded. In total, 1,027 hectares in the Rhone plain were eventually under water during the event.

The most severe single disaster affected the village of Gondo. A landslide above the village caused a protective wall to collapse on October 14, and the large mass of rock, earth, and debris from the wall hit several buildings below and slid further down into the Doveria gorge, which was experiencing flooding due to the rain. Ten houses were destroyed, and 13 people lost their lives. The three-hundred-year-old Stockalper Tower was damaged. Along the Doveria and the Grosses Wasser river in the Zwischbergen Valley, the flooding also destroyed protective structures and riverbank reinforcements.
After the severe Rhone flood of 2000, detailed planning for the third Rhone correction in Valais began.

Near Chamoson, the right bank of the Rhone dam broke, exposing the gas pipeline of the Gazoduc du Rhône, which lay unprotected above ground. Through the breach in the dam, water flowed into the Rhone plain, washing debris and mud onto agricultural land. A dam on the canal from Sion to Riddes also broke, and water overflowed from the canal from Leytron to Fully. The commercial district of Saillon, with several wineries, was flooded. In total, 1,027 hectares in the Rhone plain were eventually under water during the event.

The most severe single disaster affected the village of Gondo. A landslide above the village caused a protective wall to collapse on October 14, and the large mass of rock, earth, and debris from the wall hit several buildings below and slid further down into the Doveria gorge, which was experiencing flooding due to the rain. Ten houses were destroyed, and 13 people lost their lives. The three-hundred-year-old Stockalper Tower was damaged. Along the Doveria and the Grosses Wasser river in the Zwischbergen Valley, the flooding also destroyed protective structures and riverbank reinforcements.
After the severe Rhone flood of 2000, detailed planning for the third Rhone correction in Valais began.

Floods in Serbia occurred after heavy rainfall and a strong cyclone that affected the central part of the Balkan Peninsula in the second half of May 2014. The rainfall covered the entire territory of Serbia, with over 100 liters of rain per square meter falling within 24 hours. Absolute precipitation records were noted on May 15 in Belgrade (107.9), Loznica (110), and Valjevo (108.2). More than 30 people lost their lives due to swollen rivers, landslides, and water. A state of emergency was declared on May 15.

Cyclone Tamara (also Donat in Croatia or Yvette in Central Europe) affected the region of Central and Southeastern Europe on May 13, 2014. It spanned a large horizontal area, with a vertical thickness of several kilometers throughout the troposphere. A low-pressure field formed over the Adriatic when cold and moist polar air penetrated the Mediterranean region. This polar front collided with a moist subtropical front, leading to the formation of very low pressure. During May 14, the cyclonic field moved towards the Balkans and "stagnated" over the areas of Serbia, Croatia, and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The air mass saturation was around 100%, and humidity increased due to warm air from the south and east. The development of such a low-pressure field was also favored by the physical-geographical specificity of the Balkan Peninsula. The center of the cyclonic field was over Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, where between May 13 and 15, a large amount of precipitation was recorded, the highest ever recorded since meteorological observations began. The weakening and disappearance of the cyclone began on May 16 and concluded on May 18.

Heavy rain caused by a cyclone over the Balkan Peninsula fell almost continuously between May 13 and 16 in Serbia and neighboring countries. Over 100 liters per square meter were precipitated within 24 hours, and a total of over 200 liters of water sediment fell over three days - the most in Valjevo, Belgrade, Loznica, and Novi Sad. The large amount of rainfall led to the occurrence of torrential flows, flooding, and numerous landslides. This was also the rainiest May in history. The multi-year average for this time of year is about 70 millimeters of precipitation; however, in 2014, as much as 214 liters per square meter fell (Belgrade).
The tables provide an overview of municipalities by districts that were partially or completely flooded:[13]

On May 14, severe weather caused flash floods and rivers to overflow their banks. This led to the declaration of a state of emergency in 16 municipalities in Serbia. The Kolubara River overflowed along with its tributaries Ljig and Kacer, followed by the Bolec River, Skrapež, Jadar, and the Western Morava. Lower areas near rivers were flooded in Valjevo, Lajkovac, Ub, as well as in the municipalities of Ljig and Gornji Milanovac, Kosjerić, Loznica, the vicinity of Novi Sad (Petrovaradin, Futog), as well as in Mala Moštanica and Mislođin. Rescue teams evacuated several dozen citizens from areas affected by heavy rainfall.

During the night between May 14 and 15, rescue services evacuated over 500 people from affected areas. A state of emergency was declared across the entire territory of Serbia. In Topola, a firefighter lost his life during a rescue operation. Heavy rainfall caused the Kolubara River to overflow near the coal mining basin, leading to a work stoppage. Over 85,000 people across the country were left without electricity, and a large number of houses and homes were flooded. Due to the large amount of water and landslides, certain parts of the Loznica municipality were cut off. Due to the critical situation in the country, representatives of several European countries offered humanitarian aid, with Russia and Slovenia being among the first.

The situation significantly worsened on May 16 when several towns and places were left without electricity, including Lazarevac, Paraćin, Smederevska Palanka, as well as parts of Šabac and Obrenovac. During the day, a large amount of water overflowed from the Kolubara River, flooding Obrenovac and its surroundings. The evacuation of the entire town and neighboring settlements began, involving numerous rescue services and units (army, gendarmerie, firefighters, etc.). Obrenovac was covered with water several meters high. Due to heavy rainfall, the Sava River level was rising in the areas of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croatia. Following a public call, a large number of volunteers from all parts of Serbia gathered and were sent to Šabac and Sremska Mitrovica to build dams and embankments along the banks. In most areas where electricity supply was disrupted, water was not drinkable. By the end of the day, 15,200 people were evacuated from the affected areas, most of them from Obrenovac. The situation was critical in Svilajnac, Paraćin, Krupanj, and many other places, where most settlements were flooded or cut off due to landslides and mudslides.

On the night between May 16th and 17th, over 10,000 volunteers participated in building sandbag barriers in Šabac and Sremska Mitrovica. People near the embankments were evacuated as a precaution. A difficult situation occurred in Krupanj, where around 200 houses collapsed due to landslides, and communication was hindered. Ljig was without electricity and water. A large number of landslides were activated in all affected areas. Water partially receded from Gornji Milanovac, Trstenik, Koceljeva, and Svilajnac. The Velika Morava River overflowed near Varvarin and close to Ćićevac. Water penetrated the surface mines of the Kolubara coal basin - Veliki Crljeni and Tamnava-West Field. By the end of the day, a total of 16,300 people were evacuated, mostly from Obrenovac and Barič.

On May 18, a cyclone that caused heavy rainfall in Serbia and the region moved towards the southern part of the Mediterranean. In the area of the Požarevac municipality, the Mlava River overflowed. The water threatened the Kostolac thermal power plant and the Drmno coal mine. The water level in Obrenovac decreased, but the evacuation continued. For health and safety reasons, entry into Obrenovac was prohibited without special permission.

About 25,000 people were evacuated from the flooded areas. People were evacuated from the surroundings of Sremska Mitrovica and Šabac, as well as from the villages of Morović and Višnjićevo in the Šid area. Volunteers and special services reinforced the embankments on the Sava, Mlava, and Kolubara rivers. In Belgrade, embankments were preventively set up in the municipalities of Savski Venac, Stari Grad, Čukarica, Novi Beograd, and Palilula. Due to the rising water levels of the Sava River in the village of Zabrežje, a complete evacuation of Obrenovac was initiated.

During May 20, the water levels of the Sava and Danube rivers were rising. A total of over 30,000 people were evacuated. Entry into Obrenovac was prohibited for everyone except teams involved in cleaning and terrain rehabilitation. Defensive embankments in Kostolac were reinforced to protect coal mines and the thermal power plant. At Đerdap, the reservoir was emptied to prepare for the incoming water wave. Due to the rising water levels of the Danube, the population in the coastal area of the Smederevo municipality was evacuated. The Government of the Republic of Serbia declared May 21, 22, and 23 as days of mourning.

The level of the Sava River dropped by about 10 centimeters. The level of the Danube was rising, so regular flood defense was declared in Novi Sad and Golubac. Villages around Obrenovac (Mislođin, Draževac, etc.) received water for technical use. In Smederevo, emergency flood defense was declared, and the city port was submerged. Volunteers and services continued strengthening existing embankments, building new ones, and repairing those that had given way. Evacuation in Obrenovac continued. A total of 2,260 buildings were flooded in Serbia by May 21.

On May 22, a partial return of the population to the flooded areas began. Residents of Barič were allowed to return to their homes, and some residents of Obrenovac (men) came to their town to help with damage repair and cleaning. The water level of the Danube rose near Bačka Palanka, Novi Sad, Slankamen, Pančevo, and Zemun, and the level of the Tisa increased near Titel. After seven days, electricity was restored in Obrenovac, and coal excavation from the Kolubara basin for the needs of TENT resumed. Gendarmerie units and special sanitation teams continued cleaning the flooded areas of mud, bulky waste, and animal carcasses.

The water level of the Bosut River and its tributary, the Studva, rose by 10 millimeters every hour in the territory of Serbia due to the large amount of water flowing in from Croatia. During the night between May 22 and 23, the Mlava River breached a levee near Kostolac. In Rakovica, a landslide caused by a slope collapse covered the road near the Straževica tunnel, but it was quickly cleared. Smederevska Palanka regained water supply after eight days. A total of around 38,000 residents were evacuated, 25,000 of whom were from the Obrenovac area. The state of emergency in Serbia was lifted, but it remained in effect in two cities and 17 municipalities still affected by the floods (Sremska Mitrovica, Šabac, as well as Obrenovac, Ljig, Krupanj, Ub, Lajkovac, Smederevska Palanka, Osečina, Paraćin, Mionica, Svilajnac, Kosjerić, Bajina Bašta, Mali Zvornik, Koceljeva, and Vladimirci).

The state of emergency has been lifted in Trstenik, and the population has begun returning to their homes. The Sava and Danube rivers were stagnant, and emergency flood defense was declared in Zemun. Rehabilitation and cleaning in Obrenovac continued, and due to numerous landslides on the Loznica-Ljubovija road near Mali Zvornik, the construction of an alternative road 11 km long has begun.

The level of the Danube and Sava rivers was decreasing. After ten days, electricity production was resumed at the Nikola Tesla A thermal power plant. Classes in primary and secondary schools in Ćuprija were restored. In Krupanj, a dam at the Stolice antimony mine broke, leading to the spillage of toxic tailings and a potential environmental issue.

Due to heavy rainfall between May 25 and 26, several houses in the municipality of Grocka were flooded. The Gročica River and the Begaljica Stream in Zaklopača overflowed. Heavy rains also flooded the center of Pančevo. In Smederevska Palanka and Loznica, the state of emergency was lifted due to the improvement of the general situation in the territories of those municipalities. In Kragujevac, over 50 liters of rain fell, leading to the flooding of several industrial facilities and residential houses, especially in the neighborhoods of Beloševac and Lekina Bara. Due to the situation, a state of emergency was declared in the city's territory. In the settlement of Bresnica, the Bresnica Stream overflowed, and in the Zastava Arms factory, part of the production facility was flooded.

As a consequence of heavy rains and floods, numerous landslides have been activated across Serbia, a large number of residential and commercial buildings have been submerged, over 1,000 have been damaged or endangered, and more than 30,000 residents have been evacuated from the affected areas. The preliminary estimated damage amounted to around 1,000,000,000 euros. The table above shows rivers and streams by hydrographic basins (Sava, Morava, Danube) that overflowed between May 14 and May 21, 2014. More than 60 watercourses overflowed in areas affected by the floods.

Due to heavy rainfall, hundreds of landslides have been triggered across Serbia. In Mali Zvornik, a landslide covered the main road. In Bajina Bašta, landslides destroyed and endangered around 300 houses. In Kosjerić, over 600 landslides were recorded, and in Gornji Milanovac, around 300. In Krupanj, soil movements combined with torrents caused significant damage and affected over 500 homes. Landslides have also been activated in the municipalities of Požega, Čačak (100), Kraljevo (60), and Valjevo (100). In Belgrade, the area along the Sava and Danube rivers from Barič to Karaburma and further to Ritopek is at risk. Landslides have also occurred in the Ljig municipality, where 50 houses were destroyed in the village of Ba. Apart from the most affected areas, landslides have also been triggered in the vicinity of Niš (Gabrovac, Gornji Matejevac), near Bojnik, Medveđa, and Lebane, as well as in parts of the Pčinja District.

Floods and landslides damaged and destroyed about 4,500 km of roads and 250 bridges. A total of 2,260 structures (houses, buildings, industrial facilities, etc.) were submerged, and about 1,800 were endangered. Agriculture suffered significant damage, with approximately 80,000 hectares of flooded arable land, which is about 2% of the total arable land in Serbia. In the Kolubara coal basin, a dam breach occurred, and the Kolubara river overflowed, completely flooding two basins, Veliki Crljeni and Tamnava-West Field. Over 150 million cubic meters of water poured into both pits, with depths reaching 50–60 meters. Half of Serbia's total electricity production comes from the Kolubara basins. Railway traffic was disrupted on most routes due to track damage. Tracks were damaged on the Belgrade-Bar railway near Lajkovac and the Belgrade-Niš railway near Jagodina and Bagrdan, as well as between Paraćin and Ćićevac, where the flood washed away 150 meters of track. On the Prahovo-Zaječar route, the railway was buried by a landslide, as was a section near Kraljevo in the Vitanovac settlement.

Over 31,000 people have been evacuated from the endangered areas. They have been accommodated in reception centers across Serbia, mostly in Belgrade. The majority of evacuees are from Obrenovac (around 24,000), which was the most affected. The rescue efforts involved the police, gendarmerie, PTJ, SAJ, firefighters, military, volunteers, and rescuers from several countries in Europe and the region. The largest reception centers for the displaced were: Belgrade Fair (over 500), Belgrade Arena, Pionir Hall (around 250), Old and New DIF, then the Šumice Sports Center, numerous elementary schools, other sports centers, hotels, student dormitories, and others.

A large amount of water and mud that remained in the flooded areas for several days led to the development of potential sanitary problems. Warm weather and water favored the proliferation of mosquitoes, rodents, and various other pests. Contaminated water became a source of infectious diseases, such as dysentery and leptospirosis. Additionally, the flood destroyed and contaminated numerous crops and plants, and killed a significant number of livestock and other domestic animals (dogs, cats), creating conditions for other diseases. Special teams removed over 200 tons of dead animals from the affected areas.

During and after the floods, humanitarian aid was sent to the affected areas and population by a large number of individuals, organizations, associations, and countries. The aid consisted of food and water, as well as clothing, hygiene products, blankets, and mattresses. In addition, financial assistance was deposited into designated accounts of the Government of the Republic of Serbia.

Dozens of members of special teams from several European countries (Russia, Slovenia, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Germany, Austria, France, Hungary, Macedonia, Denmark, Slovakia, Romania, Montenegro, EULEX) participated in the rescue of the population. The teams were engaged in evacuating residents from endangered areas, pumping out water, transporting people, delivering aid (food, water), and more. Humanitarian aid was sent by Russia, the United Nations, the European Union, as well as Azerbaijan, Belarus, Slovenia, Montenegro, Macedonia, the Jewish Foundation, Croatia, Romania, and others. It consisted of basic human necessities, rescue helicopters, boats, special water-pumping equipment, and drying devices. In addition to state representatives, aid also came from numerous organizations — the Association of Serbs from Vienna, the Serbian-Russian Humanitarian Center, and others.

The renewal and reconstruction of flood-affected areas began with cleaning and rehabilitation of the terrain. More than 200 young people and volunteers are participating in cleaning and other necessary tasks in Paraćin, Svilajnac, Kostolac, and Krupanj.
