Article_Name: Inundaciones del río Murray en 1956, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.header: Floods of the Murray River in 1956

Whole_Text.content: Most of Australia has a very dry climate, and the central and southwestern parts of the island-continent make up the Great Australian Desert, one of the largest in the world (about 2.5 million km²). Only the northern part of the island-continent, which is already in the intertropical zone, as well as the southeastern mountains (Australian Alps), have a somewhat wetter climate. The Murray River, in turn, has an irregular flow regime and relatively low water volume, which is due to its long course through arid climate regions. Thus, although the Murray River with its tributaries (Darling, Murrumbidgee, and others) constitutes the largest river system in Australia, with more than one million km², its economic benefits for agriculture, industry, and potable water supply are not well developed, and there are possibilities to increase them through comprehensive basin planning. The Murray is a river that experiences strong floods and long periods of low water levels, so more multipurpose dams (hydroelectric, irrigation, flood control, and others) need to be built, infrastructure works need to be carried out to prevent damage in populations located mainly on the right bank of the river from the confluence with the Darling to the mouth, and areas with insufficient drainage (which in Australia are called billabongs and correspond in Spanish to terms such as abandoned meanders, oxbow lakes, marshes, or sporadically flooded areas, etc.) need to be channeled.

Whole_Text.header: Asymmetry of the Murray River basin
Whole_Text.content: When discussing the floods in the Australian Murray River basin, it should be noted that, as it is located in the southern hemisphere, any moving body, such as river water, tends to veer to the right, that is, opposite to the northern hemisphere. However, this deviation is not real but apparent, as it is not the river water that veers to the right but the Earth's surface that rotates from right to left (east to west), that is, counterclockwise. This means that, in a moving body with a constant direction (such as the Foucault pendulum), the apparent deviation would occur from left to right, or in other words, clockwise, for the simple reason that the pendulum's base, that is, the Earth's surface, rotates in the opposite direction (counterclockwise). This is why almost all the cities affected by the 1956 floods in the Murray basin were located on the river's right bank. Among the flooded cities at that time, we can mention, including their location on Google Maps: Colignan, Iraak, which no longer exists and was replaced by a lake that is now almost dried up, Mannum, Murray Bridge, Mildura, Nangiloc, whose name is written backward compared to Colignan, Red Cliffs, Renmark, Wentworth, and others. All the mentioned towns are situated on the right bank of the Murray River (except for a couple of cases where the town is divided in two by the river itself, as in Murray Bridge, although this is an exception that proves the rule because the force of the flood affected the part of the city on the right bank). The case of Iraak, which is somewhat separated from the Murray River and is now almost uninhabited, is due to the fact that it was originally a military camp during World War II (it also held prisoners), and during the 1956 floods, it was flooded, creating a lake that still exists: on one hand, the location of the place was precarious and risky and was only justified by its temporary use as a military zone. On the other hand, the floods of that year highlighted the risk of that location and worsened the initial problem: it was probably easier to dismantle the camp and relocate than to carry out infrastructure works to minimize or eliminate the risks of that location. The Google Earth program is very useful for assessing the flood risk of any location in Australia (or anywhere) since by moving the cursor over the satellite image, we automatically get the elevation in meters above sea level of any point, which can indicate how frequent a situation is where the natural levees of a river are at a higher elevation than the surrounding plain, which is precisely why it is called a floodplain. In the specific case of Wentworth, which is located on the right bank of the Darling River at its confluence with the Murray, the main reason for the flooding was not directly due to the rise of this river but because this rise dammed the waters of the Darling upstream of the confluence, overflowing to the north of the town, which was almost completely flooded for some time. In a desert or semi-desert climate, most rivers are allochthonous and can experience massive floods due to irregular rainfall, which can be very scarce for years but also very intense and disastrous on some sporadic occasions, exacerbated by the fact that the large amount of sediment carried by the river waters (due to the sparse vegetation cover in a dry climate) tends to raise the riverbed and natural levees, especially the left one, in the case of the Murray River because we are in the southern hemisphere. This is why most of the floods caused by the river's overflow occurred on its right bank.

Whole_Text.header: The anomalous meteorology in the south and southeast of Australia in 1956
Whole_Text.content: Australia constitutes an isolated continent or, conversely, an island of continental scale. It is crossed by the Tropic of Capricorn in the northern part of the country, which gives this area an intertropical climate (savanna, rainforest in some places, and especially a dry subtropical climate). Most of the territory has a desert or semi-desert climate (Australia's deserts cover more than 2 million km²), and oceanic influences are very powerful, giving rise to tropical and extratropical storms, often very intense. In the specific case of Australia, the relatively dry climate makes it irregular, with years and even decades of very scarce rainfall and brief periods (weeks or months) of extraordinarily intense rains. In 1956, a rainy period lasting a little over three months was recorded, resulting in a massive flood that reached its highest point in Morgan, South Australia, at 12.3 meters, and these floods were felt up to 100 km away from the riverbanks. In the specific case of Morgan, its location on the right bank of the river (as with the previously mentioned towns) is compounded by being situated on a 90° left bend of the Murray River, which concentrated the effects of the flood due to the natural right levee being lower than the left one in the southern hemisphere, so the centrifugal force of the river's flow at the bend was directed toward the location of this town. This location can be seen on Google Maps: Morgan, South Australia.

Article_Name: Inundación de la Ciudad de México en 1629, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The flooding of Mexico City in 1629 was an event that occurred starting on September 21 of that year, caused by a heavy rain that lasted approximately 40 hours and resulted in the total flooding of the city. The water level reached a little over two meters, and the city remained flooded for five years, from September 1629 to 1634. Of the 20,000 Spanish families living in the city at that time, only 400 remained. Viceroy Rodrigo Pacheco y Osorio, 3rd Marquess of Cerralbo, implemented several measures not only to alleviate the situation but also to prevent more people from leaving the city.

Tenochtitlan was founded in the lowest part of the Valley of Mexico, which is why its geographical location has always been the main cause of its vulnerability. Facing recurrent floods, the Mexica developed systems to control rising waters, such as retaining walls and aqueducts. With the implemented systems, they were not only able to supply themselves with clean water for consumption but also managed to prevent flooding. The Spanish, despite being aware of the existing soil subsidence problems in Tenochtitlan, decided to establish the capital of New Spain there for political reasons. In addition to the geographical location, other changes resulted in the rise of water levels: environmental changes, deforestation, and the expansion of crops that led to soil erosion. All of this contributed to the city flooding on several occasions.

After these events, the construction of the Nochistongo Cut was approved to drain the water from the city. The tunnel would have a length of 6,600 meters, a width of 3.50 meters, and a height of 4.50 meters.

When the rain began, Enrico Martínez advised Viceroy Rodrigo Pacheco y Osorio to close the outlet of the Huehuetoca drainage, which was under construction, to prevent it from being destroyed. When the viceroy realized that this was only preventing the water from flowing out, he ordered the drainage to be uncovered, but it was too late.  
The city was submerged, many houses collapsed, others were flooded, and their inhabitants could only stay on the second floor. The unsanitary conditions, scarcity, and disease that followed the flood caused the death of approximately 30,000 people in the following years. The flood also caused many people to emigrate from the city, mostly settling in the city of Puebla. The viceroy wanted to prevent more people from leaving and took several measures to provide people with confidence and reassurance that the situation would improve.

Whole_Text.header: Measures of the Marquis of Cerralbo
Whole_Text.content:
The viceroy convened a council to decide what measures would be taken. It was decided to request a loan of 6,000 pesos, which would be used to buy and distribute food daily in the most affected neighborhoods. Food would also be sold to people who could afford it but had no means of transportation. Wooden bridges were built to make it possible to cross from one building to another. Canoes were also used for transportation within the city. To prevent more houses from collapsing, it was ordered that each homeowner build a type of wall attached to their house to prevent the foundations from weakening.

The measures taken to alleviate the situation were not enough; it was also necessary to remove the water from the city. To this end, the viceroy ordered the continuation of the construction of the Huehuetoca drainage system, which, after being opened, was damaged by the water.

There was a belief that the heavy rains were a punishment for the city's sins. It was accepted that masses could be held on rooftops or balconies so that people could listen to them from their homes. On an unprecedented occasion, on September 24, Archbishop Francisco Manso y Zúñiga allowed the image of the Virgin of Guadalupe to be taken by canoe from her Basilica to the city center. Given the situation and the lack of a short-term solution, the viceroy proposed to the city council the option of relocating the capital to another city. However, the city council responded that it would cost more money to move the capital than to rebuild it. It was decided that the only viable solution would be to find an effective drainage system. In 1634, the Carmelite friar and architect Andrés de San Miguel, commissioned by the viceroy, corrected the drainage channel of Mexico City, which had been built by Enrico Martínez, allowing the water to flow out of the city and enabling its reconstruction.

Article_Name: 平成27年9月関東・東北豪雨

Whole_Text.content: The September 2015 Kanto-Tohoku Heavy Rainfall was a heavy rain disaster that occurred in the Kanto and Tohoku regions from September 9 to 11, 2015.

Typhoon No. 18, which occurred on September 7, made landfall in the Tokai region on September 9 and later became an extratropical cyclone over the Sea of Japan that night. Although the direct damage caused by this typhoon was not significant, warm, moist air flowed in from the Pacific Ocean due to the extratropical cyclone that had transformed from the typhoon moving northeast over the Sea of Japan. This collided with moist winds blowing in from Typhoon No. 17, which was approaching the Japanese archipelago from the sea east of Japan, resulting in the continuous formation of rain clouds (linear precipitation bands) stretching north to south. This caused heavy rainfall exceeding 300 mm in 24 hours, primarily in northern Kanto and southern Tohoku, leading to extensive damage.

On September 9, heavy rain centered in northern Kanto occurred, and according to AMeDAS observation data from midnight on September 7 to 5 p.m. on September 10, 24-hour rainfall by the morning of the 10th reached 551.0 mm in Nikko City, Ikari, Tochigi Prefecture, and 541.0 mm in Nikko City, Imaichi, with over 300 mm observed in various locations within Tochigi Prefecture. Additionally, total rainfall during the period was 645.5 mm in Imaichi, 622.0 mm in Ikari, 561.5 mm in Tōrobu, and 523.0 mm in Kanuma, with over 400 mm observed in various locations in Tochigi Prefecture. At 12:20 a.m. on September 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a special heavy rain warning for the entire Tochigi Prefecture, and at 7:45 a.m., a similar warning was issued for almost all of Ibaraki Prefecture. In these regions, maximum caution was urged against river flooding, landslides, and inundation of low-lying areas, while surrounding prefectures were also called upon to exercise strict caution.

The area of rainfall gradually shifted to the Tohoku region, and at 3:20 a.m. on September 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a special heavy rain warning for Miyagi Prefecture. The special heavy rain warnings issued for each prefecture were lifted at 6 a.m. on the 11th in Tochigi Prefecture, at 8:15 a.m. in Ibaraki Prefecture, and at 7:30 p.m. in Miyagi Prefecture. On September 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency named the heavy rain and the resulting disaster that struck the Kanto and Tohoku regions as the "September 2015 Kanto-Tohoku Heavy Rain." Additionally, the Geospatial Information Authority of Japan created a special page on its official website titled "September 2015 Kanto-Tohoku Heavy Rain," providing information on the disaster using data such as topographic maps and aerial photographs.

On October 6, the government decided in a cabinet meeting to designate the agricultural damage caused by the disaster as a "severe disaster" under the Act on Special Financial Assistance for Coping with Severe Disasters, and to designate specific areas in Minamiaizu Town, Minamiaizu District, and Showa Village, Onuma District, in Fukushima Prefecture as "localized severe disaster areas." This decision was promulgated and enforced on October 7. As a result, the proportion of costs subsidized by the national government for restoration work on farmland and agricultural facilities carried out by local governments was raised to a maximum of approximately 90%.

The heavy rain in Tochigi Prefecture and flooding in Ibaraki Prefecture were compared to Typhoon No. 4 in 1998. While Typhoon No. 4 in 1998 recorded torrential rain and over 1,000 mm of precipitation, the Kanto-Tohoku Heavy Rain had a total rainfall of about 600 mm, with hourly rainfall of 50–70 mm (no record-breaking short-term heavy rain information was issued during the period).

The total rainfall observed from September 7 to September 11 was 647.5 mm in Imaichi, Nikko City, Tochigi Prefecture, and 536.0 mm in Hitsupo, Marumori Town, Miyagi Prefecture, exceeding 600 mm in the Kanto region and 500 mm in the Tohoku region, resulting in heavy rain more than twice the average monthly rainfall for September.

According to the summary of damages as of October 18, 2017, by the Fire and Disaster Management Agency (including damages caused by Typhoon No. 18), a total of 20 deaths have been confirmed: 15 in Ibaraki Prefecture, 3 in Tochigi Prefecture, and 2 in Miyagi Prefecture. Additionally, there were 82 injured nationwide, 81 houses completely destroyed, 7,090 partially destroyed, 384 partially damaged, 2,523 flooded above floor level, 13,259 flooded below floor level, and 1,722 non-residential buildings damaged. It was also confirmed that breaches, overflows, leaks, flooding, and damage or collapse of embankment slopes occurred in five rivers managed by the national government and 80 rivers managed by prefectures. According to the tally announced at 5:00 PM on September 13, evacuation orders were issued to approximately 240,000 people in one metropolitan area and 19 prefectures from Iwate Prefecture to Kagawa Prefecture since September 8, and evacuation advisories were issued to approximately 3.15 million people. Even one year after the breach of the Kinugawa River embankment, 79 households and 197 residents of Joso City continue to live in temporary housing provided by the prefecture or city.

In the vicinity of Joso City, Ibaraki Prefecture, on the early morning of September 10, overflow and leakage from the embankments occurred at several locations along the Kinugawa River, and at 12:50 PM, one embankment in Misaka Town of the same city collapsed. As a result, a wide area of Joso City, sandwiched between the Kinugawa and Kokaigawa Rivers, was submerged, causing significant damage, including 2 direct fatalities, 12 disaster-related deaths, and over 40 injuries. Additionally, the Joso City Hall main building, which had just been completed in 2014 incorporating lessons from the Great East Japan Earthquake, was flooded, and more than 5,000 houses were partially or completely destroyed. In response to this incident, Joso City established a verification committee and compiled a report. 

Furthermore, at Tokyo Electric Power's Kinugawa Power Plant (Nikko City), Doyahara Power Plant (Shioya Town), and Akagawa Power Plant (Nasushiobara City), generators were submerged, and facilities were damaged, leading to a halt in power generation. Additionally, a landslide caused a transmission tower to tilt and break, cutting off power supply to the Yagan Railway Aizu Kinugawa Line, resulting in the suspension of operations on that line. Moreover, at Kinugawa Onsen in Nikko City, Tochigi Prefecture, an open-air bath of a hotel facing the Kinugawa River collapsed.

Tochigi City Riheya Elementary School and Oyama City Hanegawa Nishi Elementary School in Tochigi Prefecture announced plans to resume classes by borrowing vacant classrooms from other schools after their school buildings and gymnasiums were submerged by the flood. The second semester closing ceremony was held in hallways and music rooms as the gymnasium was under renovation and unavailable. In March 2016, the renovation of Hanegawa Nishi Elementary School's gymnasium was completed, and a reconstruction ceremony was held on March 9.

At Oyama Driving School, facilities and vehicles suffered damage, with 14 out of 18 vehicles submerged, leading to a suspension of operations. However, operations resumed on November 11, 2015.

On the 11th, the Mogami Oguni River overflowed in Mogami Town, Mogami District, Yamagata Prefecture. In Osaki City, Miyagi Prefecture, the embankment of the Shibui River in the Naruse River system collapsed, and in Tomiya Town and Taiwa Town, Kurokawa District, the Yoshida River and its tributaries, the Zen River and Chikurin River, overflowed. In Iitate Village, Soma District, Fukushima Prefecture, 395 bags containing decontamination waste from the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant accident, which had been stored in the village, were washed away due to river flooding caused by the typhoon. At least 167 of the recovered bags were found to be damaged, and it is believed that soil, grass, and other contents were lost. Additionally, the contents of two bags that were washed away as far as Haramachi Ward, Minamisoma City, were also found to have been lost.

Tobu Railway suffered damage to various lines in Tochigi Prefecture. The Tobu Nikko Line was suspended between Shinkanuma Station and Shimo-Imaichi Station due to a landslide at Shimo-Koyama Station and embankment washout between Shinkanuma Station and Kita-Kanuma Station. The Tobu Utsunomiya Line was suspended between Yatsuka Station and Nishikawada Station due to the loss of the abutment and bridge girder of the No. 2 Sugata River Overflow Bridge between these stations. The Tobu Kinugawa Line was suspended between Shimo-Imaichi Station and Shin-Fujiwara Station due to embankment washout between Shintakatoku Station and Kosagoe Station, and track ballast washout between Kosagoe Station and Kinugawa-Onsen Station. Substitute bus services and transfers to other railway lines were provided in the affected sections. Some sections of the Tobu Railway were restored by September 18, and the remaining sections were fully restored by October 7.

The Kanto Railway Joso Line was flooded between Kokinu Station and Sodo Station due to the breach of the Kinugawa River embankment, and the Mito Vehicle Base, the operational hub, was also damaged. As a result, the entire line between Toride Station and Shimodate Station was suspended. Train operations resumed between Toride Station and Mitsukaido Station and between Shimotsuma Station and Shimodate Station by September 18. On October 10, train operations resumed between Mitsukaido Station and Shimotsuma Station, but the service was significantly reduced due to emergency restoration. Full normal operations, including express services, resumed on November 16.

The Kominato Railway Line was suspended between Kazusa-Ushiku Station and Kazusa-Nakano Station due to embankment washout and other impacts between Kazusa-Okubo Station and Yoro-Keikoku Station. Train operations resumed between Kazusa-Ushiku Station and Tsukizaki Station by September 16, but the restoration of embankments and removal of landslides took time, and operations between Tsukizaki Station and Kazusa-Nakano Station resumed on October 24 of the same year.

Whole_Text.content: Iraq floods of 2015 were floods that occurred in Iraq in November 2015 in several Iraqi cities (such as Baghdad, Basra, and Kut) after heavy rainfall. The rainfall caused the sewage systems to overflow, leading to floods that submerged many areas in central and southern Iraq. These floods resulted in the death of more than 50 people due to electric shocks caused by fallen power lines in the water, which electrocuted citizens through the water.

Whole_Text.content: The St. Lucia flood was a flood that affected several European countries between December 13 and 14, 1287, and is named after the saint of the day, Lucia of Syracuse. As with other similar disasters in the area, such as the 1953 Netherlands flood, the phenomenon occurred due to the conjunction of a spring tide and a storm with low atmospheric pressure. The most severe consequences took place in Frisia, with around 50,000 direct deaths. The alteration of the terrain was such that a new sea, the Zuiderzee, was even created, which had previously been a freshwater lake, the Flevo. The force of the tide collapsed the dunes that separated it from open waters, thus creating a new oceanic inlet. Dozens of settlements disappeared under the waves, new ports were created, and the need for more protection systems for coastal areas became evident, as the dike system installed in West Frisia saved much of this region. The flood was also strongly felt in the British Isles, where the storm and waves buried entire villages. Some commercial ports, such as Dunwich, disappeared, causing significant economic losses. In the medium term, the flood contributed to migratory waves of people who no longer felt safe in coastal areas and in the newly created peatlands or who had lost everything and sought ways to make a living in inland cities. It also affected the linguistic distribution of Frisian, which saw its area of influence reduced due to the mortal victims and population movements. Due to all this impact, the St. Lucia flood is considered the fifth most significant in recorded history, both for the high number of victims and for its consequences on the landscape, economy, language, and demography over time.

Whole_Text.content: The Danube flood of 1830 in Vienna from February 26 to March 10, 1830, was an exceptionally severe flood of the Danube. It was the last major Danube flood in Vienna caused by an ice jam.

The flood inundated Leopoldstadt in today's 2nd district and other Danube-adjacent settlements such as Floridsdorf, Leopoldau, and Rossau, causing enormous damage. On February 28, 1830, drifting ice formed an ice jam near Stadlau, which broke during the night of March 1. The masses of water made their way from Leopoldau through Breitenlee, Markgrafneusiedl, Großhofen, Glinzendorf, Rutzendorf, Kimmerleinsdorf, Breitstetten, Haringsee, Straudorf, and Wagram an der Donau across the Marchfeld and flowed back into the Danube's riverbed near Stopfenreuth. A total of 74 people lost their lives due to the flood wave. Kimmerleinsdorf was almost completely destroyed. The streams of the Vienna Woods and the Wien River could no longer drain and also overflowed their banks. As a result, large parts of the city area were under water for days. However, the city was hit much harder by the subsequent cholera epidemic, which was triggered by the flooded cesspools and the contaminated groundwater. By December 1831, around 2,000 people had died from cholera.

After the flood and the subsequent cholera epidemic, all the important streams of the city were gradually vaulted and converted into stream canals (see also the history of Vienna's sewer system). This and the next major Danube flood in 1862 ultimately also gave the impetus for the Vienna Danube regulation.

The Danube flood of February 1862 was an exceptionally severe flood of the Danube. It caused particularly great destruction in Vienna and Passau.

The flood, caused by persistent thawing, inundated areas on both sides of the Danube in Vienna at the beginning of February, particularly Leopoldstadt, Brigittenau, Zwischenbrücken, Rossau, Floridsdorf, Mühlschüttel, Stadlau, the area around the Great Danube Bridge, and Langenzersdorf. In Passau, the flood reached its peak on February 2 with a level of 11.6 m.
This and the previous major Danube flood of 1830 ultimately gave the impetus for the Vienna Danube regulation in Vienna.

The flood in Skopje in 1962 occurred on November 16, 1962. Skopje, Ohrid, Struga, Titov Veles, Resen, Kichevo, Bitola, Novaci, Prilep, Tetovo, Krushevo, Bogomila, and a large number of villages and settlements in Western Macedonia were affected that day by the water disaster, which was the result of exceptionally heavy rains. The waters of the Shar Mountain basin from Bistra and other mountains that gravitate towards Treska, foamy and muddy, poured into the bed of the muddy Vardar River. Four human casualties were recorded.

Seven hundred and thirty cubic meters were flowing out of the main discharge tunnel at the Matka hydroelectric power plant, while over 70 cubic meters of water per second were flooding the dam walls. The water continued to rise, and within just 15 minutes, an increase of 4 centimeters was recorded. The power plant's machine hall was flooded, the turbo generators were shut down, and the entire Matka Lake was filled with tree logs. The lake began to overflow precisely at 11:55 a.m., passing over the dam at that time. By 1:00 p.m., it had spilled into the machine section, swept away the concrete and stone support in front of the plant as if it were a straw, and the embankment dissolved.

On November 16, 1962, throughout the entire day and the previous night, heavy rainfall occurred in the area of Skopje and its surroundings, causing major floods in Skopje, Petrovec, and Gjorce Petrov. In Skopje, four people drowned, as reported by 6 PM. The most affected areas in Skopje were the municipality of Idadija, near the City Park, the surroundings of Ilindenska Street, around the main post office, and the city square. Houses along Cvetan Dimov Street were endangered due to the overflow of the Serava River. Around 4:00 PM, all schools were dismissed. Students who lived nearby were met by their parents at the school gates, but there were children who lived far away and could not return home due to the water. At the new concrete bridge, work was halted due to the heavy rains. However, the workers did not leave their posts and, together with experts, began removing large logs carried by the dangerous currents of the Vardar River with long iron rods from as early as 3:00 AM. This bridge was supposed to be opened for use on November 29, 1962. At this bridge, the hydrometeorological service installed a water gauge. At 2:30 PM, the water level here was recorded to be eight centimeters higher compared to November 5, 1937, when the water level was 260 cm above normal, or 330 cm. Pedestrian wooden bridges, particularly those near the National Theater and the bridge located between the new concrete bridge and the railway bridge, were especially endangered. Due to their instability under the pressure of the rising waters, pedestrian traffic on them was prohibited on the morning of November 16. The railway bridge near the Military Hospital was closed to all trains, while movement on the railway bridge near Gjorce Petrov was allowed at a speed of five kilometers per hour. Only one bridge over the Vardar was safe — the Stone Bridge. The district headquarters for natural disasters immediately took measures to accommodate endangered families from the areas of Idadija and Kisela Voda in the "Kocho Racin" elementary school, while families from the municipalities of Kale and Saat Kula were accommodated in the Health Center of these municipalities. All lost children were also housed in these two points in the city. The Vardar River overflowed onto Ilindenska Street, Marshal Tito Square, the City Park, near the stadium, and everywhere the protective embankments were the lowest. Many basements were filled with water, and parts of the city were occasionally left without electricity. The water flooded the narrow and deep spaces of the "St. Andrew" Monastery, and everything in the restaurant by the Matka Lake was underwater. Villages in the vicinity of Gjorce Petrov were also affected. The dam of the new reservoir near the village of Bojane was breached. Due to the high water level of the Treska River, the lake near the Matka Hydroelectric Power Plant was overfilled, and as a result, water was gradually released to prevent danger to the dam of the lake itself. In Saraj, the camping grounds were flooded.

In Ohrid, 400 houses were submerged, Kičevo was without traffic connections, in Pelagonia many areas were flooded, and there were significant material damages in all flooded regions. In Ohrid, several thousand citizens were evacuated, and over 500 houses were flooded. All villages in Resen were underwater. Parts of Titov Veles and Kičevo were seriously endangered. Bogomila was cut off from other towns. The situation was similar in Debar. Tetovo was left without postal and telecommunications connections. Kruševo was completely isolated from the world. For two days and nights, the people of Struga fought against the massive water surge from the lake. Around Ohrid Lake: scattered boats filled with mud and various household items. In Struga, the lake overflowed and flooded the entire tourist settlement. The Sateska River flooded a large part of the Struga Field. The Jablanica River overflowed, flooding and destroying roads in several places. Due to prolonged torrential rains, the Vidobishka and Koselska Rivers overflowed, spreading 3 and 2 kilometers wide, respectively, along their entire course. These two rivers also flooded parts of Ohrid. In addition to these two rivers, the Daljan River also overflowed, spreading about 2 kilometers wide. In Ohrid, due to the rising waters, about ten houses collapsed. Since the water level rose more than a meter, the flooded houses could only be accessed by boats. Around 350 families were evacuated and accommodated in the "Bratstvo – Edinstvo" primary school, the Jugohrom hotel, and the PTT hotel. The water surge caused the collapse of several houses in Resen, Carev Dvor, Drmeni, Gorna and Dolna Bela Crkva, and other areas. All citizens aged 15 to 55 were mobilized. The village of Ezerani, south of Resen, was cut off from other settlements. Bitola and Pelagonia were underwater. After heavy rains, the Crna River rose, followed by the Šemnica, Dragor in Bitola, and Kurderes, as well as all their tributaries and village streams. In the morning, the Dragor overflowed near the slaughterhouse, and at the same time, so did the Kurderes, combining their waters and flooding a vast area near Bitola, before the railway line. Near the village of Novaci, the Crna River flooded 3,000 hectares of arable land. The waters of the Crna River also destroyed two large bridges near the village of Brod. The Vukri fish farm was damaged. Near Titov Veles, the Vardar and Topolka Rivers rose 4.5 meters above normal. The entire "Vasil Levski" street, on the left side of the Vardar, was flooded. The buildings of the "Trajko Andreev" and "Blagoj Kirkov" schools were underwater up to the first floor. At the city market, the water reached a height of one meter. Five families were evacuated on the first day after the flood. Two bridges on the Topolka were swept away. 6,000 chickens and chicks from the "Stochar" enterprise were destroyed. The Babuna River overflowed its banks. Bogomila was completely isolated from the railway station because the bridge over the Babuna could not be crossed. The water surge uprooted trees along the riverbank and flooded the football field. In Bogomila and Tetovo, several houses were flooded, and according to initial estimates, about 70 hectares of sown land were affected. Tetovo region: road and postal communications were disrupted. The rising Pena River, whose level increased by more than a meter, destroyed riverbank walls in several places and flooded the streets: "Leninova," "Mirče Acev," and "Jeni Malo." The basements of some institutions, including the Veterinary Station, were flooded. In Prilep: the Oreovečka River rose and swept away two wooden bridges in the Tabana area. In this area, one private house was endangered due to a landslide on the left riverbank. The river carried away trees and several livestock. Large areas of the Prilep Field were underwater.

In Skopje, 1,050 houses were destroyed, 157 buildings were underwater, and 4,445 citizens were left homeless; in Petrovec, nearly 4,000 hectares of fertile land were flooded. The water surge destroyed three bridges in Skopje and three in Gjorce Petrov. In Ohrid, 36 houses were destroyed by the flood, 57 were damaged, and 56 houses were inaccessible because they were filled with mud and water two days after the flood. In many cities, there was a general mobilization of the population, members of the Yugoslav People's Army (JNA), and the People's Militia, and all possible means of transportation were engaged. The department store "Skopje" reported the first material damage of 300 million dinars. It was estimated that the total damage from the flood exceeded 10 billion dinars. The sewage and water supply networks were severely damaged, and the pumping stations at Rasce and Kozle were destroyed. Saraj was completely destroyed and inaccessible. Underground waters emerged in distant areas from the Vardar River, such as near the railway station.

The building of the National Theater in Skopje was damaged, especially the electrical installations, the stage rotation mechanism, and the scenery. On the first day after the flood, teams of soldiers and firefighters were sent from Nis, Leskovac, Surdulica, Urosevac, Kosovska Mitrovica, Belgrade, Prizren, and other places. From Negotino to Demir Kapija, the Vardar River was on average 400 meters wide. Near Gevgelija, there was a lake 8 kilometers wide. In the Gevgelija area, five bridges were destroyed. Two kilometers from Gevgelija, trains "floated" 200 meters through water.

In the Tetovo area, 3,000 hectares were flooded, and eight bridges were swept away. The archival material of the film production company "Vardar – Film" was completely destroyed. The negatives of all feature and documentary films shot from 1945 until the day of the flood were completely destroyed. In the Skopje Zoo, only about 20% of the animals perished, while the rest were saved, including lions, monkeys, the elephant, the hippopotamus, the tiger, and the reticulated python. Alongside the efforts of the Yugoslav People's Army, the entire population and the People's Militia, young people joined in, significantly contributing to helping those affected by the natural disasters across all regions of Macedonia. Youth work brigades and groups were made available to the disaster response headquarters. Youth and student work groups participated in clearing damaged houses and rescuing endangered families. They began organized efforts to protect and clean schools, dormitories, and other facilities. On November 19, 1962, 3,830 young people worked to clear the streets of Skopje, while on November 20, 1962, around 5,000 young people were involved in the affected areas of Skopje and its surroundings. On the initiative of the Main and District Committee of the Red Cross and the Disaster Response Headquarters of the Idadija Municipality, a group of youth leaders and activists organized the transfer and care of children from the most affected families in the Idadija Municipality area to the Red Cross center on Vodno. In this reception center, 72 children aged 7 to 14 were transferred. Such youth engagement was also noted in other parts of Macedonia: Bitola, Titov Veles, Ohrid, Gevgelija, and other affected areas. Youth organizations also assisted in the actions of health authorities to vaccinate the population to prevent the potential spread of infectious diseases.

The Corpus Christi flood refers to a weather disaster that occurred on June 21, 1984 (Corpus Christi Day) in the Main-Tauber district of Baden-Württemberg, primarily causing torrential flooding in the areas of the municipalities of Königheim, Tauberbischofsheim, Boxberg, and Lauda-Königshofen. The town of Königheim was particularly severely flooded. Dittwar, Kupprichhausen, and Lengenrieden were also heavily affected. The total damage amounted to around 90 million Deutsche Marks.

f1 Map with all coordinates of the main affected watercourses, locations, and retention basins of the Corpus Christi flood: OSM | WikiMap The trigger of the flood was a heavy rain on June 21, 1984, of up to 150 mm, which fell over the catchment areas of Brehm- (⊙49.5580979.520383, ⊙49.6192979.668103) and Schüpfbach (⊙49.553749.571589, ⊙49.515249.693058). The rain began in the afternoon and completely flooded the partially narrow stream valleys with flood waves up to three meters high downstream.[1][2][4] Severe storms occurred in the areas of Kupprichhausen (⊙49.5269059.62103), Lengenrieden (⊙49.5279999.64004), Oberlauda (⊙49.56669.6787), Heckfeld (⊙49.551299.63651), Dittwar (⊙49.5902789.636111), Brehmen (⊙49.5694139.554947), Gissigheim (⊙49.5942789.58725), Königheim (⊙49.6177789.595556), and Tauberbischofsheim (⊙49.62259.662778). The center of the heavy rain was in the area of Hof Esselbrunn (⊙49.5730479.590232) and Reisberg (⊙49.5759.6045). The water masses flowed through the Eisgrundgraben (⊙49.5647749.61033, ⊙49.5907679.631603) and Ölbach towards Dittwar (13.5 cubic meters/second) and via the Adelsgraben above Gissigheim as well as the Brehmbach towards Königheim (10 to 19 cubic meters/second) and streamed towards the villages and towns below.[2][3] Around the same time, a two-meter-high flood wave rushed through the Schüpfbach valley towards Kupprichhausen and Lengenrieden on a width of about 100 meters.[2] The flood reached its peak around 5 p.m. with a flow rate of about 100 to 120 m³/s. Subsequently, at 5:18 p.m., District Administrator Georg Denzer declared a disaster alarm for the Main-Tauber district.[1][2] Following this, police teams and a SAR helicopter of the German Air Force were dispatched to the disaster area. Additionally, forces from the DLRG, fire departments, and the Technical Relief Organization were mobilized to the affected area.[3] Shortly thereafter, and only about half an hour after the rain stopped, the situation worsened again: The dam of the Gissigheim retention basin (⊙49.5788069.567639) broke around 5:20 p.m. after being overtopped with extremely high outflows.[3][6] Previously, the bottom outlet had been clogged, and the flood relief system could no longer handle the water masses after debris at the grid cover of the relief system significantly reduced its capacity. As a result, the dam was overtopped by up to 65 cm before breaking, with an estimated maximum outflow of 54 m³/s.[6] The second flood wave triggered by the dam break damaged a large part of the houses in Königheim up to the second floor.[1][3] The dam, like most dams of that time, was not designed to withstand overtopping and was therefore not erosion-resistant on its downstream side. However, the actual cause of the dam break was not the regressive erosion but the integration of the relief system into the dam body, where the interlocking of the overflow structure was missing, and cavities were present due to the recessed components.[6] The maximum water level in the reservoir was 10.7 m, and the storage volume was 0.144 million m³.[7] At the start of the dam break, 0.165 million m³ were stored.[6] Due to the retention effect (storage effect) of the widening Brehmbach valley, the second flood wave in Königheim could no longer be recognized as a single wave in the general flood.[6] The water peak level in Königheim lasted until about 6 p.m. due to the retention effect.[3] Despite the dam break, the retention basin prevented even greater damage in Königheim, as it delayed the flood wave of the Brehmbach, allowing the flood waves from the catchment areas below the basin to flow ahead and preventing the waves from overlapping.[6] The flood in Königheim had largely subsided by around 7 p.m.[3] The railway embankment (⊙49.603579.6438) of the then Tauberbischofsheim–Königheim railway line, lying across the flow direction of the Muckbach from Dittwar near the Dittwar station, prevented even greater disaster for Tauberbischofsheim. The Umpfertal, Königshofen, Sachsenflur, Schweigern, and Boxberg also fared relatively well due to high railway embankments. These caused a backwater, which, however, became a disaster for some other communities.[4] Police, fire departments, the military, the Technical Relief Organization, DLRG, and the Red Cross were continuously deployed.[1][3] Several missing person reports were not confirmed, and there were no fatalities,[8] but nine people were injured. However, over 1,200 animals died, half of them large livestock. 24 buildings were completely destroyed, and 184 were severely damaged.[2] Large parts of the stream and river meadows were underwater, and numerous buildings were at risk of collapse. Electricity and telecommunications networks, as well as water supplies, failed in large parts of the disaster area. In addition to Federal Highway 27, several state and district roads were no longer passable.[8] Over 100 vehicles were swept away by the water masses, completely demolished, or piled on top of each other.[9] On the evening of the disaster, the disaster management team called for boiling drinking water throughout the disaster area.[8] In an initial estimate, the district office's disaster management team assumed about 7,000 people were directly affected by the flood disaster, suffering significant damage to their property.[9]

After the heavy rainfall had already subsided on the evening before, it finally stopped during the night of June 22, 1984. By the morning, a large part of the water had already receded, and the water levels of the Tauber River began to drop again. At 6:45 a.m., technical emergency management teams were established in the four most affected municipalities (Königheim, Tauberbischofsheim, Boxberg, and Lauda-Königshofen). Around 1,000 emergency personnel began the initial cleanup efforts. District Administrator Georg Denzer stated in a press conference in the afternoon: "At the moment, it is not my task to estimate the damage caused. The priority was and still is to contain the disaster and to avert danger to people and animals. Now it's time to clean up and rebuild. And for that, we need help." The initial priority was the evacuation of people from houses at risk of collapse. Additionally, efforts were made to restore power supply, telecommunications networks, and road connections. In areas with destroyed water supplies, the population was provided with water via tank trucks. Since the suction baskets of the fire department pumps were repeatedly clogged, divers had to be deployed in Tauberbischofsheim in some cases. On June 22, Baden-Württemberg's Interior Minister Dietmar Schlee visited the site to gain a personal impression of the emergency situation and promised swift assistance from the state.

The Minister-President of Baden-Württemberg, Lothar Späth, visited Dittwar, one of the hardest-hit locations in the disaster area, on June 23, 1984. Meanwhile, cleanup and safety measures progressed: with the exception of the L 511 road between Heckfeld and Oberlauda, all roads were at least provisionally passable again. Power and drinking water supplies were now ensured through emergency generators (including those from Badenwerk) and water treatment facilities. The structural securing of buildings and bridges, as well as the removal of approximately 1,200 animal carcasses, were the most urgent tasks. The floods had scattered the animal carcasses across the entire, partially still flooded, disaster area or buried them under debris, making cleanup efforts challenging. Additionally, basements were cleared of mud, wood was removed, and homes were cleaned. Another focus was on removing oil slicks after some oil tanks in flooded basements had overturned and leaked. Disaster tourism, which began on this Saturday, proved extremely disruptive for everyone involved. According to emergency personnel, onlookers showed no consideration for the people affected by the disaster and increasingly hindered rescue efforts, necessitating barriers over an ever-wider area.

The cleanup work continued unabated throughout the entire affected area on June 24, 1984. It became apparent that far more buildings than initially assumed were at acute risk of collapse. Approximately 1,150 emergency personnel primarily supported or demolished buildings. Another focus was the removal of debris to ensure that water could flow away in the event of further rainfall. However, part of the emergency personnel had to be withdrawn from the main damage area after the collapse of the railway bridge over the Main between Wertheim and Kreuzwertheim was reported at 1:00 PM. According to eyewitnesses, disturbances caused by onlookers in the affected area gradually took on extreme forms, significantly hindering the operation of vehicles.

In Dittwar and Königheim, the public water supply could be restored on June 25, 1984. However, emergency power generators still had to be used in Königheim to maintain the electricity supply. While cleanup and securing operations in Königheim continued unabated, even within the town area, the focus in other affected areas increasingly shifted to locations outside the towns. Approximately 820 emergency personnel were still engaged in these efforts. For example, stream beds and bridge passages were mostly cleared of coarse debris by hand, as trucks or excavators could hardly be used on the still waterlogged and muddy ground.

The cleanup work continued, especially in the damage centers, with a large number of volunteers. After the mud masses had largely been removed from the flooded houses, severe damage often became apparent that had not been visible at first glance, necessitating further safety measures. As the feed supplies for the surviving livestock in the affected area were running low and many field paths were still impassable, feed increasingly had to be procured from other areas.

On June 27, 1984, approximately 720 helpers were still in action, primarily dedicating themselves to the time-consuming clearing of stream bridges and water passages. Heavy equipment was mostly still unusable on the softened grounds. Further buildings at risk of collapse were secured if possible, and in some cases, demolished. Previously completed operational areas became relevant again after numerous already drained basements were reflooded by infiltrating pressure water. In the meantime, the farmers' association ensured the supply of agricultural businesses with feed and other necessary goods. Water tests conducted by the State Chemical Investigation Office revealed that all water sources in the affected area were contaminated with coliform bacteria. The boiling requirement for drinking water thus remained in place until daily samples could rule out any danger to the population. Heavy clearing equipment was only needed to a limited extent, and the deployed military units could be withdrawn from the disaster operation. Although the operation was not yet completed on June 27, the number of aid workers could be gradually reduced one week after the flood. The Corpus Christi flood triggered the first and so far only disaster alarm in the Main-Tauber district.

After the Corpus Christi flood, the significantly affected areas were partially occupied with reconstruction until the late 1980s. Following this flood, effective flood protection measures for the future were repeatedly discussed. In the Brehmbach Valley, where the Gissigheim retention basin broke during the Corpus Christi flood on June 21, 1984, it took until 2019/20 for a new protective structure, the Königheim flood retention basin, to be built in the Brehmbach Valley near Königheim.

With the declaration of the disaster alarm, a so-called disaster management team was formed at the district office of the Main-Tauber district. According to a pre-prepared plan for such cases, employees of the district office took their place in this leadership team for the entire duration of the operation, coordinating the deployment of technical aid forces. In addition, four technical operation management units were established in the main damage areas to lead the units deployed there. The connection between all these locations was ensured by the telecommunications center set up in the district office. Furthermore, the following authorities, organizations, and units were involved in detail.

The ruin of Goglio was a catastrophic event that occurred on November 1, 1666, affecting the towns of Valgoglio in the Novazza district and Gromo in the upper Val Seriana in the province of Bergamo, causing around seventy victims, many homeless, and the destruction of many factories with severe social and economic consequences.

The Goglio is a mountain stream that originates from the lakes of the Orobie Alps above Lake Aviasco, flowing into the Serio in the valley floor at Pranzera di Gromo after a 5 km course, overcoming a height difference of about 1550 m. Since the 13th century, on the right side of the stream, from the Colarete hamlet to the Pranzera locality, its waters were used through sluices, serving workshops that forged bladed weapons; this area was called the Goglio district. The extraction of iron and other minerals is documented as early as Pliny the Elder (23-79 AD), who referred to Christians condemned by the Romans to extract metals in the mines of the upper Val Seriana as Damnatio ad metalla in his Naturalis Historia. The upper valley, along with neighboring areas, was donated by Charlemagne in 774 to the monasteries of Saint Martin of Tours and Saint-Denis. Reclaimed by the Church of Bergamo in 1026, it became the subject of disputes and clashes centered on mining rights between the bishopric and local noble families who owned the lands with iron and silver mines, including the Colleoni and Rivola families. In 1267, the village obtained the privilege of being called a borough, with the right to work the minerals and enjoy the income derived from extraction and processing. Ironworking in the upper valley became very important and more productive under Venetian rule in 1427; it included not only the territory of Gromo, which was considered the "little Toledo," but also the surrounding areas. The altarpiece of the Church of San Gregorio, titled Madonna with Child between Saints Gregory the Great and Charles Borromeo, painted in 1624 by Enea Salmeggia, and the private property map drawn by notary Bartolomeo Scacchi illustrate how the village appeared at the time and where the forges, residences, and other activities were located.

"[...] there existed along the Golio stream a district of Gromo, a noble land of this valley, of perhaps twenty families. They were celebrating All Saints' Day, when a part of the overhanging mountain broke off and fell with such force that from the whirlwind preceding it, boulders of immense size were hurled into the air with a terrifying noise [...] It destroyed to the foundations eighteen houses, a church, an oratory; two bridges, thirty buildings, twenty-seven of which were used for the manufacture of weapons, and crushed sixty-three people."

The disastrous event occurred on November 1, 1666, All Saints' Day, at noon. Several concurrent events took place which, despite having different causes, developed in a chain reaction. Written accounts tell of continuous days of heavy rain that had swollen the stream, a phenomenon certainly not uncommon, as its waters were not regulated by dams or artificial reservoirs. Testimonies collected from shepherds who were staying in the area on the opposite side of the valley and witnessed the event describe a strong wind that carried away people and rocks; subsequently, a loud roar was heard, caused by the collapse of a part of the mountain called Cima Bani, likely triggered by the rains and the severe deforestation that had occurred over the centuries to meet the great demand for charcoal furnaces, which had made the terrain unstable. As it descended into the valley, the landslide dragged trees and rocks with it, skirting the Novazza hamlet of Valgoglio, until it reached the Colarete hamlet, where it settled above the Goglio stream, blocking it and forming a lake, which, swollen with water, soil, and debris, overflowed, carrying with it the material and everything in its path, including the forges, with their furnaces, hammers, warehouses, houses, and even two small churches. Gabriele Medolago's book cites on page 26: the church was entirely destroyed... along with some properties located in the same district, and there was no hope of rebuilding churches or anything else due to the instability of the river. Upon reaching the valley floor, this landslide blocked the Serio River, which, swollen with debris and incessant rains, overflowed, carrying away men and houses beyond the town's borders.  
All of this happened in the time of a Pater Noster.

"[...] there was a district located at a distance of two musket shots from the land of Gromo, situated above the Golio river [...] due to the convenience of said river, twenty-seven buildings were constructed, all dedicated to the manufacture of arms [...] on the days of saints [...] a part of the mountain detached itself with barns, woods, and lands above the said district at a distance of about a thousand steps" (notary Bartolomeo Scacchi, Municipality of Gromo) thus begins the report of notary Bartolomeo Scacchi[9]; while the report of the Captain to Venice recounts, "Most Serene Prince, it is worthy of the supreme attention of Your Serenity the strange and frightening incident that occurred in the land of Goglio in the Seriana Valley [...] the land lay above a placid little river named Golio, about thirty miles from there (Bergamo) [...] which continuously served various buildings and forges for the work of blades, swords, as well as many other ironworks [...] the day before yesterday, on All Saints' Day, around noon, a mountain collapsed and crumbled" (Captain Giovanni Francesco Dandolo, November 3, 1666, State Archives of Venice). The geography of the village, divided into three distinct nuclei, located on the west side of the Serio river, and the event occurring on a holiday, saved a good part of the villagers: in fact, the documented victims number between 63 and 67. The district of Goglio was located in the southernmost part of the village; here were 27 forges; the workers' houses; two small churches, that of San Rocco, the small oratory called Santa Croce[10], and two bridges that allowed access to the northern area of the valley. In the upper part was the village, situated on a hill, with the castle and the palace inhabited by noble families, and further north in the valley, the parish church, which, given the midday hour, fortunately hosted the faithful for the All Saints' Day services. Testimonies of the event have been documented since the first days. On November 3, a dispatch was sent to Venice by Captain Francesco Dandolo and Podestà Gerolamo Giustiniano, with a detailed account of the events, damages, and victims; this document is preserved in the State Archives of Venice. On November 6, the archpriest of Clusone, Alessandro Ghirardelli, came for an inspection and, although he left a somewhat exaggerated testimony, he describes not only the material damages but also the emotional state of the villagers; as does the document of notary Gregorio Scacchi, now preserved in the archives of the parish of Gromo. The flooding of the Serio carried downstream not only debris but also the bodies of the victims, which are documented in the parish registers. The remains of the dead extracted from the river's waters are documented in the archives of Parre, Alzano Lombardo, and as far as Seriate. The event was also reported by the historian Giovanni Maironi da Ponte[11]."

The consequences were severe because, both in the municipality of Gromo and Valgoglio, the disaster had destroyed the main activity. The 27 forges, which were capable of producing up to 1,000 sword blades per day and provided work for the community's families, were completely destroyed. The population decline within the first month was 30%; the flood had forced the workforce to migrate to other locations, suddenly finding themselves without work and unable to wait for the reconstruction, which could not be immediate. Even the dead were not immediately extracted from the rubble but are documented in church records from December 1666 through all of 1667. In Venice, measures were initiated for tax relief, which were initially granted for five years and then renewed from time to time. The damages were estimated at 60,000 scudi, justifying the exemptions from the payment of taxes and rents, which were applied from 1666 until the mid-18th century. In 1733, a list was drawn up of families entitled to compensation from the Venetian Republic. Recovery and reconstruction were very slow; it took fifty years before the destroyed part of the settlement was reused. Other forges were built, but the activity that had made the town of Gromo famous no longer yielded the same profits: times had changed, and demands were different. However, subsequent production is documented, not only of bladed weapons but also of arquebuses.

«In a ducal decree of the exalted Venetian Senate dated March 19, 1667, which grants the community of Gromo a ten-year exemption from all real and personal taxes […] due to the misfortune that occurred to the community itself in the district of Goglio, where sixty-three people lost their lives under the ruins of a piece of mountain that collapsed, and as a result not only were the dwellings of the entire aforementioned district swept away, but the lands were destroyed along with the ruins of thirty-two buildings, which were their means of sustenance […]» (Maironi da Ponte – Odeporic or Historical Political Natural Dictionary)

Article_Name: Riuada de 1982 al Berguedà - Viquipèdia, l'enciclopèdia lliure

Whole_Text.content: The 1982 flood in Berguedà is the set of catastrophic effects caused by the historic rise of the Llobregat River and its tributaries in the Berguedà region during November 7 and 8, 1982, due to intense downpours that affected the Pyrenean and pre-Pyrenean areas. In Berguedà, it had severe consequences for the economy, as in addition to destroying communication infrastructures and private properties, it severely impacted the textile industry and mining, the two economic pillars of the region at that time. The existence of the Baells dam prevented the damages from being even more severe in the Llobregat valley. Fortunately, there were no human losses, unlike in Alt Urgell and Andorra, where such losses occurred due to these downpours.

From November 6th, due to the phenomenon known as a cold drop or DANA, exceptionally intense rains occurred in the Catalan Pyrenees that lasted 48 hours. At that time, there was no pluviographic device in Berguedà to measure the intensity of rain per hour, but the total rainfall over 48 hours in the upper Berguedà was around 400 mm on average, meaning it is estimated that in two days, the amount of rain equivalent to half a year fell. As a consequence, the flow rates of the rivers and streams in the Llobregat basin increased extraordinarily.

At 4 p.m. on November 7, a Sunday, the Baells reservoir, which was at level 621, was receiving between 400 and 500 m³/s. Considering that the safety level is at 625, and that the bottom and mid-level gates can release up to 160 m³/s, it was already anticipated that the spillway gates would need to be opened. Between 4 and 5 p.m., the nearest towns were alerted: the Civil Guard, Red Cross, Civil Protection, Water Confederation, and Berga Firefighters. The town councils were not notified, as it was considered that at that time no one would be there. 

In the towns of lower Berguedà located along the Llobregat River, such as Gironella, concern began to grow over the river's rise. Although it had rained in the lower part of the region, such a significant increase in flow was not explained, as the magnitude of the rainfall in upper Berguedà was unknown. The intensity of the rain increased the higher up one went.

By 8 p.m., the water had already reached the level of the river street in Gironella, and the local Red Cross and volunteer firefighters began working, monitoring the river's course. At 10:30 p.m., the peak time for water inflow into the La Baells reservoir at 1,200 m³/s, a call was made from the reservoir to the Gironella Nursing Home, informing them that they had begun evacuating the residents. Considering the time it would take for the water to arrive, the gates were opened. 800 m³/s were released, while the usual flow is 7 m³/s. The reservoir level reached 631.48, one and a half meters above the maximum capacity (630). It was a delicate moment, as it was the first time the reservoir had reached this point, and it was unknown how the dam would respond.

The flood caused a shock to the economy of Berguedà, with very significant losses in the region's companies, on one hand due to the destruction of machinery and facilities, and on the other due to the halt in production.  
The quantification of losses caused by the flood and the deluge in economic activities indicates that 49% corresponds to mining, 41% to industry, 8% to agriculture, and 2% to commerce. Regarding municipalities, those with the highest losses are, in order: Cercs (1,500 million pts.), Puig-reig (737), Gironella (180), Casserres (144), Guardiola (77), Berga (76), Fígols (62), La Pobla (52). On the other hand, concerning private properties, the most affected were the towns with buildings along the river. The force of the water, when the water level reached the height of the buildings, demolished several homes, some completely and others partially. The affected municipalities were: Guardiola, Gironella, and La Pobla de Lillet. Additionally, these same towns, along with the towns of Puig-reig, Cercs, and Bagà, suffered damages to municipal facilities, communications, and public works such as bridges, paths, roads, retaining walls, etc. Overall, damages to roads, bridges, and local and regional road communications exceeded 100 million pesetas.

Due to their nature, all the numerous textile colonies in the region were intensely affected, as these are factories built near a river to harness hydraulic energy to operate the machines. The hydroelectric facilities that generate the energy (or most of the energy) needed by the factory were not spared from the devastating effects of the flood, as the turbine, along with the canal and the dam, are located at the lowest level, right by the river. The rise in the river level covered all the machinery and installations, which meant that, in addition to repairing or replacing them, they were left without energy production. The companies affected in the turbines in Berguedà were: Filatura Berguedana (La Pobla de Lillet), Colònia Rosal, Cal Metre (Gironella), Filats i Teixits Fusté (Cal Bassacs), Viladomiu Nou, Viladomiu Vell, Ferrer (Vilada), Colònia Guixaró (Casserres), Colònia Prat (Puig-reig), Colònia Pons (Puig-reig), Colònia Marçal (Puig-reig), Colònia Manent (Puig-reig), and l'Ametlla de Merola. Secondly, to a greater or lesser extent, water entered the factories and damaged the machinery and materials (whether raw or processed). One of the most affected was the l'Ametlla de Merola factory, where damages were estimated at 500 million pesetas, and a contract suspension file was issued for the entire workforce, 350 workers.

The most important group of mining operations in Berguedà were the Fígols mines, which were mainly accessed through the La Consolació entrance (Cercs). This operation, consisting of a network of shafts and galleries, all interconnected, with a drop of 2,000 m, is located inside a mountainous massif, on the exterior of which several streams and brooks flow. The different openings of the operation acted like a sponge through which water filtered, gradually flooding all the galleries and accumulating in the deepest part of the operation, where it reached a height of 75 m. All the machinery and equipment there became unusable. As a result, the company filed a temporary suspension of contracts affecting 300 workers (although initially it was planned for 776 workers).

Whole_Text.header: Gironella, a village by the river
Whole_Text.content: The alert in the town of Gironella began at 8 p.m. on Sunday, November 7, when the water of the Llobregat River reached the level of Riu Street. The Red Cross entered the Victoria Cinema to warn if there were residents with houses along the riverbank. Volunteer firefighters were monitoring the Hospital building, the elderly residence. Between nine and half-past nine, a crowd of people had already gathered near the Eres Bridge and the Old Bridge, where it was expected that the flood would have repercussions. At the same time, a house on Riu Street, the Ferrer family (known as Maruja's house), had already been evacuated as the water was rising above the door. Simultaneously, water began to enter the lower levels of the Sant Roc Hospital-Residence; however, the lack of communication about what was happening upstream and the lack of foresight meant that the evacuation of the elderly did not begin until much later. Access to the Old Bridge and the Eres Bridge was cut off due to the risk of collapse, which eventually happened, isolating the Cal Ramons neighborhood and the Eres neighborhood from the urban center. The old town could only be accessed via the wall. Evacuations began for houses on the left side of Avinguda Catalunya, from the Eres Bridge to the Slaughterhouse. Riu Street was also evacuated, where it was no longer passable, and water was already entering the lower levels and ground-floor apartments. On this street, water entered all the lower levels, and several homes were completely destroyed. Regarding the Sant Roc Residence, as water reached the main door, all elderly residents were evacuated through the ambulance garage and the passage leading to Avinguda Catalunya, and they were initially relocated to the Pearl Pub, the Victoria Cinema, and the lower levels of the Parish Hall. The operation lasted until 3 a.m. The Apolo building on Avinguda Catalunya was also evacuated as water was undermining its foundations. Power, drinking water, and telephone supply cuts persisted for much of the following day, Monday. The City Council offered housing and financial aid to families who had lost their homes.

Whole_Text.header: L'Ametlla de Merola, an example of recovery
Whole_Text.content: The textile factory of Ametlla de Merola was the most affected by the flood in Berguedà. The water reached a level of 1.5 m inside the factory, and 1.60 m in the loom room. When the water level receded, the first people who entered the building found that the machinery was rendered unusable—some machines in an irreparable state—walls had collapsed, everything was covered in mud, and the thread had been scattered. The Bonser warehouse, which was full of manufactured goods, was left empty. The initiative to try to resume activity began immediately. The company applied for unemployment benefits for the workers. At the same time, the population, which largely depended on work at the factory, collaborated in the recovery efforts. The predominant sentiment was to act immediately to return to normality. The first task that kept most of the population busy was removing mud, using rakes and dumpers. Meanwhile, women and retirees also contributed by cleaning small parts. Efforts were made to save the electrical components of the looms, and mud was removed from the looms using the motor pump lent by farmers from the municipality of Sagàs, which were later cleaned with petroleum and sprayed with anti-corrosive agents. The Vocational Training School of Navàs also provided personnel and tools to assist in the recovery efforts. In short, it was a model of cooperation to save not only a company, on which jobs depended, but also to restore normality to a population, with the associated social and cultural aspects.

Whole_Text.content: The Benevento flood of October 15, 2015, occurred due to heavy rains that affected the basin of all the waterways in the province of Benevento. The waterways that caused the most disruption were the Calore, the Sabato, and the Tammaro. The most affected areas were Ponte, San Giorgio la Molara, Solopaca, Paupisi, Benevento, Montesarchio, Airola, and Pietrelcina.

The main causes are the heavy rains that fell on the ground, which had reached saturation and was unable to absorb more water, and the alleged opening of the Campolattaro dam on the Tammaro River, the watercourse that caused the most disruption to the populations of the Benevento area. The river reached unprecedented flood levels, and along with the exceptional flood of the Calore River, brought the provincial capital and several neighboring municipalities to their knees.

The damages were numerous, starting with the agricultural sector, literally devastated by this event, then severe damages were suffered by livestock and the industrial sector. There were two victims. One, caused by the flooding of the Tammaro, was a seventy-year-old woman from Pago Veiano, swept away by the waters. The second victim, caused by the flooding of the Calore, was a man from Varoni di Montesarchio, who, while trying to clear the basement of mud, was overwhelmed.

Whole_Text.content: The 2016 Piedmont flood is one of the most violent floods recorded in Piedmont, classified in some areas up to level 3 by the alert bulletin issued by the Civil Protection Department. The event affected the regional territory between November 21 and 25, 2016, when a depression system extending from the British Isles to the northern African coasts channeled intense southeast humid currents near the Alpine chain. This meteorological configuration was characterized by persistent and abundant rainfall, especially near the western and northern Alpine reliefs and the areas bordering Liguria. The dynamics and meteorological configuration were similar to the flood that affected Piedmont in 2000. The November 2016 flood caused significant damage across much of the regional territory, due to numerous landslides, mudslides, and flooding with frequent overflow of streams. During the event, one victim was recorded in Perosa Argentina, in the Pinerolo area, found only after several days by firefighters, about ten kilometers from where they disappeared, in the Chisone stream.

Analyzing the evolution in detail, the saturation effect of moist air masses induced by orographic lifting concentrated the phenomena predominantly near the Alpine reliefs. In fact, heavy snowfalls were recorded above mid-high altitudes, accumulating over 1 meter of fresh snow in Sestriere. Below are some rainfall totals recorded at the end of the worsening weather by some hydro-meteorological stations of ARPA Piemonte (Regional Agency for Environmental Protection) present in the area. In Niquidetto, 613.2 mm were recorded; 584.8 mm in Viù; 324 mm in Pinerolo in the Turin area; 586.6 mm in Barge; 547.8 mm in Ponte di Nava Tanaro in the Cuneo area; 574.2 mm in Calizzano in the Savona area.

The high altitude of the snowfall, which generally remained above 1700 meters, caused heavy and persistent rains at medium altitudes, leading to a significant increase in the hydrometric levels of the hydrographic network, often exceeding the danger threshold, numerous slope phenomena, and landslides.

The greatest concern was caused by the Tanaro river network, which exceeded the danger threshold multiple times during the event. The peak flow was recorded on the morning of November 25, when ARPA hydrometric stations measured 4.67 m at Ponte di Nava, 4.88 m at Garessio, 6.14 m at Piantorre, 6.5 m at Farigliano, and 6.14 m at Alba. Further downstream in the basin, in the sections between Asti and Alessandria, the Tanaro exceeded danger levels on the morning of November 25, reached its peak in the afternoon (Asti: 7.71 m, Masio: 5.79 m), and fell below danger levels between the evening and the following morning. In the Bormida basin, hydrometric levels rose but remained below warning levels until November 24, when they began to rise rapidly, surpassing danger levels and reaching their peak in the Alessandria area during the day of the 25th, with 5.08 m at Cassine Maggiore and 8.3 m at Alessandria. In Alessandria, it fell below danger levels in the early hours of November 26. In the Turin area, hydrometric levels increased significantly starting November 24. In particular, the Pellice at Villafranca exceeded danger levels on the afternoon of November 24, reaching a peak of 6.12 m and then falling below danger levels on the morning of the 25th. The Chisola at La Loggia exceeded danger levels on the evening of November 24, reaching a peak of 7.41 m on the morning of the 25th, and then falling below danger levels on the morning of the 26th. In Turin, near the confluence with the Po, the Dora Riparia remained slightly above danger levels from the early morning hours of November 25 until early afternoon, reaching a peak of 4.29 m. The Stura di Lanzo remained above warning levels from the morning of November 24 to the morning of the 25th, approaching but not reaching danger levels, with a peak of 3.09 m in the early hours of November 25. Hydrometric levels of the Po River began to rise significantly on November 24, exceeding danger levels from Moncalieri to Crescentino Po in the evening of November 24, while at Carignano and Casale Monferrato in the morning of November 25, and in the Alessandria area in the afternoon of the 25th. Peaks were reached at Carignano with 6.71 m, at Moncalieri with 8.72 m, and at Turin with 6.35 m between the afternoon and night of November 25, representing the second-highest values after the 1839 flood. Levels fell below danger levels on the morning of November 26 throughout the river's course, except in the section downstream of Turin between Castiglione and Crescentino, where they had already fallen by the evening of the 25th.

The valleys that recorded the most significant hydro-geological disruptions were Val Chisone and Val Germanasca, in the Pinerolo area, where some landslides and intense slope phenomena isolated some inhabited centers and caused significant damage.

Whole_Text.content: The flash flood that struck western and central Bohemia on May 25 and 26, 1872, was one of the most devastating reliably documented natural disasters in Czech territory, reaching the level of a thousand-year flood on the Berounka River. A cyclone formed at the frontal boundary in the Blšanka and Střela river basins, causing very intense torrential rainfall on the afternoon of May 25, with a record 237 mm falling in Mladotice in an hour and a half. In Beroun, the flow rate of the Berounka River reached an unprecedented 2,500 cubic meters per second, while the Vltava in Prague peaked at a flow rate of 3,300 m³/s. Because the main flood wave arrived at night, there were significant losses of life: officially, 337 deaths were recorded, with the worst-affected areas being Holedeč (43 people) and Nebřeziny (40 people). A large number of domestic animals also perished, thousands of people lost their homes, five pond dams were breached on the Blšanka River, a massive landslide caused the damming of the Mladotice stream and created the Odlezelské Lake, while on the same stream, the extensive Mladotice pond was breached.
